story:
What turns you on? 

What shuts you down? 

What really makes you HAPPY?

These are the types of questions we asked ourselves while conceiving this world premiere play, Happy by Liz Thaler, premiering in F*ckFest, a sex positive theatre festival at The Brick (Williamsburg, NYC) in June 2015.
This multi-faceted, funny, and, above all, honest portrayal of kink culture was created to represent this much-misunderstood and maligned community with respect and realness (think: anti-50 Shades).

HAPPY originated as a 10 minute play in 3 parts, developed through Amios' monthly short play series SHOTZ, for December 2013's Erotica-themed Voulez Vous Coucher Avec SHOTZ?. This version was remounted for 6 performances at The Brick as part of the Winter Tens One Act festival in January 2014, taking second place in the two-week competition. 

After such intense investigation into these characters, playwright Liz Thaler then expanded the piece, taking those first 10 minutes and following its players through their changing and challenging relationships. The full length was then given a public staged reading by Amios in April 2014 at Shetler Studios. 

The play continues to evolve in an open collaboration with the creative team, who relishes an opportunity to produce a minimalist festival staging to further workshop the full-length piece before they embark upon a full run in 2015/16.

What We Need & What You Get

Though our production costs are low, and we receive a lot of assistance from The Brick, we still need to compensate the artists involved with this premiere production. Your tax-deductible contribution through In Extremis' fiscal sponsorship with Fractured Atlas will go directly to paying the incredible team of artists a modest stipend for their time and talent, as well as helping offset the costs of all of the costumes, props, and set required to bring this show to life.

What do you get in return (other than the satisfaction of supporting new work and emerging artists)? Check out the perks to your right! You could receive a personal video from Liz and Lauren explaining the kink term of your choice, tickets to the show, invitations to the official cast party, or even take home an actual prop from the show!

Your Impact

HAPPY's F*ckFest production will, in many ways, enable the creators to embark on a longer and more fully realized production run in the future. Through rehearsal, we will continue to discover and develop the script, and how we want to bring it to life. New audiences will be exposed to the work, including industry professionals who can assist the creative team in securing the connections and funding necessary for a full run in their own space. And, it is our hope that through this work we will shine a different light on the kink community than has been represented elsewhere in the media. 

Most importantly, we hope entertain and enlighten audiences from Brooklyn and beyond with this challenging and thoughtful new work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow our journey to production on social media! You can follow us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/happytheplay), Twitter (@HappyThePlay), and Instagram (@HappyThePlay). You'll get an intimate look at the making of this world-premiere work from start to finish.

You have 4 chances to catch the show for yourself this summer. Tickets are only $18 and will also help contribute to the future life of this production.

Come on, get HAPPY!

The Brick & In Extremis Theater Company present

HAPPY 

by Liz Thaler

"A love story with a few kinks"

directed by Lauren Miller

produced by Peryn Schmitt

featuring: Hanna Cheek*, Michael Grew*, David Jenkins, Todd Lawson*, Cassandra Paras, and Kathleen Wallace*. 

*denotes member of Actors' Equity Association

Premiering in F*ckFest at The Brick in June 2015.

More info at www.bricktheater.com and www.inextremistheater.org

"Sparks fly when kink novice Alex encounters professional dominant Luke at a fetish party. But when these private roles clash with their public selves, how do they know what’s real and make-believe? A serio-comedy about what turns us on, what shuts us down, and what really makes us Happy."

story:
OUR STORY

Kelrik has been dedicated to providing quality live theater in San Luis Obispo and Los Angeles for years. Our goal is to challenge, motivate, enlighten and captivate our audiences; to introduce young children to, and foster their appreciation of live theater; to evoke thought and change, both personally and within our society; and, of course to entertain. After the loss of our beloved home at Unity in 2013 we have diligently searched or a new place to call home.  However the process has been a little bumpy financially.


WHY DO WE NEED IT?

Producing Theatre is a huge undertaking and isn’t possible without the support of our community. While we at Kelrik are masters of making the most out of very little, with two major productions coming up, we need your help getting them up and running to their highest quality. The cost of putting up Peter Pan alone, will be about $50,000. Willy Wonka is close to $30,000.

Only 50% of a theatre company’s income is achieved  by ticket sales.  For any theatre company to flourish and remain financially stable, it relies on donations from organizations, private donors, volunteers, partnerships, corporate sponsors, grants, and fundraising efforts.   That means we have to rely on our community for support.

We need some financial LOVE from you in order to cover all the production costs including:

·  *Performance Rights and Music

·  *Theater and Rehearsal rental space

·  *Director, Choreographer, Musical Director, Designers

·  *Costumes, Props and Sets

·  *Lighting

·  *Promotion and Advertising

We are committed giving our actors and audience a professional theater experience.  Every dollar raised will go toward production costs for our 2015 CELEBRATE season.  With your help, this season will be a year of growth, change and opportunity for many exciting and challenging entertaining productions.  


THE IMPACT

Our project affects the entire SLO and NOHO communities…  especially YOU! Our project is so valuable to our funders in:

·  Creating jobs

·  Providing a safe and inviting environment that induces creativity

·  Presenting a variety of musicals through innovative eyes

·  Educating and training the audiences of tomorrow so theater continues to enrich our lives

What happens if we don't reach our goal? 

WE KEEP GOING! It will take up to three years to gain and build a devoted base of supporters who will continue at attend a Kelrik Production.  We might not reach that potential crowd with this fundraising campaign.  The money raised will go towards securing our most prominent needs in the season. 

OTHER WAY YOU CAN HELP

1) Can't give now? That's okay! Kelrik still loves you and we want you to be a part of our growing future.  Please stay connected for future events, fundraisers, or season announcements by joining our newsletter HERE.

2) Save the date! Our next show, Peter Pan will play July 10 – 19, 2015 in San Luis Obispo.  Put that on your calendar NOW to join us.  Come see a show!

3)  It takes a village to put on a show and we can only succeed with your help.  Become part of the Kelrik family by sharing this project with your friends and loved ones.  You can be a huge help to us by simply spreading the word about our campaign and sharing our video on Facebook and Twitter. You can use the IndieGoGo share tools to make this easier. And check out our website to learn more about our company, members, workshops and productions: www.kelrikproductions.org  You can also follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

We are Christine Noah, Quincy Newkirk, and Amos McCandless, and together we are The Avant Guardians, a new local theatre company in Charlotte, NC committed to producing contemporary work and pushing boundaries. We are all Davidson College alumni who studied theatre and decided that our passion for our creative art could not be ignored. Of course, we have our day jobs to keep our lights on and our cupboards full of mac 'n' cheese: Christine works for a nonprofit, Quincy is the fellow for Davidson's Department of Theatre, and Amos is a college counselor. But we have all been witness to the transformative, subversive, and unifying power of theatre, and we are committed to sharing that power with our community.

To that end, we have set out to produce the Regional Premiere of Mike Bartlett's BULL. First produced in 2013, BULL is described by Dramatists Play Service as "an allegorical deathmatch between business colleagues—full of bizarre power plays and one-upmanship—wherein one of three employees is allegedly going to be fired. The odds against our protagonist are stacked from the outset: rumple-faced sad-sack Thomas never quite gets his footing against opponents Tony, a shark in wolf's clothing, and Isobel, a snaky number with a talent for undermining." 

British playwright Bartlett got the idea for the play from watching an actual bull fight in Mexico. "It’s a hard and complicated thing to see something you really disapprove of and hate but that does things to your animalistic instincts, which is thrilling,” he said in an interview with the Evening Standard. “You can see why Christians and lions happened, why people turned out for public hangings, why people love seeing these things on the internet — it activates something primal and unsanitised.” 

Bartlett said he wanted above all to show “how bullying works when you are an adult, which is quite a different thing to how it happens when you are a child. It is quite difficult to see it but if you are on the receiving end you feel it straight away. In an office, often you don’t notice it until it is already happening and you are complicit in it. Sometimes it is almost as if the person being bullied is playing up to the role they have been cast in because it’s a way of taking part.” This subject is something that real people with real jobs and real lives can relate to--something Bartlett thinks is essential for work to connect with audiences.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $1,200 for our production of BULL, which breaks down as follows:

  • Royalties: $500
  • Design costs: $300
  • Marketing/printing: $200
  • Venue rental: $200
If we do not reach our goal, we will reduce our production costs as much as we can and fund it ourselves, using our box office proceeds to fill in the gaps. If we do reach our goal, however, we should be able to use most of our box office proceeds to fund our next project, creating a more sustainable production model.

Check out our donor benefits levels to the right under "Perks." We may not have much to give, but we will do our best to show you how much your donation means to us. If you'd like to give more than what is listed, we'd be happy to work with you to create a benefits package that best fits you and your donation.

The Impact

All three of us at The Avant Guardians want nothing more than to create a meaningful piece of theatre that will exhilarate, move, and inspire. If passion and determination could serve as currency, we could have this show paid for a hundred times over. Unfortunately, arts funding isn't very easy to come by, especially for companies who are just starting out, which can make getting on your feet a little tough. Your support--monetary or otherwise-- of this project would be invaluable to us as we work to establish ourselves as theatre practitioners.

But the positive impact won't just be on us--it will also be on our audiences. If you come to see the show, we promise to present you with something that will challenge you, excite you, and, hopefully, make you see something in the world a little bit differently. That's the beauty of theatre: it enriches the lives of everyone it touches.

Performances will take place at the Warehouse Performing Arts Center in Cornelius July 16-18 and 24-26.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can certainly help us by sharing this campaign on social media and via email, "liking" our Facebook page, or just sending us supportive thoughts and comments--because a little encouragement can go a long way.

And no matter how you choose to support us, let us go ahead and say THANK YOU!

Love,

The Avant Guardians

Love,

story:
The Overdevelopment of Scott 

~ a theatre piece by Sharon Josephine Fogarty

Featuring two Technicians (Martin Everall and Paul Fraccalvieri) who breed human labrats for fun and profit and Scott (Kevin Pruitt) whose kindness alters their plan. 

Current lab subjects:

Gracious (bred for eating disorders)..........................................Karen Christie-Ward

Rita (for cosmetics & hygiene products).......................................... Elizabeth Mozer

Virginia (for tobacco addiction)............................................................... Polly Korbel

Tito (for violence)...................................................................................... Sanjay Kaul

Tammy (to be a good listener).................................................Saki Masuda Aoyama

Freddie (raised on Television)......................................................... Jason Grossman

Esther (for sexual addiction)........................................................... Savannah Graner

Written & Directed by S.J. Fogarty

Assistant Director, U/S: Julie Lauren Stevens

Lighting Design by David Alan Comstock

Stage Managed by Carolyn Resnick

In 2014 MAKING LIGHT was awarded Best Play by the Thespis Theater Festival for The Devil of Delancey Street.  Fogarty was entered into the Indie Theatre Hall of Fame with a People of the Year award in 2005, the Manhattan Theatre Source Hall of Fame in 2006 and was runner up for Best Play in the Venus/Adonis Festival 2015 for Bride of Frankenstein ~ an experiment in intimacy.  Fogarty recently received recognition for Best Comedic Song for Why Do You Take So Long to Come. MAKING LIGHT was founded in 1986 to 'heal the planet one play at a time,' but mostly we've just been trying to heal ourselves and maybe set an example.

You are invited... 

To come to our party featuring a staged reading of TODOS...

Sunday, August 30th, 2015:

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2049233

Doors open: 4:00 PM, reading starts about 4:30 PM
Suggested Donation: $20.00, refreshments available, cash only.
At Theaterlab, 357 West 36th Street, 3rd Floor, NYC
Further info, email: makinglighttheatre@gmail.com.

Here's what we need...

  • REHEARSALS: The Overdevelopment of Scott requires 3 rehearsals per week for 8 weeks.  Rehearsal space rental averages $70 each.  3 x 8 x $70 = $1,680.
  • THEATRE RENTAL: We are considering TheaterLab at 357 West 36th Street, NYC which costs $2,000 per week for 2 weeks = $4,000.
  • ACTORS PAY: We would like to reimburse actors for their meals and transportation during rehearsals/performances and offer a stipend of $50 per performance per performer.  We hope to have 8 performances and there are 11 cast members = $4,400.
  • CREW PAY:  Our Lighting Designer usually charges $350 per design.  Additionally, we would like to pay our Stage Manager $50 per performance, $50 x 8 = $400.  Total tech cost $750.
  • INSURANCE: Since this is an AEA Showcase, we usually purchase Volunteer Accident insurance from State Farm for about $420.
  • GRAND TOTAL $11,250.

Here are some interesting reasons why theatre is important:

http://theatrewashington.org/content/7-reasons-why-theatre-makes-our-lives-better

http://www.tcgcircle.org/2014/06/the-top-ten-reasons-why-theatre-is-still-important-in-the-twenty-first-century/

http://www.oldcreamery.com/about-theatre/blog/why-go-theatre/

story:
[English follows]

Salut à tous,

 
Je m’appelle Jean-Sébastien et je suis un grand passionné d’art contemporain sous toutes ses formes. Je m’investis déjà dans la communauté locale artistique via le Cercle des jeunes philanthropes du musée des Beaux-Arts de Montréal, et cette année j’ai décidé d’aller encore plus loin: je m’engage à courir le triathlon de Charlevoix pour soutenir une activité de Tangente dédiée au jeune public.


  • Le triathlon de Charlevoix, c’est quoi?

    Triathlon sprint : 20 km de vélo, 750 m de natation, et 5 km de course le 26 juillet 2015.

  • Tangente, c'est qui, c'est quoi?

    Tangente est un lieu de diffusion, de développement et un centre de documentation en danse contemporaine, offrant un environnement propice à la prise de risque artistique et à la création. Une des ses missions est notamment de sensibiliser le jeune public à la danse contemporaine, via des activités interactives avec des artistes.

  • À quoi servira le montant récolté?

    Il nous permettra d’inviter gratuitement 50 élèves du primaire à une activité artistique interactive avec Adam Kinner, artiste programmé dans notre saison 2015-2016. L’atelier stimulera leur imaginaire de manière collective en faisant appel une créativité insoupçonnée. Voilà un exemple d'atelier organisé par Tangente:

     
    Cette animation s’insère dans Le mois des arts orchestré par La Commission scolaire de Montréal, qui permet chaque année à des écoles de milieu défavorisé d’organiser gratuitement des projets culturels en partenariat avec de nombreux organismes locaux.

  • Quel est notre objectif?
    $900 - c'est le coût total pour mettre en place l'activité: rémunérer l'artiste et le médiateur, payer la salle du Monument National et les collations.

  • Charlevoix, c'est loin...

    Grâce à la magie d'Internet, tu peux suivre mon entrainement, voir la course et m'encourager en direct en un clic depuis ton salon. 

  • Pour ceux qui en doutent, je m'entraine vraiment

    Retrouve toutes les photos et vidéos de mon entrainement sur l'évènement Facebook.


On compte sur vous pour soutenir la créativité des jeunes!


---------------------


Hi everyone,


My name is Jean-Sébastien and I'm fond of contemporary art in all its forms. I'm already involved in local artistic community through The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts’ Young Philanthropists’ Circle. This year, I decided to challenge myself by running the Charlevoix triathlon for Tangente, in order to support Tangente's activity for kids.

  • Charlevoix what?

    Charlevoix triathlon sprint is a 20Km cycle race + a 750m swim + a 5Km run.

  • What is Tangente?
    Tangente is a space for contemporary dance presentation and public development, as well as a documentation and archive center, which encourage artistic risk taking and creation. One of its missions is to educate young people to contemporary dance. 

  • What will be the amount collected used for?

    The total amount collected will allow us to invite for free 50 primary school students to an interactive artistic activity with Adam Kinner, who will also present his show during our 2015-2016 season. The workshop will be specifically designed to engage their burgeoning imagination in a collective way.
    Here is an exemple of a former workshop organized by Tangente:

     
    This animation will be part of The month of arts, orchestrated each year by La Commission scolaire de Montréal, which give to schools from underprivileged areas the opportunity to organize cultural projects for free in partnership with local organizations.

  • What is our goal?

    $900, which is the total cost to set up the workshop including the fees for the artist and and the mediator, the renting of the stage at the Monument National, the snacks.

  • Charlevoix is a bit far...

    Thanks to the magic of the internet, you can follow my training and the triathlon live from your coach... and even cheer me on in one click.

  • I actually train for real

    You can follow my training with pics and videos on our Facebook event.


We count on you to support creativity among young people!


Nos partenaires - Our partners:

story:
PLEASE HELP BRING ASYLUM TO PHILADELPHIA SPRING 2015!


Based on a true story of a young woman who fled Uganda to escape an honor killing at the hands of her father, Asylum is a vivid display of courage and an unyielding will to live. Philadelphia was at the heart of this production from the very beginning (the cast and crew from the world premier were all from the Philly region), and it's fitting that we strive to bring it to our home city---the city of Brotherly Love--one that is known for having passionate people who stand up for what's right whether it's easy to do so or not. 

Asylum is an award-winning play (NYC 2012 Downtown Urban Theater Festival) that is about human rights, gay rights and women’s rights. It is more than entertainment. It is bigger than theatre. It is about the courage to fight for one’s right to dignity, and the most primal and deepest human need of all: LOVE. Though the story delves into religious intolerance and violence against women, it still manages to capture the power of faith, the force of will and the audacity of hope. Asylum has a raw honesty that’s not only unique to the story, but extremely relevant for our time.

Please help us bring it to a stage in Philadelphia where we can also have it filmed professionally and distributed worldwide. 

HOW THE MONEY WILL BE USED:

·  Rent for audition space

·  Rent for rehearsal space

·  Rent for performance space

·  Accident insurance for cast and crew, and venues rented

·  Lighting, sound and other technical design

·  Set building materials and construction

·  Set design and props

·  Advertising and marketing

·  Cast and crew salaries

·  Administrative (script copies, office supplies, ticketing, legal and accounting services)

Your help will afford us the opportunity to tell an incredible story about the destruction and persistence of love. Please donate today. Your contribution will be TAX DEDUCTIBLE and greatly appreciated by all involved with the production.  If you are unable to donate funds please SPREAD THE WORD by sending the link to this campaign to your family, friends and colleagues who may be able to contribute.

THANK YOU!!!!

ABOUT THE PLAYWRIGHT, CHERIL N. CLARKE

Cheril N. Clarke is the author of five novels, two plays, numerous short stories and two children’s books. Her first play Intimate Chaos was produced multiple times and was translated to Spanish for a production in Puerto Rico. The Spanish production, Caos Ìntimo, was nominated for Best Play in the 6th annual Festival del Tercer Amor. Clarke’s most recent play Asylum was a featured production of the 2012 Downtown Urban Theatre Festival in New York City where it took home the Audience Award and was runner up for Best Play. As of summer 2014, Clarke has been named the Young Ambassador for the Philadelphia region of the Dramatists Guild of America.

She has been featured on NPR, WPEB 88.1FM Philadelphia, About.com, in Curve Magazine (the nation’s best-selling lesbian magazine), The Princeton Packet, Philadelphia Gay News, Out IN Jersey, Burlington County Times, Philadelphia Business Journal, Phillyburbs.com as well as Crain's New York Business newspaper. Her opinion columns have been featured by the National Black Justice Coalition and her editorial and blog postings have been featured by the Human Rights Campaign. She resides in southern New Jersey with her wife, Monica Bey-Clarke, who is also her business partner for My Family!, a retail and publishing company geared toward LGBT-headed families. Their pioneer title, Keesha and Her Two Moms Go Swimming, was recently noted on Parents.com.

Never Give Up, Always Persevere


*This campaign is one part of a multi-faceted fundraising campaign. If it does not reach its goal the project will still happen. We have contingency plans to pair down in the event we have less funds to work with. If we surpass our goal, we will add more show dates. Our current goal is 6 performances in Center City, Philadelphia.

story:
About the project

Let's Not Beat Each Other To Death has been programmed in the PuSh International Performing Arts Festival in Vancouver. This is an incredible opportunity to share the show with a new audience, and make valuable connections with arts presenters from around the world. 

About the company

We formed The Accidental Mechanics Group in 2011 to create new works that explore and celebrate the nature of performance, persona and queer identity, employing whatever means necessary: storytelling, music, dance, media.

At the centre of any Accidental Mechanics Group event is an intimate act of direct contact between the performer and the audience. 

The team includes creator/performer Stewart Legere, director/dramaturge Christian Barry, producer Karen Gross, production manager Louisa Adamson, projection designer Nicholas Bottomley, and costume designer Leesa Hamilton. 

About the show

Let’s Not Beat Each Other To Death began as a response to the brutal killing of Halifax queer activist Raymond Taavel and an attack against outspoken gay musician, Scott Jones. Inspired by violence and manifested in love, the show’s scope expands outward as a search for explanation, compassion, and catharsis on a larger scale. Let’s Not Beat Each Other To Death asks us to look for the roots of violence within ourselves. Using theatre, music, and a participatory dance party with the audience, the show asks: how do we love better? How can we be better? 

What We Need & What You Get

Artistic fees and accommodation are covered by the PuSh Festival, but we need your help to cover some pre-production costs (rehearsal time/space, some lighting and sound equipment rentals), to help get the team to Vancouver, and to rent a special lighting and sound rig for the performance. 

Tours are expensive. If we happen to surpass our goal, every single dollar of your contribution will still go towards the show and its development. 

We're asking for your help to make this amazing opportunity happen.

We're offering some humble perks as a token of our gratitude, and as an inside look at the work we make.

Impact

This show was developed as a reaction against violence and as an attempt to pay tribute to those who live brave lives in the face of brutality. Before each production of Let’s Not Beat Each Other to Death, the text is updated to reflect the constantly shifting global landscape, as well as to take into consideration local stories that may be able to provide special resonance for a new audience. In each new place, it becomes a vigil with both local and global significance.

Getting to Vancouver (and specifically to PuSh) means sharing the show with a new community as well as opening the door to new relationships between an east coast performance company and national and international presenters. An investment in this show is an investment in queer and Nova Scotian art.  

Other ways you can help
If you'd like to help but aren't able to contribute financially, please share the campaign over social media, email, and in face to face conversation. Word of mouth is invaluable. Tell your friends that you think this project important.

story:
The Chosen Ones: A Short History of the Show.

The idea for The Chosen Ones started with one Evernote note.

Things have grown since then (given one of the notes that, perhaps, there should be a female character involved) and, after many months, five drafts, and a personal vendetta with my school's copy woman after sending a print request for over 2,400 pages in scripts, the end result is a script that it's writer, it's cast, and it's supporters are incredibly proud of.

Here's the rundown.

A Brief Summary:

Taking place in the present day Grendel Arthurian's School for the Chosen, it is young Jedi, Lucas Groundkicker, and young Wizard Henrick Popper's first day at the new school following a shut down of the renowned British School which may or may not have something to do with the facial blemishes of a pig.

It is here where they encounter young wardrobe adventurers, a young demigod, a Hobbit, and there trusted Headmaster: Dobi-Wan Kenobledore.

Things really stir up when the evil Dark Lord Vadermort shows up to the school and kidnaps the Galactic Princess Lily. It falls upon our Young Heroes Lucas and Henrick to safely bring her back to the school. And that's when the real fun begins.

 

We're Theatre People. We're all broke. Why should we donate to you?

A worthwhile question. There are many, many young professionals tied onto this project ready to get it off the ground. This show promises to thrive if it can be achieved with its modest budget. Our donations will go towards props, costumes, and quite possibly a new performance space in late May. Remember; Shrek the Musical on Broadway opened at an estimated $25 million. What's $500 compared to that behemoth?

Besides. We have some swell perks. So who wouldn't want to donate?

story:
A tale emerges of two women unraveling the sacrifices expected of them for migration, survival, and love. Between dreams, nightmares, and islands, they attempt to grasp the ways that hands have touched their bodies. Emerging Black playwright Phanésia Pharel brings her magical play LUCKY to the Conch Shell New Works Reading Series. Inspired by Cuba and the island of Quisqueya, the play challenges audiences as these women come to terms with sexual trauma and discover the power of healing through writing. Simply put: When the black girls dance, God smiles and the world becomes alive.

LUCKY will be presented on Saturday, October 12th, 2019 at A.R.T./NY Studios.

Past, Present, Future

LUCKY was first presented as a developmental workshop at Barnard College in March 2019. The staged reading featured a full creative team and cast of seven, and was produced by the student theatre association NOMADS (New and Original Music Authored and Directed by Students). The five-week workshop process centered on character-building discussions, consent workshops, and strengthening the historical and cultural foundations of the play. The final presentation played to a full house, selling out in less than one day. 

Now we’re pushing the story further with a professional reading at the Conch Shell New Works Reading Series, a company dedicated to developing and producing new works by Caribbean-American writers. We’re looking to use this opportunity to workshop the play and discover what it needs to be the best it can be. We’re excited to explore the rhythm of LUCKY by working with some of the best talents in New York City and presenting it in a space centered around Caribbean voices. We value our artists’ time and will not be asking anyone to work for free. Our anticipated budget is divided into 2/3rds for cast and creative stipends and 1/3rd for other production costs.

LUCKY will have a life past this workshop. It is an important, powerful, and timely story that deserves to be on the stage. As with any great art, it takes time to create and revise and fully realize. Thank you for taking a chance on emerging artists and supporting new work.

The Team

Phanesia Pharel (Playwright) is a playwright, performer, and lyricist. Her work has been performed in Lincoln Nebraska, Miami Florida and Atlanta Georgia and New York City. As a Caribbean American woman-she is interested in how the Black and Latin American diaspora can find the space to address trauma, societal limits and healing through storytelling​.​ Her first monologue "MY KID, MY LIFE" was published in the 2015 City Theatre anthology. Her first play “Penelope” shows a young black woman's journey through the brutality of systemic racism. “Penelope” was selected as one of four in the nation to be workshopped at the International Thespian Festival. It was later published in Dramatics Magazine and with dramatic publisher Samuel French. One of her plays “Shovel Me Away” was produced at Micro Theater Miami, receiving the “Best Of The Best 2016” award. "A ZOO STORY" received honorable mention at the Blank Stage young playwrights festival in Los Angeles. She also has poetry published in various anthologies. She studies and practices Theatre at Barnard College of Columbia University where she recently won the Brandt Playwriting award.

Yvette Ganier (Director) received a 2001 Obie award for her portrayal of Prix in Kia Corthron's play "Breath, Boom" at Playwrights Horizons. Her directing credits include "August in April: A Tribute to August Wilson's Life and Legacy," and most recently the staged reading of "First Black President" by Ofem Ajah at the Rave Theatre Festival. Yvette also served as dramaturg on Shona Tucker's  "Growing Wild" in the #HealMeToo Festival. Yvette is best known for working with August Wilson originating the roles of Rena in "Jitney" and Black Mary in "Gem of the Ocean" and featured as Tonya in "King Hedley II" at The Goodman Theatre. Some of Yvette's acting credits include: Broadway - "The Miracle Worker", "King Hedley II"; London - "Jitney"; Off-Broadway/NY - "The Slow Room", "The Block", "Pitbulls", "Breath, Boom", "Jitney", "For Colored Girls"; Regional credits include: The Goodman and Steppenwolf theaters in Chicago; The Mark Taper Forum in LA; Baltimore CenterStage;The Wilma Theatre; Cleveland Playhouse; Actors Theatre of Louisville. Yvette is currently recurring in "New Amsterdam" on NBC as Nurse Linda Weber. Other awards include The Bowden Award (New Dramatists), LA Ovation Award, NAACP Image Award and the AUDELCO Award.

Maddy Cohen (Producer) is a New York-based producer and stage manager. She is a recent graduate from Barnard College, where she majored in Theatre with a concentration in Production Management, and was ​president of NOMADS, ​a student theater group dedicated to workshopping and producing plays and musicals written by Barnard and Columbia students. ​Producing credits at Columbia include​ Hamlet ​and T​he Fairytale Lives of Russian Girls,​ as well as the 2018-19 NOMADS season, which included ​The Other Side ​by Eden Gordon, ​Imperson All ​by Amanda McDougall, and the workshop of ​Lucky ​by Phanesia Pharel. Professional stage management credits include ​Ghosts and Gaslighting ​(Broadway Bound Theatre Festival), ​Scum: A New Play​ (The Producer’s Club), Ex Habitus​ (Corkscrew Theater Festival), ​Snow White Padded Room​ (Broadway Bound Theatre Festival), and ​A Friend​ (Strawberry One-Act Festival). She has held internships and staff positions at Ars Nova, The New Group, Corkscrew Theater Festival, Ensemble for the Romantic Century, and The New York International Fringe Festival.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about LUCKY by sharing our fundraiser and page on the Conch Shell website.
  • Come to the reading! We would love to see you on October 12th. Space is limited so please contact us directly if you would like to attend.
  • Support our friends by coming to one (or more!) of the other Conch Shell Readings.

We’re looking to use this opportunity to workshop the play and discover what it needs to be the best it can be. We’re excited to explore the rhythm of LUCKY by working with some of the best talents in New York City and presenting it in a space centered around Caribbean voices. We value our artists’ time and will not be asking anyone to work for free. Our anticipated budget is divided into 2/3rds for cast and creative stipends and 1/3rd for other production costs.
LUCKY will have a life past this workshop. It is an important, powerful, and timely story that deserves to be on the stage. As with any great art, it takes time to create and revise and fully realize. Thank you for taking a chance on emerging artists and supporting new work.
The Team
Phanesia Pharel (Playwright) is a playwright, performer, and lyricist. Her work has been performed in Lincoln Nebraska, Miami Florida and Atlanta Georgia and New York City. As a Caribbean American woman-she is interested in how the Black and Latin American diaspora can find the space to address trauma, societal limits and healing through storytelling​.​ Her first monologue "MY KID, MY LIFE" was published in the 2015 City Theatre anthology. Her first play “Penelope” shows a young black woman's journey through the brutality of systemic racism. “Penelope” was selected as one of four in the nation to be workshopped at the International Thespian Festival. It was later published in Dramatics Magazine and with dramatic publisher Samuel French. One of her plays “Shovel Me Away” was produced at Micro Theater Miami, receiving the “Best Of The Best 2016” award. "A ZOO STORY" received honorable mention at the Blank Stage young playwrights festival in Los Angeles. She also has poetry published in various anthologies. She studies and practices Theatre at Barnard College of Columbia University where she recently won the Brandt Playwriting award.
Yvette Ganier (Director) received a 2001 Obie award for her portrayal of Prix in Kia Corthron's play "Breath, Boom" at Playwrights Horizons. Her directing credits include "August in April: A Tribute to August Wilson's Life and Legacy," and most recently the staged reading of "First Black President" by Ofem Ajah at the Rave Theatre Festival. Yvette also served as dramaturg on Shona Tucker's  "Growing Wild" in the #HealMeToo Festival. Yvette is best known for working with August Wilson originating the roles of Rena in "Jitney" and Black Mary in "Gem of the Ocean" and featured as Tonya in "King Hedley II" at The Goodman Theatre. Some of Yvette's acting credits include: Broadway - "The Miracle Worker", "King Hedley II"; London - "Jitney"; Off-Broadway/NY - "The Slow Room", "The Block", "Pitbulls", "Breath, Boom", "Jitney", "For Colored Girls"; Regional credits include: The Goodman and Steppenwolf theaters in Chicago; The Mark Taper Forum in LA; Baltimore CenterStage;The Wilma Theatre; Cleveland Playhouse; Actors Theatre of Louisville. Yvette is currently recurring in "New Amsterdam" on NBC as Nurse Linda Weber. Other awards include The Bowden Award (New Dramatists), LA Ovation Award, NAACP Image Award and the AUDELCO Award.
Maddy Cohen (Producer) is a New York-based producer and stage manager. She is a recent graduate from Barnard College, where she majored in Theatre with a concentration in Production Management, and was ​president of NOMADS, ​a student theater group dedicated to workshopping and producing plays and musicals written by Barnard and Columbia students. ​Producing credits at Columbia include​ Hamlet ​and T​he Fairytale Lives of Russian Girls,​ as well as the 2018-19 NOMADS season, which included ​The Other Side ​by Eden Gordon, ​Imperson All ​by Amanda McDougall, and the workshop of ​Lucky ​by Phanesia Pharel. Professional stage management credits include ​Ghosts and Gaslighting ​(Broadway Bound Theatre Festival), ​Scum: A New Play​ (The Producer’s Club), Ex Habitus​ (Corkscrew Theater Festival), ​Snow White Padded Room​ (Broadway Bound Theatre Festival), and ​A Friend​ (Strawberry One-Act Festival). She has held internships and staff positions at Ars Nova, The New Group, Corkscrew Theater Festival, Ensemble for the Romantic Century, and The New York International Fringe Festival.
Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about LUCKY by sharing our fundraiser and page on the Conch Shell website.
Come to the reading! We would love to see you on October 12th. Space is limited so please contact us directly if you would like to attend.
Support our friends by coming to one (or more!) of the other Conch Shell Readings.

story:
ABOUT US

SeaBus is a small collective of movers that reside in Columbus, Ohio, who share interest in researching, improvising & performing together. Co-Directors, Kelly Hurlburt & Josh Hines, along with the collective, navigate the "dance" between the collision of form (technique & choreography) with improvisation (instincts, and impulse.) SeaBus is fueled by collaboration and it's frame constantly fluctuates as opportunities to work and perform with artists arise both near and far.

Milk & Bones, our newest collaborative evening-length venture, will premiere at The Fisher Theatre on February 16th at 8pm and 17th at 2pm. The show includes real-time composing of dancers in space, along with architectural sculpture and sound scores ,developed by local Columbus artist, Amery Kessler.

HOW TO HELP

We need supporters and backers like you to lift us up and into action! A contribution of any amount is a huge help. By contributing to our project, you are supporting a niche and nurtured form of dance art that is rarely seen in a performance setting, let alone in the midwest. 

A challenge dancers and artists are constantly facing is being underpaid for hours of hard work. There is a common stigma that dancers cannot make a living doing what they love to do. Our company is determined to lead by example and show our community, dancers and non-dancers alike, that it is feasible to make a living as a dance artist in the cities that we call home.

With your help, we can pay our dancers and collaborators fair wages for their hard work and time, rehearsal rental, performance venue rental, marketing materials, costumes, and future productions and projects.  

With your generous help and support, our goals can be achieved!

THE IMPACT

Dance improvisation, when used as a means of performance, creates surprising and daring compositions in real-time. We listen, support, and grow by sharing space with one another. Being an improvisational dance company means that we have the opportunity to be vulnerable, sensitive, and trusting in order to create arresting, yet ephemeral compositions in the moment. This is the draw of dance improvisation; this is the reason we want to share it with all of you!

We intend to demonstrate how dance improvisation is a valuable and enriching medium, while also bringing contemporary dance to the forefront of an already rich visual and musical arts community in Columbus. The performers will come together for a week long rehearsal intensive that culminates in a weekend of performances at Columbus Dance Theatre's resident space, The Fischer Theatre.  This project will not only make contemporary dance accessible throughout the greater Columbus community, but it will also provide educational opportunities through community events, including workshops, open rehearsals, and “talk-backs” after each performance

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Starting a dance company is no easy task, when we can find the time in our busy everyday work lives and gather in one location and create a cohesive work, the process can be quite demanding. At the end of the day, we are all improvising, which means anything can and does happen. However, attuning to ten other people in a space and being able to come to an understanding is the reason why we dance in the first place. There is something so special about having an unspoken, mind-reading, "aha" moment with ten other people. And then that moment is gone.

With your generous help and support, our goals can be achieved!

PLEASE SHARE

Some other ways you can help support our project is to share! Please feel free to share this campaign, our social media handles, and our name. We feel passionately about our community, and sharing is a HUGE way to bring more like-minded artists together! @sea_busdancecompany

story:
Please consider making a tax-deductible gift to support this world premier production of OLIVES AND BLOOD by Michael Bradford. We have already raised over $15,000 to put towards this production. This last small amount will help pay for a musician to join us on stage and the really exciting design elements. Plus we have exciting PERKS (listed right here) for those who decide to make a donation!

OLIVES AND BLOOD

By Michael Bradford, Directed by May Adrales

June 9th - 24th

It is said in Spain that the dead are always more alive than the day they were born. So it is for the presumed murderer of Federico Garcia Lorca, Juan Luis Trescante Medina. Sixty years after Lorca's death, the aging fascist, Trescante, fights to hold onto the myth of a murder that defined his life. But in Spain, sixty years is little more than a breath, and a reckoning is all but inevitable.

Being presented at HERE as part of the prestigious HEREstay program.

From the Playwright...

I fell in love with Lorca's poetry and plays, his voice and his elegiac conversation about "duende," which can be loosely translated as having soul, expression and authenticity. I was also intrigued about his murder in 1936 and the myriad of conversations about Lorca’s works that are still so prescient in the contemporary moral and political conversation in Spain.
 
The play speaks to issues all along the spectrum of humanity; arrogance, fear, self-delusion, dignity, love and redemption. The play takes the time to look at a human being at a specific moment in time, from every angle, and lets each audience member take away what speaks to him or her.

About the Playwright...

"Michael Bradford is one of those rare playwrights who captures the depth, power, and soul of his characters. His work is both theatrical and poetic; it is poignant and relevant. When I experience a Michael Bradford play, I am stepping into a world that is full of life and longing."  --- Daniella Topol, Past Artistic Programming Director of the Lark Play Development Center

story:
Our Story

Gog is produced by North Shore natives Jason Lindner (Yale MFA Playwright) and 

Brant Russell (Northwestern MFA Director) and stars Steep Theater ensemble member 

Michael Salinas. The darkly comic tale is a twisted glimpse into how an underbelly 

artist conjures energies beyond his control. Equal parts indictment, satire, and 

cautionary tale, The Gog/Magog Project  is an absurdist nightmare in a cage.  


The Impact

This bold and daring project is based on the mysterious demise of performance 

artist Alexander Gog, an event still shrouded in rumor and supposition, and which, 

due to ongoing legal considerations, must be presented in this fictionalized manner. 

When Gog began his askew project â€“ to lock himself in a theatre for a year and 

perform ever night at eight, Sunday matinees at two â€“ he had no way to know what 

had been set in motion. Fifteen years of confinement later, scant remaining notes of 

the project reveal disturbing images of torture by Banana Moon Pie, exploitation by 

â€œBig Pharma,â€ and involvement from security agencies of a secret derivation. 

Ragged pages, many hastily burnt or hopelessly redacted, can only hint at the 

hundreds of humiliations piled on an unsuspecting victim in the name of the 

hungry, unseen, force that bid Gog to continue his performances, unceasingly, every 

night at eight, Sunday matinee at two.   


What We Need & What You Get

Gog needs $1500.

$300 for rehearsal space.

$500 for set materials.

$100 to clothe Gog.

$100 for lights for Gog to see and for you to see Gog.

$400 for marketing and publicity.

$100 to feed Gog during tech.


Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about Gog on Facebook and in life.

story:
TERRA FIRMA DANCE THEATRE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT!

Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT) invites your support, in providing a solid foundation for our upcoming Spring 2013 Season, and beyond. In seeking the amount of $3000, we will be empowered to fulfill our mission objectives to provide affordable and accessible dance of high-artistic merit.

Please take a moment to read on, and help us to meet (or exceed) our goal!

Your fiscal support will enable us provide no-cost to low-cost tickets to underserved audiences to our upcoming performances; remunerate world-class dancers and choreographers that are featured in our season; deepen, broaden and diversify our community outreach efforts and expand our arts-education programs. ANY AMOUNT OF SUPPORT HELPS! Kindly consider supporting Terra Firma Dance Theatre, and know that your contribution assists in ensuring arts-accessibility and programming that is of the highest caliber.  All contributions are tax-deductible, and we extend the utmost gratitude.

Please take a peek at our video, above, showcasing the rehearsal process of preparing for the April 26th 2013 premiere of Stuart Loungway's "Stagioni".

Read on, to learn more about our upcoming performance activities, and about some of the neat perks that you receive in providing support, including private lesson in dance or pilates; exclusive social gatherings; and recognition of your support of our organization.

A Solid Foundation....

On April 22nd, 2013, TFDT Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway will conduct a week-long series of master classes at the Middlesex County Performing Arts Conservatory. Mr. Loungway is donating his time and teaching, in providing instruction to the professional dance aspirants that comprise the student body of the dance department, within the school.

At the end of the week, On April 26th, 2013, TFDT will provide a culminating performance for the students of the conservatory, as well as the general public.

Showcasing high-octane physicality with an ardent flair, this evening-length re-emergence of Stuart Loungway’s Terra Firma Dance Theater employs classical and contemporary vocabulary as a springboard for international dance innovation. Broad in its range, this evening will tender the world premiere of “Stagioni,” literal translation to “Seasons” in an original and evocative deconstruction of Vivaldi’s masterpiece, “Four Seasons.” Featuring Lauren King, soloist of New York City Ballet, and nine other rising artists, Loungway creates an eclectic account of a new universe painted with texture, intricacy and the recent compositional reworking of composer Max Richter. "Stagioni", also features original costumes, created by TFDT dancer, Gabby Grywalski.

The program will also feature a previously performed duet, by Mr. Loungway, entitled Chamber, set to the music of Marin Marais.  A choreographic love poem, this work resulted in Mr. Loungway receiving the Individual Choreographic Fellowship from the New Jersey State Council for the Arts, a branch of the National Endowment of the Arts. Here, Loungway’s aesthetic explodes, twists and deconstructs the parameters of the physical and spatial possibilities of movement and perception.

 
Joined on the bill by Loungway, guest choreographer and artist Loni Landon will bring her dynamic solo piece, Welcome The Sting danced by Lavinia Vago  with music by  Richard Skelton and Hildur Guadnottir .Investigating themes of loss and recovery, this solo was created as a response to Hurricane Sandy in New York, and focuses on the emotional and physical collapse associated with loss Ms. Landon is a fresh-voice in the world of contemporary dance and joins Terra Firma Dance Theater off the heels of her recent Joyce performance, to critical acclaim. Additionally, the program is rounded out by a duet , titled "Shifting Shadow," choreographed by Manuel Vignoulle. Inspired by a picture of a man scared by his own refection and shadow, this piece explores the truth behind the illusion of the self and its multi dimensional shadows that projects both on the self and others. This piece will be danced by Isaies Santamaria Perez & Manuel Vignoulle.
 

A little more about us!

 Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT), under the guidance of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway, serves as a cultural think-tank for the dance landscape of New York. We promote an environment that cultivates dialogue and the exchange of creative ideas as exemplified through our dance performance, educational outreach and experimental theater initiatives. Our primary focal points are underserved populations and non-traditional theatergoers,in order to introduce them to the power of the arts as a life changing force. As a rapidly rising contemporary ballet company, the core of our work focuses on movement as the primary language of basic human interaction and communion.

In promoting a risk-free environment of diversity, TFDT emphasizes the value of dance as a medium to enrich, empower and engage all members of the community via its high-quality, accessible and affordable programming.

As vanguard caretakers of the art form of ballet, we actively seek to promote new audiences and heighten their awareness and willingness to move away from “traditional and typical dance models”. With a responsible eye to the future of ballet, we work to provide a progressive and contemporary experience, with the understanding that ballet will not look as it once has.

The interwoven philosophical, societal and political issues of the 18th and 19th centuries, that once informed and governed the creation and understanding of new dance work and art in general, no longer exist. It is with this notion in mind that we embark upon our mission to present a new and viable model that preserves ballet as a current and relevant art form, which carries the potential to provide a deep and long lasting impact upon its audience members
 
Terra Firma Dance Theater is comprised of 10 high caliber dancers: Guest artist, Lauren King (Soloist,New York City Ballet), Izabela Szylinska (formerly of Polish National Ballet), Erin Arbuckle (Soloist, Ballet Next), Lester Badenoch (former dancer w/ Atlanta Ballet, American Repertory Ballet, North Carolina Dance Theatre), Tiffany Mangulabnan(current soloist, Ballet Next; former Principal- Philippine Ballet Theatre) Rebecca Walden (NYC free lance dancer), Gabby Grywalski (Pittsburgh Ballet); Erika Carpenter (Kravenko Dance Academy); Lukasz Zieba (freelance dancer, Poland, Ailey School professional-track aspirant) and recent SUNY Purchase graduate, Jessica Miller. 
 
Stuart Loungway is the Founder/Artistic Director of Terra Firma Dance Theatre. His training began with Tania Lichine, Irina Jacobson, and John Clifford before receiving a full scholarship to the prestigious School of American Ballet. He began his professional career performing with the Houston Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, before joining San Francisco Ballet Company and continuing as a Principal Dancer with American Repertory Ballet. He has performed soloist and principal roles in work by David Bintley, James Kudelka, George Balanchine, William Forsythe, Mark Morris, and many others. Mr. Loungway maintains an active schedule as a master teacher, choreographer, performer, and served on the dance faculty at Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University. Selected as “Who’s Hot” by National Dance Critics Association Chair Karyn Collins, Mr. Loungway’s choreography, as expressed by Robert Johnson of Dance Europe, is “elegant and evocative” and “bodes well for the future of dance.” His work and company have been featured in the national dance publication Pointe Magazine.

His work has been featured at Ballet Builders/New Choreographers on Pointe. He is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company teacher for Ballet Hispanico.

The interwoven philosophical, societal and political issues of the 18th and 19th centuries, that once informed and governed the creation and understanding of new dance work and art in general, no longer exist. It is with this notion in mind that we embark upon our mission to present a new and viable model that preserves ballet as a current and relevant art form, which carries the potential to provide a deep and long lasting impact upon its audience members
 
Terra Firma Dance Theater is comprised of 10 high caliber dancers: Guest artist, Lauren King (Soloist,New York City Ballet), Izabela Szylinska (formerly of Polish National Ballet), Erin Arbuckle (Soloist, Ballet Next), Lester Badenoch (former dancer w/ Atlanta Ballet, American Repertory Ballet, North Carolina Dance Theatre), Tiffany Mangulabnan(current soloist, Ballet Next; former Principal- Philippine Ballet Theatre) Rebecca Walden (NYC free lance dancer), Gabby Grywalski (Pittsburgh Ballet); Erika Carpenter (Kravenko Dance Academy); Lukasz Zieba (freelance dancer, Poland, Ailey School professional-track aspirant) and recent SUNY Purchase graduate, Jessica Miller. 
 

Stuart Loungway is the Founder/Artistic Director of Terra Firma Dance Theatre. His training began with Tania Lichine, Irina Jacobson, and John Clifford before receiving a full scholarship to the prestigious School of American Ballet. He began his professional career performing with the Houston Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, before joining San Francisco Ballet Company and continuing as a Principal Dancer with American Repertory Ballet. He has performed soloist and principal roles in work by David Bintley, James Kudelka, George Balanchine, William Forsythe, Mark Morris, and many others. Mr. Loungway maintains an active schedule as a master teacher, choreographer, performer, and served on the dance faculty at Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University. Selected as “Who’s Hot” by National Dance Critics Association Chair Karyn Collins, Mr. Loungway’s choreography, as expressed by Robert Johnson of Dance Europe, is “elegant and evocative” and “bodes well for the future of dance.” His work and company have been featured in the national dance publication Pointe Magazine.

  His work has been featured at Ballet Builders/New Choreographers on Pointe. He is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company teacher for Ballet Hispanico.

story:
OVERVIEW:

In November 2012, I accomplished what I had not imagined I would for a long time: I produced and directed an evening of my own tap choreography, “TRANSITIONS,” in Lexington and Marblehead, Massachusetts. The show received great press in local media, two of the three shows were sold out, and audience feedback was enthusiastic and encouraging. (“I want to see it again ASAP,” one person wrote, “although I can understand that your school work might be more important.”)

Since those inaugural performances, I have given much consideration to ways in which I could improve and embellish the show to make it as entertaining and seamless as possible. It is my intention to restage the show for new audiences at different venues, primarily in the Northeast, in 2013 – and with YOUR help, I’m confident I can make this happen!

ABOUT THE SHOW:

“TRANSITIONS” is an original production of rhythm tap dance integrated with poetry, cinematography, Vaudeville, and hip hop dance, boasting a soundtrack ranging from Dinah Washington and Tower of Power to Harry Connick, Jr. and Shel Silverstein.

At turns thoughtful, satirical and humorous, “TRANSITIONS” features routines inspired by periods of change and personal development in my life. While “The Tall & Short of It” portrays the struggles and successes of my towering, 6’8” talent, “My Manhattan” lampoons my culture shock as a pilgrim to New York City. And my former teacher, Kelly Kaleta, original cast member of Imagine Tap!, becomes my partner in a series of playful duets entitled “Just the Two of Us."

Excerpts from the show have been previously presented at such venues as the Massachusetts Dance Festival, Dance for Life Boston, and Monkeyhouse Dance’s “Against the Odds” Festival, with upcoming appearances at the Boston Center for the Arts and The Steve Katsos Show 4th Anniversary
Spectacular.

As a young artist, I believe in dance/art that is rhythmic, engaging and accessible and that utilizes the entire body as a rhythm-making machine. Accordingly, I believe that “TRANSITIONS,” as an interdisciplinary rhythm tap show that mixes comedy and introspection with an underlying narrative current, succeeds at relating to and entertaining its audiences.

Most of all, I love performing, especially with my best friends, and fulfilling the motto of my hometown youth dance company: “Share the joy of dance with others.”

TOUR SCHEDULE:

June 1: The Dance Hall – Kittery, ME
June 14: The Regent Theatre – Arlington, MA
July 6: Marjorie S. Deane Little Theatre – New York, NY
TBA: inkub8 – Miami, FL

ABOUT THE DIRECTOR & CHOREOGRAPHER:

I am the recipient of a YoungArts award from the National YoungArts Foundation and am currently an undergraduate student at New York University’s Gallatin School of Individualized Study. Inspired by Savion Glover’s appearances on Sesame Street, I began studying tap and jazz at the age of five at The Dance Inn in Lexington, Massachusetts. I spent seven seasons under the tutelage of Thelma Goldberg and Kelly Kaleta with the Legacy Dance Company, where I am now on faculty, and also served as Dance Captain of the New England Tap Ensemble, directed by Aaron Tolson. In addition to a burgeoning solo career, I am a founding member of Michelle Dorrance’s company, Dorrance Dance/New York. You may have seen me on So You Think You Can Dance or read one of my articles for Dance Spirit, Dance Teacher or Dance Studio Life. In 2011, I was a guest choreographer for Boston’s Urbanity Dance. I am also a proud alumnus of the inaugural tap program at The School at Jacob’s Pillow. www.ryanpcasey.com

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:

Although I successfully produced the original production by myself with help from family and friends, as a college student and incumbent college graduate my resources are limited. Your generous donation will help offset costs of:

-- Venue rental & technical crew fees
-- Cast transportation & lodging
-- Cost of printing programs & posters
-- Performer stipends

I am also a sponsored artist with The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for Ryan P. Casey are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 161 Sixth Avenue, 14th Floor, New York NY 10013, (212) 691-6969, fax: (212) 255-2053, www.thefield.org. A copy of The Field’s latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

Visit: https://www.thefield.org/Profile.aspx?SAID=2884


SPREAD THE WORD:

Whether you can donate or not, please consider sharing this link on your social media pages, like Facebook and Twitter, or forwarding it to friends and family via email! Any and all support is greatly appreciated by the entire cast. My dance teacher always enforced the idea that dance belongs out there in the community. Let’s make this happen!

story:
"Landfall"

Hello, we are Unsolicited Artists Theatre Troupe and we are committed to bring theatre to people whether or not they ask for it. Our show "Landfall" has been invited to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this year and we are asking for support. As we are comprised mostly of young theatre artists, we are relying on community support.

Our biggest need for funding is for travel. We are from Memphis, TN and we need to get all the way across the ocean to Edinburgh.

This show started as a project at University of Memphis and is written by an alumni of the department, Spencer Glenn Miller. As, we have said before our young cast is hoping for a wonderful once in a lifetime experience and you can be a part of that. We are looking to grow, learn, and bring back to our community new theatre as well as a stronger theatre troupe.

If you are unable to help we understand but we ask please that you spred the word about our cause.

 

The Show:

Landfall 

A modern faerie-tale about how a young star is tricked out of the sky and how one little star can change a family's life forever.

Our Wonderful Cast:

Landfall Cast
Mary : Morgan Baltz 
North : Lexi Jenne
Paul : Matt Schmidt 
Joanne : Ellen Saba
Dark Man : Steven Cox
Push : Kristen Surratt
Pull : Katelyn Hendricks Miller
Press : Miranda Fisher

 

Everyone needs a little Theatre in their lives so help us bring a little theatre to the rest of the world.

story:
The Importance of Running in My Life

   My name is Michelle Landry, I am 27 years old, and have been running ever since I could walk.  Growing up I was always playing with the neighborhood kids, out running the boys, and lucky enough to be involved in organized sports (soccer, basketball).  In high school I went on to finding my niche in running hurdles and competing in high jump, long jump, and triple jump on the track team.

     However, there were many obstacles to over come such as multiple sports injuries such as Patella Femoral Syndrome-which I had to see a physical therapist for, shin splints, and other muscle strains/ scrapes and bruises.  Having supportive friends, family members, teachers, and coaches, helped me to increase my self confidence as an awkward and lanky 5'8", 105 lb teenager. They also helped me push myself to qualify for and compete in state meets and receive multiple sports honors such MVP.  With my new found confidence I was able to find a defined career path and future helping others, as a physical therapist, just as I had been helped.

    But I am one of the lucky ones who had a supportive community and network of role models to guide me in the right direction, of whichever life path I chose.  There are many girls who are not so lucky.

    So I hope that by running my first full marathon (26.2 miles!!!) in Chicago this October, I can give back, in the hopes that girls like myself, will grow up to be strong individuals who will enrich their community. As the money I raise will create valuable scholarship funds for girls who can't afford to be part of this amazing organization.   

 

The Charity!!

I see Girls On The Run as an active 'Girl Scout' Group who try to inspire girls to be healthy and confident. They manage fun, after-school programs involving running, and training for a team based 5k event.

"Over the past 13 years, Girls on the Run-Chicago has served more than 27,000 girls aged 8-14 across 6 Chicagoland counties. In 2013, more than 1,000 coaches will mentor 8,000 girls - empowering them with the confidence and character they need to become strong, healthy women."

story:
GO TO BREL!

Greetings!  It is with great excitement that I announce my upcoming show “GO TO BREL!" Musical Director: Peter Kiesewalter, which is devoted to the work of legendary Belgian songwriter and performer, Jacques Brel, to be performed September 20th, 22nd, 25th as a part of The Phoenix Theatre Ensemble's upcoming fall repertory season at The Paradise Factory Theatre, 64 East 4th Street, NYC (http://www.phoenixtheatreensemble.org/go-to-brel/)

While all of my solo cabaret shows in the past have included songs by BREL, It has been an ongoing desire to perform a show comprised solely of the works of this iconic artist. Now, fifteen years after the commencement of my cabaret career, I have been afforded the opportunity! The Phoenix Theatre Ensemble, has very generously reached out to me with an offer of producing “GO TO BREL!” this fall, which for me is surely a tremendous gift. There are however, some costs for which I will be solely responsible, including all fees incurred by rehearsing and performing with my brilliant Musical Director and accompanist, Peter Kiesewalter (a musical genius, and an extraordinary human being!) Costume, props, and equipment rental, will also be my own personal financial responsibility. Sooooooooo... with that being said... any contribution will be greatly appreciated and help in making this show the very best that it can possibly be, and to let live again the magnificent masterpieces of legendary JACQUES BREL! Merci! Merci! Merci! Xo 

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0lwgcAZEPhg

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y-QMyhoi2p8

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YzeOp90j_Rk

story:
Go into the arts. I’m not kidding. The arts are not a way to make a living. They are a very human way of making life more bearable. Practicing an art, no matter how well or badly, is a way to make your soul grow, for heaven’s sake. Sing in the shower. Dance to the radio. Tell stories. Write a poem to a friend, even a lousy poem. Do it as well as you possibly can. You will get an enormous reward. You will have created something.

= KURT VONNEGUT

OUR MISSION is to do what Kurt Vonnegut said: practice our art and make our souls grow.

We are a group of family and friends who remember how much fun we’ve had through the years doing plays. In fact, many of us became friends – and family – doing theater. Though most of us have jobs and responsibilities that fill up our lives, we still find ourselves thinking:  “You know, it’s time for me to get back on the stage.”  Or:  “It’s about time I heard that piece performed.”  But when, or how?  Well, collectively, we’ve decided that we don’t need to wait for an invitation to pursue our dreams. With your help, we can provide an opportunity for ourselves.

And in making theater now, we celebrate a new wave of participatory life. We strike a blow against virtual experience.  We come together to have fun and give wing to the dormant spirits inside us.  Perhaps the same is true for you?

Our festival consists of 8 short pieces. They are each original in every sense of the word.  They are also varied in style and genre, their multiplicity reflecting the differences in our life experiences, which you can see in our bios below. But they all have one thing in common:  each will have been carefully nurtured and produced by talented and dedicated people.


WHAT WE NEED

To make F-Fest possible, we need a dozen actors, at least three directors, and two stage managers.  We need to build a set, find props, design lights, and create a sound design that suits 8 pieces.  And of course, we need to rent a theater.

Our goal for all this was $5,000.


WHAT YOU GAVE

You gave more than we asked, which is the height of generosity.  Though all who gave are listed under the Funders tab above, we believe you deserve to be publicly lauded here and now.

A titanic thank you, then, to Rob Mason, David Goodman, Ava Seave, Miriam King, webernyc, jhharding, rcrispinojr, Marsha Norman, winter1, Constance Kehoe, Lisa & Devon, Benita Koman, ANGUS25, albeaumont, scotts7, Laurie Klatshcer, jbwahl, rogervmeier, David Arrow, fonnefong, Deborah G Winer, Virginia Wilhelm, Mary J Mason, Lisa Master, perdev, lisalock, hollykshaw, Gene Santarelli, araj28, LoraMyers, Beth Blatt, elizabeth mead, boisakreproductions, M Tattenbaum, Douglas Cohen, Susan Karwoska, Greg Alexander, phisugi, artiehz4, caroldo1, and six Anonymous donors [you know who you are].

Now everyone come and see the show!


WE ARE

ROBERT BOATRIDE

Robert, with worlds of sin to feast on, has chosen the side of the mundane. F-Fest offers him the chance to divert his attentions from impractical obsession onto a socially acceptable course.

TOM COASH

Tom is a playwright, director, producer, and professor.  His new play VEILS, which won both the Clauder Competition and the Edgerton Foundation National New Play Award, just received its Equity Premiere at Portland Stage (Maine).

LORI GOODMAN

Lori’s full-length play Touch was accepted to the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. With Lora Myers she co-wrote Wordplay: Fun Games for Building Reading and Writing Skills in Children with Learning Differences.

ISAAC GOODMAN-BOYD

Isaac’s play The Man That Rules Us All won the Young Playwrights Foundation 2006 Write a Play NYC competition. He also writes novels and short stories and graduates in May from Clark University.

CLIFFORD LEE JOHNSON III

CLJ3 is the Swiss Army Knife of theatrical consultants. For more information, go to <clj3@clj3.com>.

SOFIA JOHNSON

Sofia’s play 22 Stories appeared in the 2011 New York International Fringe Festival. A student at the University of Chicago, she is an original cast member of Attori Senza Paura, UChicago's first Commedia Dell'Arte troupe. 

JANE KELLEY

Jane is the author of the middle grade novels The Desperate Adventures of Zeno and Alya, The Girl Behind the Glass, and Nature Girl. She is delighted to return to the theater, where her creative life began.

ALICE KING

After apprenticing at Actors Theater Of Louisville, Alice moved to NYC where she studied with Uta Hagen and became a member of Circle Repertory Company. Since 2007, she has been the CEO of Alice King Books.

EMILY KING

Emily enjoyed a theatrical career in the US and Britain as an actor, singer, director, and playwright. As a NYC Officiant, she has married hundreds of couples. Emily recently published A Kind of Magic, a novel for middle graders.

ELISE MORRIS

Elise has created underscores and song cycles for numerous theatrical productions, including, Opa! (co-written with composer Nick Carras), and has performed with such artists as Joe Jackson; Cy Coleman; and Peter, Paul and Mary.

MELANIE SUTHERLAND

Melanie’s wide-ranging directing credits include 7 Sins in 60 Minutes (conceiver/director, HERE Summer Sublet Series, Philly Fringe); river: post-futurist (Paula Cizmar, Cherry Lane); Fargo (David Morse, Circle Rep); and A Pirate’s Lullaby (Jessica Litwak, Rattlestick).

KEITH WEBER

Keith has been a pro caddie on the PGA Tour and a professional photographer. As an actor he studied at HB Studios and with Joe Gilford (where he met his wife Alice). At present, he runs KWeber Construction.


WHERE & WHEN

The 78th Street Theatre Lab

236 W. 78th Street

Tuesday, March 11 @ 8:00 p.m.

Tuesday, March 18 @ 8:00 p.m.

Tickets $18

For reservations call (718) 768-7403 or email: cljak@nyc.rr.com.
