Douglas Cohen, Susan Karwoska, Greg Alexander, phisugi, artiehz4, caroldo1, and
six Anonymous donors
 [you know who you are].
Now everyone come and see the show!
WE ARE
ROBERT BOATRIDE
Robert, with worlds of sin
to feast on, has chosen the side of the mundane. F-Fest offers him the chance
to divert his attentions from impractical obsession onto a socially acceptable
course.
TOM COASH
Tom is a playwright,
director, producer, and professor. 
His new play VEILS, which won both the Clauder Competition and the
Edgerton Foundation National New Play Award, just received its Equity Premiere at
Portland Stage (Maine).
LORI GOODMAN
Lori’s full-length play Touch was accepted to the 2012 New York International
Fringe Festival. With Lora Myers she co-wrote Wordplay: Fun Games for Building Reading and Writing Skills in
Children with Learning Differences.
ISAAC GOODMAN-BOYD
Isaac’s play The Man That Rules Us All won the Young
Playwrights Foundation 2006 Write a Play NYC competition. He also writes novels
and short stories and graduates in May from Clark University.
CLIFFORD LEE JOHNSON III
CLJ3 is the Swiss Army Knife
of theatrical consultants. For more information, go to <clj3@clj3.com>.
SOFIA JOHNSON
Sofia’s play 22 Stories appeared in the 2011 New York
International Fringe Festival. A student at the University of Chicago, she is
an original cast member of Attori Senza Paura, UChicago's first Commedia
Dell'Arte troupe. 
JANE KELLEY
Jane
is the author of the middle grade novels The
Desperate Adventures of Zeno and Alya, The
Girl Behind the Glass, and Nature
Girl. She is delighted to return to the theater, where her creative life
began.
ALICE KING
After
apprenticing at Actors Theater Of Louisville, Alice moved to NYC where she studied
with Uta Hagen and became a member of Circle Repertory Company. Since 2007, she
has been the CEO of Alice King Books.EMILY KING
Emily enjoyed a theatrical career in
the US and Britain as an actor, singer, director, and playwright. As a NYC
Officiant, she has married hundreds of couples. Emily recently published A Kind of Magic, a novel for middle
graders.
ELISE MORRIS
Elise has created
underscores and song cycles for numerous theatrical productions, including, Opa! (co-written with composer Nick
Carras), and has performed with such artists as Joe Jackson; Cy Coleman; and
Peter, Paul and Mary.
MELANIE SUTHERLAND
Melanie’s
wide-ranging directing credits include 7 Sins in 60 Minutes
(conceiver/director, HERE Summer Sublet Series, Philly Fringe); river: post-futurist (Paula Cizmar,
Cherry Lane); Fargo (David Morse,
Circle Rep); and A Pirate’s Lullaby (Jessica
Litwak, Rattlestick).
KEITH WEBER
Keith
has been a pro caddie on the PGA Tour and a professional photographer. As an
actor he studied at HB Studios and with Joe Gilford (where he met his wife
Alice). At present, he runs KWeber Construction.WHERE & WHEN
The 78th Street Theatre Lab236 W. 78th Street
Tuesday, March 11 @ 8:00 p.m.
Tuesday, March 18 @ 8:00 p.m.
Tickets $18
For reservations call (718)
768-7403 or email: cljak@nyc.rr.com.

story:
WHY WE ARE

Etta's Eyes Only was born from a mind-meld of ecstatic-high-school-aged-stary-eyed-naive-optimists, trying to prove that the world is an optimistic-naive-stary-eyed-ecstatic-high-schooler, itching to break traditions- and create them. We do what we do with what we have because we can. We are a haven, an exploration and a release, an artistic fix.

WHO WE ARE

We are made up of a ten member ensemble, all between the ages of 14 and 21. We have a technical crew of 15, also between the ages of 14 and 21, and we have a non-traditional quartet, still between the ages of 14 and 21.

Although Etta's Eyes Only (EEO) has grown from a figment of imagination into a fully functioning company- complete with actors, a director, a playwright, a costume department, a props department, a set, a master electrician, a publicity department, and a home venue- we're still naive, optimistic high-schoolers and college kids. And it's worked out pretty well for us so far. 

OUR MISSION

The mission of Etta’s Eyes Only-Youth Theatre Company is to maintain an entirely youth-ran platform, thereby eliminating the confines of a school, or "supervisor" based program, and allowing aspiring theatre artists to explore and experiment with their art in whichever way they see fit. The company strives to present brave, important, artistic, and thought provoking theatre- proving that the youth is a truly important part of the artistic community.

OUR PRODUCTION

On August 1st, 2nd and 3rd at 7pm, we will be performing a home-grown version of Charles Mee's BIG LOVE at The State Theatre in down town South Bend. We have uniquely shaped the show to fit our ensemble, which creates a truly artistic piece of stage-craft. Charles Mee gives the following explanation of the show--

Fifty brides flee their fifty grooms and seek refuge in a villa on the coast of Italy in this modern re-making of one of the western world's oldest plays, The Danaids by Aeschylus. And, in this villa on the Italian coast, the fifty grooms catch up with the brides, and mayhem ensues: the grooms arriving by helicopter in their flight suits, women throwing themselves over and over again to the ground, pop songs and romantic dances, and, finally, unable to escape their forced marriages, 49 of the brides murder 49 of the grooms-and one bride falls in love. About the same odds as today.

The show was chosen because of its importance to the theatre community, it's creative opportunities, and its brave subject matter- which the members of EEO would not be able to experience in their high school funded theatre programs. 

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

EEO is rich in all aspects but fiscally. And as such, we are desperately in need of funding to pay for things like: props, costumes, paint, lighting equipment, programs, posters, publicity, and other items which will help the production to have the largest impact it can on the local theatre world.

story:
Hello There,

Good Day Ladies and Gentlemen, and welcome to the indiegogo campaign page for Fishes, a play by David Fennelly which will be returning to the stage this year with your help. This play has already enjoyed a successful run in the Collaborations Festival in Dublin. But we would like your help to make it even bigger and better this time round.

As you can see we are asking for a total of €1,500 but every little helps, this money will be used to fund the production costs of the play, such as the lighting, materials for the set, costumes, and rental of a rehearsal space, so that we can make sure the final performance is as perfect as we believe it can be. So help us get this production off the ground, and not only can we promise you an interesting, insightful, darkly comic, and, let's face it, just downright kick ass, play at the end of it all (the 3rd to 11th of December in Smock Alley Boys’ School in Dublin to be exact) but we can also offer you some interesting perks for helping us out!! For more details read on.

Give us your money!! We’ll make it worth your while:

Now we certainly don’t expect you to just hand us your hard earned Spondooligs without at least attempting to give you some form of reason to want to give them to us. So, bear with me for the briefest of moments and I shall break down some of what you get for being the hero we all know you are and forking over the cold hard digital donations, and so you know we’re not just asking you for money for the sake of asking I’ll give you some details of where this money is going to go;

  • Rehearsal Space: much as we love holding rehearsals in bedrooms, and living rooms. We would like to have the space for our actors to properly spread their arms, legs and other movement related appendages without slapping each other in the face, in order to make this play the absolute best that it can be. One of the first things we will be using your warm-hearted and incredibly kind donations for is the rental of a rehearsal space

  • Lighting: We do not want to have to perform in the dark, as interesting as that would be, this play calls for very specific lighting, and we’d like to know that when the curtain goes up, you will be able to see our actors’ faces. Believe me, they are a sight not to be missed. Your kind donations will go a long way in shedding light on this fact, so please help (if you smiled at that pun make sure your friends, family, pets and other interested parties don't miss out on the fun by sharing this page on your social media site of choice)

  • Set Design: Remember how I said we needed lights so that you could see our actors’ faces? You should, I literally just said it, we also need a set for them to act on, there would be nothing worse than having our actors have to mime opening and closing doors, and pretend to sit on chairs that aren’t really there. I don’t want to have to tell them they can’t have seats on the stage, or walls, so please, please help us give them the set they deserve, all of this will just make the already awesome play even more awesome.

We here at Fishes HQ feel that you deserve some return on your investment, and besides our everlasting, and undying gratitude this is what donating could earn you:

  • €5 – A donation of this amount will earn you, not only a special space in the hearts of everyone involved but also a thank you on the Fishes Facebook page

  • €10 – everything you see above with the added bonus of being personally thanked in the Fishes programme. Plus the space you earn in our hearts will come with its very own en-suite

  • €15 – This incredibly generous donation will earn you; everything included in the above rewards, with the heart-space now coming with a wide-screen plasma-screen T.V. (UPC will cost extra though) plus a poster

  • €20 – The space you earn in the hearts of the team will now come with UPC to go with your wide-screen T.V. and en-suite (you could even put the T.V in the figurative, metaphorical bathroom) you will also receive everything listed above, and entry into a draw for a ticket to the preview night of Fishes

  • €50 – Hey big spender, if you are unbelievably awesome enough to have given us a donation of this size, we will love you forever, with a love that burns with the force of a thousand suns. Your heart space now also comes with a personal live in maid (you'll never have to lift a finger again, (figuratively speaking of course)) Alongside this, we will also give you the thank you, the Personal mention in the programe, the poster, and, guarantee you a ticket to the Opening night of Fishes

But what if I can’t give you my money??

Shame on you! Why would you think that we would dislike you for not being able to help us out. It’s a hard thing to have to deal with, if you can’t help us out right now there are of course other ways you can help out. Just follow these easy steps.

  1. Procure laptop/other internet worthy vessel: “But I’ve already got me hands on a wonderfully capable internet-faring vessel laddy!! Avast and watch me surfing the high interwebby seas” I hear you scream in your best impersonation of Captain Jack Sparrow. “Good” I reply in my digital typing, in that case, get on your social media website of choice and start spreading the word about how awesome we are.

  2. The above step is pretty much the only step, but Indiegogo does have some fairly easy to use share tools so that the word is even easier to spread!! So get spreading.

Now, unlike the donations, we can’t offer you any physical reward for this. However, I can say that if you’re creative in how you share this (No vandalism though please) you might earn yourself a like/share on facebook, or even a retweet on twitter. So get sharing my little internet minions*

Thank you for reading through this pitch, hopefully we have convinced you to donate as much as you can, or to spread as much word about us as you could ever want. For more updates just follow the links provided to our facebook and twitter pages, which should be positively giddy with the stuff we’re putting up there.

*You’re not actually my minions, that would be weird (yet somehow awesome) and I am certainly not some kind of theatrical Wicked Witch of The West (again that would be almost completely awesome)

story:
PANIC! is a rough-edged new musical based on the songs of the American rock band Panic! At The Disco. PANIC! The Musical tells the story of Andi Witko, a naive teenager on the verge of rebellion after meeting bad boy Oliver Murphy. The musical features songs from all four studio albums, including hits such as: "I Write Sins, Not Tragedies," "Lying is the Most Fun A Girl Can Have Without Taking Her Clothes Off," "Ready to Go," "This Is Gospel," etc. 

 PANIC! is created and directed by Alexis Acar with book by Christina Rose Sabia, choreography by Evan Lovelace featuring musical arrangements by Brandon Austin, musical direction by Craig Petrocelli, and stage management by Brianna Garza. 

 PANIC! is a cinematic whirlwind, which we intend to showcase in its fully-realized form.  With the producers' interest we've cultivated, and the outstanding connections we've made, your contributions will facilitate this Workshop, on our way to the ultimate Broadway production!

Please consider a contribution large or small, if you love Panic! At The Disco as much as we do or you just love contemporary musical theater - You're in for a show tonight.

story:
Short Summary

The Arts are disappearing in our schools, Ten West is here to save the day:

  • Ten West Center for the Arts is a 501(c)3 Non-Profit based in Fortville, Indiana. Our mission is to simply help youth stay creative. 
  • This campaign is running to help fund our theatre program's summer production of "The Nerd" by Larry Shue
  • With your help, our young adult theatre program will have the funding available to build and paint their set at no cost to performers, making theater accessible to anyone interested. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for a little, but we'll give a little too:

  • We need $1000 to achieve our goal. The money will go directly to sets, props, and costumes. 
  • We have many great perks at all levels of contribution! 
  • For $5, donors will receive a hand written thank-you card from the cast. 
  • For $10, you get a thank-you card and a hand-made friendship bracelet from the cast. 
  • For $20, you get a signed 8X10 photo of the cast and crew, as well as a bracelet and a thank-you card. 
  • $50, gets you get a signed 11x17 poster from the show, the cast photo, the bracelet, and thank-you card. 
  • $100 will get you all the previous perks, as well as a Ten West T-Shirt! 
  • $500 gets your name added to our permanent donor plaque in the Ten West Auditorium. 
  • If we do not reach our $1000 goal, all funds raised will still go directly to offsetting the cost of set, props, and costumes. 

The Impact

Check out the difference your small contribution makes to our community. 

  • Theatre is a fun experience for all involved. Being able to do it for free, is a very special thing. Your dollars are directly responsible for getting kids interested in theater, and busy after school. 
  • This is not our first production. We recently closed the musical "Little Shop of Horrors". We sold out every show and saw over 400 people in attendance. Before that we had successful runs of "Godspell" and "Black Comedy"
  • This is a 100% volunteer organization. None of your contribution goes towards salaries or hiring instructors. It all goes to helping the kids directly so they can put on a show. 

Risks & Challenges

We are already in production for this show, the challenge is to pay our bills, and to present a quality performance. 
  • Your donations help free up the funds to pay for facilities and overhead costs. 
  • This in turn helps us provide the theater program at no cost to students. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Strapped for cash right now? Thats okay:

  • Make some noise about the show. Share it with your friends on all your social media outlets. 
  • Tell everyone about this campaign and ask them to contribute what they can!

Thank you for your consideration.

story:
Village Playwrights Story

The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS was founded out of the need of Lesbian and Gay writers to have a venue to present their works without fear of being harshly criticized or dismissed because of their sexual orientation or gender identification.  The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS meet at the LGBT Center in New York on the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of each month and welcome all Playwrights, Screenwriters, Directors and Actors to participate in their programs.  The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS take pride in critiquing works solely on their merit and not on their sometimes sensitive subject matter. This allows each writer to find his or her voice as a creative individual.  To speak freely is to be empowered. 

What We Do

Twice a month we hold readings of plays. We help with the casting of plays and the readings are followed by a critique of the works by the writers’ peers which is an invaluable aid for the writer. We encourage writers to take their scripts off the shelves and out of the drawers and allow them the opportunity to hear their works performed by trained actors. Some writers choose to have their works read as they are working on them, scene by scene; others prefer to hear their works read when they are completed.

We sponsor An Evening of Short Plays in a theater that we rent in order to give the writers the further opportunity of participating in the production of their plays that have been workshopped at our meetings.  Putting a play before an audience is the best method for learning how to write well.

Since 1985, The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS have been actively involved in helping writers in their endeavors and we are deeply committed to continuing this valuable enterprise. We would gratefully appreciate your support. 

Many of our writers have gone on to have had their works presented by many local organizations such as the FRESH FRUIT FESTIVAL, the SAMUEL FRENCH OFF-OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL and THE THEATRE FOR THE NEW CITY.

What We Need 

We are seeking $500 to sponsor a Gay Holiday Short Play Reading Series celebrating Halloween (2014), Valentine's Day (2015) and Gay Pride in June (2015) . Short plays fitting the Gay Holiday theme will be solicited from the United States and internationally. The Village Playwrights will produce readings of the play at the LGBT Community Center in New York City.   The money will be used to pay for performance and rehearsal space for these special events. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donate your loft space or unused space for rehearsals.
story_txt:
Village Playwrights Story

The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS was founded out of the need of Lesbian and Gay writers to have a venue to present their works without fear of being harshly criticized or dismissed because of their sexual orientation or gender identification.  The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS meet at the LGBT Center in New York on the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of each month and welcome all Playwrights, Screenwriters, Directors and Actors to participate in their programs.  The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS take pride in critiquing works solely on their merit and not on their sometimes sensitive subject matter. This allows each writer to find his or her voice as a creative individual.  To speak freely is to be empowered. What We DoTwice a month we hold readings of plays. We help with the casting of plays and the readings are followed by a critique of the works by the writers’ peers which is an invaluable aid for the writer. We encourage writers to take their scripts off the shelves and out of the drawers and allow them the opportunity to hear their works performed by trained actors. Some writers choose to have their works read as they are working on them, scene by scene; others prefer to hear their works read when they are completed.We sponsor An Evening of Short Plays in a theater that we rent in order to give the writers the further opportunity of participating in the production of their plays that have been workshopped at our meetings.  Putting a play before an audience is the best method for learning how to write well.Since 1985, The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS have been actively involved in helping writers in their endeavors and we are deeply committed to continuing this valuable enterprise. We would gratefully appreciate your support. Many of our writers have gone on to have had their works presented by many local organizations such as the FRESH FRUIT FESTIVAL, the SAMUEL FRENCH OFF-OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL and THE THEATRE FOR THE NEW CITY.What We Need We are seeking $500 to sponsor a Gay Holiday Short Play Reading Series celebrating Halloween (2014), Valentine's Day (2015) and Gay Pride in June (2015) . Short plays fitting the Gay Holiday theme will be solicited from the United States and internationally. The Village Playwrights will produce readings of the play at the LGBT Community Center in New York City.   The money will be used to pay for performance and rehearsal space for these special events.  Other Ways You Can HelpDonate your loft space or unused space for rehearsals.

story:
About The West Village Musical Theatre Festival:


The West Village Musical Theatre Festival (WVMTF) offers writers, composers, lyricists, actors, and directors the opportunity showcase original works in a professional setting.

We believe there is a little “Village” in all of us, so we  challenge every participant to show us something new, refined, daring and that belongs to the artist alone. This mission goes well beyond the stage, and permeates the lives of the community we wish to create through our art: a community of emerging professionals that invoke the spirit of one of the most creative areas in New York City.

Since our first festival in 2010, we have expanded every year. And this year, we are bigger than ever!

We will present 5 series of 15 minute musicals. Each series has up to 6 shows, so the audience can enjoy a tasting menu of new musicals, sampling different styles, genres and subject matter during one visit to the theater. Some musicals are “Snapshots” of larger works, others are “Shorts” and stand completely on their own.

We want to provide the best opportunities for all of our artists. This means providing the right venue to showcase all of their hard work and creations.

We need a home!

This year, the home of the WVMTF will be The Players Theatre in the heart of the West Village. This is the perfect place to capture the spirit of this art community.

Built in 1907 and converted into a theater in the late 1950's, the Players Theatre has been a jewel in the midst of beautiful Greenwich Village, serving as a magnet for performing artists and their audiences.

The theater has been home to such long run productions as Charles Bush’s Psycho Beach Party and Teller and Todd Robbins‘ Ruthless  starring an 8yr old Brittany Spears, Natalie Portman and Legally Blonde the Musical’s  Laura Bell Bundy.

However, paying for the theater can be a pretty big hurdle to jump and we need your help. Our costs for the performance space come to $15,000.

Your contribution will help us produce 2 weeks of musical theater including:

25 tech rehearsals

5 dress rehearsals

20 series of musicals

100 PERFORMANCES!

Other Ways You Can Help


If you're unable to contribute to our IndieGoGo campaign, you can still be a part of the West Village! We appreciate your support however you are able to give. How about:

  •  Sharing a link to this IndieGoGo page on your social media platforms. The more updates, links, tweets, shares, and likes we can get, the better!
  •   Buy a ticket to see the festival! http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/708446
  •  Tell all your friends about the festival, invite one to come along with you to the show!
  •   Follow us on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter to stay connected!
Visit us at www.wvmtf.com.

If you are contributing to a specific show, please leave a comment on this page indicating the title of the show. 


THE PERKS:
- All perks may only be fulfilled prior to the date of the event's occurrence.
- A "Village Voucher" grants you the ability to  see any 4 series of your choosing. Including Repeats!
-All tickets purchased through this site will be available for pick up at the box office.

Special thanks to our video contributors: Resistance Pictures, sound editor-Yoko Higuchi, voice actor-Michael Evans, production assistant-Nadeem Ali

story:
Photo by kind permission of Kiyoko Lerner

Check out the profile of the play complete with quotes from playwright Judith Kampfner in Hyperallergic.

Watch our new video produced by Dre Voelkel. 

Please contribute! Stop Press: A generous supporter is matching our contributions--up to $5,000. Your donation will go even further to help develop the new play about outsider art: The Strange Case of Henry Darger. Proceeds from our performances will benefit the gallery in Chicago that has a permanent installation of Henry Darger's studio - with the goal of promoting contemporary self taught artists.

Our project?

To build awareness about the life and mind of an extraordinary man. He struggled as a blue-collar worker with emotional difficulties. He made his art the passionate focus of his life and did not seek an audience but after his death, it is inspiring people around the globe. To create this body of work, despite such financial and personal suffering and hardship is testament to the drive and optimism of a pure artist. It has a giddily uplifting impact - that's our belief.

Who are we?

We are a team of drama professionals committed to developing this new stage play. It is a process that involves writing, workshopping with actors, editorial sessions with the director, more workshopping, reading in front of a live audience and getting feedback from question and answer sessions. And then back to the drawing board for the next bout in the hope of attracting a major theater company that will be able to take on the scope of this very visual play.

David Kersnar, founding member of Lookingglass Theatre in Chicago is haunted by the life and mind of a reclusive hospital cleaner Henry Darger (1892 - 1973) who painted an astonishingly dramatic, beautiful epic work over sixty years in his attic room in Chicago and wrote an accompanying 15,000 page novel about a war waged by soldiers who enslaved children and the brave little androgynous girls who fought for freedom. 

The play will have two performances at the Intuit Center for Intuitive and Outsider Art in Chicago on August 8th and 9th. Box office proceeds will go to the museum/gallery, which houses a permanent installation of Darger's astonishing studio. It is the only non profit in the USA that is dedicated solely to promotion the work of outsider and self-taught artists with exhibitions, resources and educational programming.

 Henry Darger is undoubtedly now one of the best-known outsider artists in the world. His troubled life in a school for the feeble minded, the abuse he suffered and his stoic resilience are key to the reasons for his fame. However even though his life story is poignant, his fame is ultimately due to the brilliance of his art: the mixed media work that is stunningly contemporary (elements of manga, graphic novel, cartoon, comic book, and fantasy art) that is both unsettling and mesmeric.

David and Lookingglass actor Troy West have teamed up with journalist and veteran BBC radio producer, playwright and director Judith Kampfner. Her play ‘ The Strange Case of Henry Darger’ has already had a reading at Lookingglass. The team has taken it upon themselves to develop the play further and then shop it to theaters around the globe in the hope of taking Darger to a new audience.

The team has carved out time over the summer for two weeks of workshops over June and July in Chicago, which will culminate in the Intuit Gallery Benefit performances.  

This is a wholly independent project, which represents enormous challenges in turning it into a substantial stage production.  So, we are turning to friends and colleagues like you to help support it and spread the word.  This grassroots model is becoming more and more common in the arts and beyond, and we are striving to meet this challenge in a way that involves you and other fans.

Endorsements:

A very intriguing and imaginative interpretation of Darger’s life and work. I thought your play was ambitious and thought provoking.

- Michael Bonesteel. Adjunct professor at School of the Art Institute of Chicago and Darger biographer. 

Judith Kampfner's work in progress is a trip down a theatrical rabbit hole. It's  deftly zig-zagging script makes the life of this fascinating outsider artist from Chicago even more enchanting, tragic and intriguingly strange. The play also brims with choice details of everyday life in early 20th century Chicago making it not only great drama but a time-traveling experience.

- Tony Macaluso, Director of Syndication the WFMT Radio Network / The Studs Terkel Radio Archive

The Strange Case of Henry Darger, brings both fictional intrigue and historical perspective to the ongoing public fascination with the life and times of one Mr. Henry Darger .... While factual in many ways, Judith Kampfner's engaging  fictional re enactment of an important but still undetermined episode in Henry Darger's life, piques  even further the curiosity surrounding his supposed involvement in a horrible criminal act. 

- Carl Hammer of The Carl Hammer Gallery in Chicago 

Judith Kampfner and Troy West
Rewards: To thank you for your support, we have put together a number of The Strange Case of Henry Darger  special gifts . Even though our campaign's currency is in US dollars you can contribute in any currency. If you want to contribute more than the perk value, you can add to the contribution amount during the checkout process  :)   Some of our thank yous:

A unique color postcard produced for our show with the Darger image featured here (courtesy of Kiyoko Lerner).

photo by kind permission of Kiyoko Lerner

VIP tickets to the August 8th and 9th shows at the Intuit performance space in Chicago (below) your name in the program, a cocktail party with the cast, and a signed script of the play.

Intuit Center memberships full of opportunities to enjoy collections of outsider art from Darger and others:

A special behind-the-scenes tour of the museum's Henry Darger Room:

Music from Michael Wookey, the Paris-based composer who created original music for the play.

A limited edition portrait of Henry Darger by artist Michael Johnson:

Copies of The Outsider art magazine featuring articles on Darger:

A mini poster in Japanese about an award-winning Henry Darger documentary:

     

A beautiful, handmade plastic pin/ornament:

     

A landscape blank card with a continuous Darger image:

(partial views shown in picture)

Creative Team

Judith Kampfner is a New York based producer director and playwright. She has written directed and produced audio dramas for the BBC since 2004.
She’s narrated and produced documentaries for the BBC and NPR since 1990. From 1992 – 99, she lived in Chicago and filed stories about the Midwest, for WBEZ’s Chicago Matters and for the BBC, Australian Broadcasting and NPR. She left to start the pilot phase of the national public radio arts show Studio 360 and was arts producer at New York Public Radio for six years before starting her own production company. She’s currently working on a stage play about servants and employers in colonial Asia.

David Kersnar is a founding ensemble member of the Lookingglass Theatre Company and has performed, designed and directed with the company since 1988. Kersnar last appeared in Still Alice, Our Town, Arabian Nights, Secret in the Wings, Summertime, Metamorphoses, and The Great Fire as well as musicals Vanishing Twin, Her Name Was Danger, and Up Against It. Kersnar also appeared with the Goodman, Steppenwolf, Remains, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, The Actor’s Gang in Los Angeles, and the Touchstone Theatre of Pennsylvania. Kersnar has twice served as the Lookingglass Artistic Director and founded and directed Lookingglass Education & Community Programs and has served as Master Teacher. Kersnar last co-wrote and directed The Last Act of Lilka Kadison for Lookingglass as well and Sita Ram for Chicago Children’s Choir in collaboration with Natya Dance Theatre and Lookingglass Theatre. Other directing and writing credits include productions at Next Theatre, Chicago Lyric Opera, Chicago Symphony, Lively Arts and Chicago Children’s Theatre. Kersnar is currently an adjunct professor at Northwestern University and Roosevelt University. Kersnar co-founded and produced over 40 films and plays nationally and internationally with Shaking the Tree Interactive Productions, which uses theatrical problem-solving techniques in business environments. Film and television credits include U.S. Marshals, Since You’ve Been Gone, Early Edition, and Turks. David holds a BS in theatre/performance studies and a MFA in directing from Northwestern University.

Troy West has been a friend of Lookingglass Theatre Company for many years. Credits include performances include performances in: Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, The Wooden Breeks, George, The Idiot, The Old Curiosity Shop, Great Men of Science #'s 21 & 22, HARD TIMES and The Great Fire.Elsewhere in Chicago, Mr. West has appeared with the Steppenwolf Theatre Company in the original productions of August: Osage County (also on Broadway and in London and Sydney) and  Picasso at the Lapin Agile (also NYC, Los Angeles and San Francisco). 

At the Goodman Theatre: By the Music of the Spheres. A Red Orchid Theatre: (also Off- Broadway at the Barrow Street Theatre).The Grey Zone, The Physicists and The Hothouse. 

Appearances in Chicago productions include work at:  Next Theatre, Interplay, Remains, Famous Door, Roadworks Some Explicit Polaroids, Wild Life and The Illinois Theatre Center.

Regional credits include; Indiana Repertory Theatre Art , American Conservatory Theatre The House of Mirth, Theatre-By-The-Sea and New Harmony Theatre among others. Television credits include: Early Edition, Nash Bridges, The Pursuit of Happiness, The “Canned” Film Festival.

Film credits include: The Dilemma, Hellcab and the soon-to-be-released Advantage: Weinberg.

Michael Wookey is an English composer and producer based in Paris, France. As a teenager he was given a Salvation Army pump organ which belonged to his grandfather who was an organist during World War II. This instrument inspired Michael to start composing and collecting obscure instruments. To date he has recorded four albums, each recorded between his submarine-like studio and various meat lockers, churches and most recently a barn in the south of France. He can also be found conducting his orchestra of toys or composing for film and theatre.

Sydney Beveridge is a writer, editor, radio producer, and researcher based in New York City.  She has assisted Judith Kampfner with radio documentaries and dramas for BBC Radio 3, BBC Radio 4, BBC World Service, and Soundprint Media.  She also works as the Media and Content Editor of SocialExplorer.com, where she assists with grant proposal and curriculum development, conducts workshops and trainings, and manages the blog and social media outreach.  She graduated with a B.A. from Swarthmore College and an M.S. and M.A. from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.  

Finally some lovely comments from loyal supporters we have only just met. Thank you!

My wife and I stumbled onto Darger and the Detective at the Intuit on dress rehearsal night quite by accident. The enthusiasm shown just two days later by Troy West was infectious. I'm sure his performance compelled a commensurate contribution from the other actors. We look forward to seeing his interpretation of Darger again in the near future.  
- Audience member Lytle Johnson, software engineer and freelance bush pilot, Decatur Island, WA
You captured soooo much from many different realms (no pun intended)--from an 'ugly' side of Chicago to the inside of Darger's mind and the complexity of his world and how people saw him, all illustrated so subtly and yet explosively dramatic.  
- Audience member Bonnie McGrath, lawyer & blogger, Chicago, IL
 As a psychotherapist I was pleased by the accuracy and compassion with which Darger's character was developed by Judith Kampfner and portrayed by Troy West. Many people are startled by Darger's subject matter and his dysfunctional mind...issues which are often handled harshly and clumsily. It was refreshing to see his character developed in a way that did not vilify him or lead the audience to come to any conclusions but their own.
- Karen Lison, psychotherapist and author, ("Reclaiming Our Lives: Hope for Adult Survivors of Incest")

(Image by Henry Darger courtesy of Kiyoko Lerner.)

story:
Gone is a response piece dedicated to the girls of Chibok that were kidnapped from their beds by the terrorist group Boko Haram.

Gone is a collaborative work between dance and music that was originally inspired by the kidnapping of the Chibok schoolgirls by the terrorist group Boko Haram. It is a work that explores the parallels between our restrictive thinking of gender roles both here in the U.S. and in other places all over the world. We have found that these ignorant groups of thought often find themselves resulting in incredible violence against women. This is where we have started, we dance for all of the girls whose dreams have been incinerated and whose lives have been stolen. The creators of this work are Nick Doshier, composer, Tawny Garcia, choreographer and the dancers who went through incredible emotional and physical exploration to help bring this piece to fruition. 

The work will premiere at the University of Texas at Austin's Oscar G. Brockett Theater.

Performance Dates & Information:

November 14 & 15 at 7:30pm

November 15 & 16 at 2:00pm

Gone will premiere in the Fall concert for the University of Texas' award-winning Dance Repertory Theater. Fall for Dance is a showcase of unique and compelling dance works created by nationally renowned acclamied choreographers, including Christian Von Howard, Charles O. Anderson, Ellen Bartel, and Andrea Beckham.

PROGRAM: Through the Mountain/ Faith in Unknowing by Andrea Beckham,  Gone by Tawny Garcia, In the World of Things and Stuff  by Ellen Bartel, Seethe by Charles O. Anderson, Two Degrees by Christian Von Howard
story_txt:
Gone is a response piece dedicated to the girls of Chibok that were kidnapped from their beds by the terrorist group Boko Haram.
Gone is a collaborative work between dance and music that was originally inspired by the kidnapping of the Chibok schoolgirls by the terrorist group Boko Haram. It is a work that explores the parallels between our restrictive thinking of gender roles both here in the U.S. and in other places all over the world. We have found that these ignorant groups of thought often find themselves resulting in incredible violence against women. This is where we have started, we dance for all of the girls whose dreams have been incinerated and whose lives have been stolen. The creators of this work are Nick Doshier, composer, Tawny Garcia, choreographer and the dancers who went through incredible emotional and physical exploration to help bring this piece to fruition.  The work will premiere at the University of Texas at Austin's Oscar G. Brockett Theater.

story:
We are a small group of people against the greed and corporations of america!...

Not really.

The Story

University of North Texas students, Book Writers Amir Ellis and Stephanie Clausen along side with Lyrist Corbin Young and Composer Grant Michael Goldberg have created an original full length musical. 

Occupy:The Musical is loosely based upon the occupy movement. It follows  two best friends, Riley and Sam, who leave their white-picket fences of suburbia for the hustle and the bustle of a nearby city to attend a Star Trek convention, when they stumble upon a local occupy movement. There they meet a cast of loveable misfits, a purpose for the occupy movement, and a purpose for themselves.

How It All Started

Ellis and Clausen watnted to work on a project together, and being students tasked with work and studies barely found the time or ideas. Until one day leaving a university theatre production and passing by the local occupy camp, an idea struck Ellis, 'Occupy The Musical', and for once Clausen didn't grimice at the idea.
Soon after they found Young for lyrics, and Goldberg for musical scoring. What was a small idea soon became a full fleshed reality with the help of an on-campus student organization, Bored In Denton.
BID provided some resources and space to put on a preview performance in November, and now with BID and your help, we are now ready for a full production for Spring 2013.

The Financial Breakdown

Through Bored In Denton, Occupy: The Musical has options for performance space, but not the funding for it or other expenses such as, printing, marketing, sets, costuming, and tech.

That's where you all come in handy.

Every dollar counts, every contribution is necessary in making this original student production a reality.

Every penny, dime, and dollar will go strictly into printing for cast, posters and programs; marketing to help get the word out and to fill every seat; sets will be limited to what we can find at local thrift stores and garage sales; costuming budget will be used for raw supplies; and the money for tech goes into paying for the people who will run the facility on campus.

Any leftover money, if any, will be donated to our sponsor, Bored In Denton, for them to use to help them put on more events on campus to showcase original UNT talent, like us!

The Purpose

We are all UNT students. This is a full student-run, created, and so far produced original musical to ever be done on campus at UNT. From our diverse cast of 30 actors and singers to the people who help run the technical equipment, we are all students.
We've dedicated time, talent, and resources into making this a successful project. 
In November we debuted a preview for friends, student organizations, and sponsors to great sucess.
Our cast is from diverse majors and backgrounds, but a passion for singing and performing.
Together we have created an event in hopes to inspire others to do the same.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't help out through indie go go?
Feel free to help us with word-of mouth, and staying connected by Liking us on Facebook, Following on Twitter and telling everyone you know.
Thanks So Much,
Occupy The Musical

story:
Who We Are:

The Penn Dixie ensemble is --> Natalia Chami, Alex Suha, Julia Correa, Gaidig Mercier, Klas Lagerlund, Cecilie Solberg Knudsrod, Anisa George, and Mat Hare.

We live in seven different coutries --> Argentina, USA, Brazil, UK, France, Sweden, and Norway.

We are trying to do the impossible --> to overcome geographical and financial limitations which threaten our creative collaboration and to develop phenomenal work for international audiences.  

The Story:

We met at the London International School of Performing Arts, where we studied devised theater, and at the end of two years of training we decided to develop a tiny piece about the poet Arthur Rimbaud and his renunciation of art. It was about 12 minutes long. People really liked it. One of our teachers even said he laughed so hard he cried. So we decided to carry on to ...  

---> PHASE 2 Where we rented some rehearsal space in London and tried to turn the baby piece into a full grown work. We invited some people to see our rough cut, and even though they were very encouraging we knew we had a long way to go. 

---> PHASE 3 In the summer of 2011 we gathered together in a barn in Pennsylvania to get back to work and see what we could improve. We worked non-stop for a month building a set, gathering costumes, throwing out half of the material we had made, and reinventing a new half. At the end we all agreed the show was much improved. We even showed it to some audiences at the Philly Fringe, but we knew that - it still wasn't done!

Each time we return to The Seer it gets fiercer, deeper, and more potent. We are now seeking support to bring the play to its final and ultimate stage - to produce a professional theatrical run of it at the Edinburgh Festival in the summer of 2013. 

The Edinburgh Festival is considered by many to be one of the most important, and certainly one of the largest theater festivals in the world. It provides an opportunity for young companies like ours to try and make a name for themselves on the international stage. Producing a play at Edinburgh presents some of the most difficult logistical and financial challenges a company can face. It is a mad chaotic marketplace where sometimes miracles happen. 

We have received official offers from a number of venues who would like to present our show. To follow through with these offers we require financial support, and so we are turning to you.

---> THE FINAL PHASE is up to you!

We need to raise $23,000 to make The Seer happen this year. Because we are a truely international company we are disqualified from many govermental grants. National grants want to fund their own national citizens, and our company does not belong to one nation - it belongs to seven! But we don't want the fact that we don't qualify for limited regional funding to limit our creative lives. We are dreaming big and turning to you - our new govenment - for support. 

This is our first time trying Indiegogo - a grassroots, crowd funding method developed to assist emerging artists and creators of all kinds to produce their work. If you feel moved to donate, we've got some nifty gifts on offer to reward you. If you can't give, then spread the word! If you can't spread the word, then just send us some positive vibes. 

At the moment our meetings look like this...

You have the power to make them look like this again...

 

Thank you for watching and reading! Thank you for being our world-wide community!

story:
Our Story

By coincidence, we met in November of 2012 at a ballroom dance studio and very quickly decided to partner together and explore our shared passion for dance. For Kiri, competing in ballroom dance was a second chance to perform and entertain audiences with her years of technical training and experience. For Marc, competing in ballroom dance was an oppurtunity to make a substantial achievement in a second career, after having found his passion for dance late in life.  We invite you to join us on our journey as we prepare to compete!
 

 

 

 

Kiri Chapman

Kiri Chapman started ballet at an early age, leaving home at the age of thirteen to study at the  Kirov Academy of Ballet in Washington DC.  She graduated valedictorian from the Kirov Academy in 2005 and immediately joined the corps of Tulsa Ballet Theater in Oklahoma.  During her three seasons with the company, from 2005-2008, she performed nationally and internationally choreography from Twyla Tharp, Balanchine, Nacho Duato, Ma Cong, Petipa and many others. She has been recognized in several internationally acclaimed ballet competitions: Youth America Grand Prix New York Finals (top twelve), Jackson USA IBC (competitor), and New York IBC (semi-finalist).  Currently, she teaches at the University of Michigan’s UMove program, “Swing City Dance”, “The Glass Room” and coaches pre-professional students privately.

 

 

Marc Brewer

Marc Brewer is one of the Midwest's most sought after Latin Dance instructors, performers, and choreographers. Certified in 9 American competitive ballroom dances and proficient in Ballet, Modern, Jazz, and Hip-hop; Latin
dance and theatrical arts are his specialties and main focus with extensive training and experience in Salsa, Bachata, Zouk and Theatrical Dance. Competitive highlights include: Cubby Bear Salsa Competition in Chicago (3rd), Toronto Salsa Festival Professional Salsa and Bachata Divisions (1st and 2nd respectively), Michigan Dance Challenge Professional Showdance/Cabaret Division (2nd), Brazilian Beat Congress Professional Zouk Competition (1st), Tri-State Bachata Open Championship (1st), and the Montreal Salsa Convention Professional Salsa Competition (3rd). With recent performances at the Reno Bachata Festival, Toronto Bachata Festival, Washington DC (Capital Salsa Congress), Chicago Salsa Festival/Latin Street Congresso, Upsate NY Latin Dance Fest (NY), Montreal Bachata Zouk Festival and more...2012 was a breakout year for this Rising Star!

 

 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Ballroom Dance is one of the most expensive hobbies one can have, and the costs to compete professionally is substantial by anyone's measure. All money earned through this campaign will go directly towards our immediate expenses associated with preparation for this competition.

In the coming months our primary expenses will consist of:

  • Travel to Orlando for USDC
    • Hotel - 4 Nights at $185 - $740
    • Flights - 2 Tickets at $240 - $480
  • Professional Coaching
    • 8 Lessons at $100/hour - $800
  • Costumes
    • Ballroom Dress - $1000
    • Men's Ballroom Shirt - $250

Total - $3270

(in reality our expenses will be much more, but we're hoping this will be a more realistic and attainable goal for this campaign)

 

In return for joining us on this journey, we are offering several perks including:

  • A handwritten thank you note, a Youtube photo/video documentary chronicling our journey and a DVD of Marc and Kiri's performance at the United States Dance Championships!
  • A one hour-long private dance lesson from Marc or Kiri!
  • A personalized Youtube 30 second dance routine performed by Marc and Kiri to a song and theme of your choice!
  • Marc and Kiri will perform one of their competition winning routines and teach an hour long group lesson at your event, a spectacle sure to wow the crowd!
  • 10 private lessons with Marc and/or Kiri and learn/perform a professionally choreographed routine with Marc or Kiri designed exclusively for you!!!

 

 

 

The Impact

We can't begin to express the magnitude of what you will help us achieve. Many of the top cabaret coaches in the U.S. (former Champions) have expressed that we have the potential to really be contenders in this division. We are excited to be able to share our art and hardwork with the world!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

story:
for me? 

A new work by Heidi Strauss for Crooked Figure Dances

Crooked Figure Dances is the artistic home of dancer/choreographer Kate Alton. The company supports and showcases her creative and performance work.

for me? is a new work by inimitable choreographer Heidi Strauss for dancers Luke Garwood and Kate Alton. Conceived as a work that moves to multiple sites, it will have its first incarnation at this year's SummerWorks festival in Toronto from August 8th-18th.

Kate (a lyrical, passionate, well recognised dancer and award winning artist, if she does say so herself) can't wait to return to performing after a near two year hiatus during which she gave birth to and cared for her wonderful twin babies, Eleanor & Luca. 

Kate & Luke are pretty chuffed to be working with Heidi Strauss, whose work in recent years has marked her as among the most wonderful choreographers that Canada has lately produced.

We need an additional $2,500 to make this happen! $2,000 will pay for performance fees for Luke and Kate, and $500 will go toward the cost of rehearsal space.

Crooked Figure Dances is a charitable organization and as such can offer charitable receipts for donations of $25 and over. Check out our other perks-Kate is a great knitter!

story:
What is Off Air Radio? 

Off Air Radio is a collaboration of writers, producers, and sound designers dedicated to reviving the art of audio plays in the United States. These are dramatic pieces that you can enjoy anywhere: in your car, on your phone, and online.

Why should you donate?

Our Goal is to grow Off Air Radio into a resouce for other writers. We want to be opportunity writers wait years for, the chance to have your work produced. In order to do that, we want to make as afforable as we can for aspiring writers. This is where you come in. By donating to the project, you allow us to give more writers the amazing opportunity to see thier work come to life.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to contribute to the project even if you cannot donate. Here are some ways you can get involved with the project. 

1. Spread the word! Tell your friends and family about the project.

2. Sign up for our email list! By signing up for our email list, you will get updates from Off Air Radio, news updates, previews, and sneak peaks of our audio plays. http://eepurl.com/yCtQL

3. Subscribe to our channel on youtube! We release all our stories on youtube for free for a limited time. Also, all our previews and sneek peak videos will be uploaded to our channel.

"The Emerald Theater Ghosts"

     Daniel is a successful lawyer in the city of Los Angeles and firmly believes that ghosts do not exist. He is the responsible and protective older brother. Eric is the adventurer in the family and he travels around the world hunting for ghosts, although he has never actually seen a ghost.
     When Eric flies to L.A. to visit his brother, they get in another argument about Eric's hobby. Tired of his brothers remarks, Eric drags his older brother to the abandoned and burned Emerald Theater where they encounter something neither of them were expecting to find.  


"The Emerald Theater Ghosts" is our first audio play written by one of our producers, Abby Cervantes.

story:
Hello, World!

Charlatan Remedies, here, and we are performing our very first, original production, in the 2013 Toronto Fringe Festival. As part of the site-specific category, we are performing in a Toronto bar where every corner, stool, rail, and window is the stage. There's lots of fun in store and on tap! Seriously. It could get crazy. We aim to use our show as vehicle to create a one-of-a-kind theatrical experience where both the audience and artist may be surprised by what takes place. Hey nonny nonny hey!

The Show: Surviving Speares

“I had a dream last night, where I was in a bar, with Shakespeare and all of his characters, and they spoke in rhyme, and we all drank beer, and then Juliet whipped out a guitar, and we all sang. I forget how it ended. But it was crazy. It was fun.”- Cast member, Andrew Petker, (Hamlet) gives his synopsis of Survivng Speares.

In our premier show, we combine our homegrown script with improv and clowning styles (based on the teachings of Jacques Lecoq) to push the audience-artist relationship to the limit (wherever that is). Juliet may ask you on a date, Shakespeare may interview you to be his new muse...We know where it starts but we don't know where it will end. In this show, audience and artist are allies, so get ready patrons, because the bard is in!

A bit about us - Charlatan Remedies:

We are a theatre company committed to concocting cures for social stiffness.

Co-founders, A. Massoud, A. Simpson, and R. Liddiard, are three young ladies who are seriously aware that we are part of a fast-paced generation, living in a fast-paced world. Everyday we are uncomfortably aware that ours is a time where a million, delightful opportunities are missed, simply because we have lost the incentive to properly interact - that is, converse face-to-face (iPhone FaceTime doesn't count!) We refer to this epidemic as “social stiffness”.

We began Charlatan Remedies to find cures for this social ailment via original dramatic works (written by us) that seek to inspire new camaraderies in our audiences that (we hope!) they will carry out into the community.

For our first demonstration, we have been accepted into the Toronto Fringe Festival with an original show, Surviving Speares.

Please Meet the Cast:

Alexandra Simpson: Co-founder, co-producer, Juliet

Andrea Massoud: Co-founder, co-producer, Cordelia

Rebecca Liddiard: Co-founder, co-producer, Witch #3

Bertha Lee: Production-Stage Manager extraordinaire

Andrew Petker: Hamlet

Charlotte Cattell: Witch #2

Chris Isaak: Shakespeare

Emma Ferrante: Nurse

Joella Crichton: Witch #1

Peter Higginson: King Lear

Zachary Knowles: Romeo

Jennifer Jakobs: Costume Design

Kvesche and Konrad Karczewski: Sound Design

We hope to put our box office sales toward paying our talented cast and crew through a profit-sharing payment structure.

 THEREFORE

Your donation will go towards:

  • Administration & Entrance Fees
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Print ads in the festival program and an array of local publications
  • Printing costs for promotional material and scripts, e.g. posters, coasters for tasty beverages, etc. (check out the image gallery!)
  • Costume rental & dry-cleaning
  • Props

Thus far:

  • We have held two vigorous days of auditions and hired a cast of talented artists from all over Toronto.
  • Had our logo and promotional material designed pro-bono by a Toronto graphic designer (Trevor Kluke Design)
  • We have negotiated a rehearsal space for two afternoons a week for FREE at another local bar (The Fraternal Order of the Eagles).
  • We have organized our first company production fundraiser, an event we have called The KICKlist, which took place May 16th at the Magpie Taproom (831 Dundas St. W.) 

Other ways you can help:

  • Share this link on Facebook
  • LIKE our Facebook page and follow us on Twitter @CharlatanRems
  • Come out to our fundraising events

AND

SEE THE SHOW! July 3-7, 9-14 in the Toronto Fringe Festival 2013 at the Magpie Taproom 831 Dundas St. W.

***Don't forget to check out our other videos and pictures in the campaign gallery***

ONLINE:  fringetoronto.com

PARKING LOT BEHIND HONEST EDS, (581 BLOOR ST W) OR 1 HOUR BEFORE SHOW @ THE MAGPIE TAPROOM, (831 DUNDAS ST WEST)

http://alexandrawatt.ca/charlatanremedies.html

@CharlatanRems

story_txt:
Hello, World!
Charlatan Remedies, here, and we are performing our very first, original production, in the 2013 Toronto Fringe Festival. As part of the site-specific category, we are performing in a Toronto bar where every corner, stool, rail, and window is the stage. There's lots of fun in store and on tap! Seriously. It could get crazy. We aim to use our show as vehicle to create a one-of-a-kind theatrical experience where both the audience and artist may be surprised by what takes place. Hey nonny nonny hey!

The Show: Surviving Speares

“I had a dream last night, where I was in a bar, with Shakespeare and all of his characters, and they spoke in rhyme, and we all drank beer, and then Juliet whipped out a guitar, and we all sang. I forget how it ended. But it was crazy. It was fun.”- Cast member, Andrew Petker, (Hamlet) gives his synopsis of Survivng Speares.
In our premier show, we combine our homegrown script with improv and clowning styles (based on the teachings of Jacques Lecoq) to push the audience-artist relationship to the limit (wherever that is). Juliet may ask you on a date, Shakespeare may interview you to be his new muse...We know where it starts but we don't know where it will end. In this show, audience and artist are allies, so get ready patrons, because the bard is in!
A bit about us - Charlatan Remedies:
We are a theatre company committed to concocting cures for social stiffness.
Co-founders, A. Massoud, A. Simpson, and R. Liddiard, are three young ladies who are seriously aware that we are part of a fast-paced generation, living in a fast-paced world. Everyday we are uncomfortably aware that ours is a time where a million, delightful opportunities are missed, simply because we have lost the incentive to properly interact - that is, converse face-to-face (iPhone FaceTime doesn't count!) We refer to this epidemic as “social stiffness”.
We began Charlatan Remedies to find cures for this social ailment via original dramatic works (written by us) that seek to inspire new camaraderies in our audiences that (we hope!) they will carry out into the community.
For our first demonstration, we have been accepted into the Toronto Fringe Festival with an original show, Surviving Speares.
Please Meet the Cast:
Alexandra Simpson: Co-founder, co-producer, Juliet
Andrea Massoud: Co-founder, co-producer, Cordelia

story:
Short Summary

 “the Stranger” -- an ongoing study and discourse, is inspired by Latino choreographer David Herrera’s experience growing up poor in Hollywood, CA. Using the personal stories of the director and cast, “the Stranger” presents the difficulty of finding and defining oneself through one’s inclusion and exclusion from different communities when poverty, culture, and media images intercede. In this current episode DHPCo. reveals how a person’s position within America’s class system affects their paths of self and community identity, and the consequences those chosen paths may have.

“Growing up, I didn’t realize I was poor”, explains Herrera. “We were just living, and in my child’s eyes, quite happy. It wasn't until I became an adolescent that I began to see the difference between me and my schoolmates. The clothes they wore, the things they did or DIDN’T have to do, and things they possessed that were clearly out of my parents’ (and my) reach”.

Through a seamless fusion of modern dance, theater, and text, Herrera lends a voice to “the Stranger” that bears from the inner struggle of someone growing up within conflicting communities, in this case the working-class and middle/upper-class. In particular, Herrera sheds light on the complexities of someone making personal choices in regards to identity within the structures of status and class limitations.

Can we come to define and identify ourselves (and be at peace with those decisions) by pushing away culture and even family? Or are we in danger of becoming a permanent stranger to the self by doing so? “the Stranger” brings to life the complexities of inclusion and exclusion that the working class may experience, and the struggle to understand and find oneself within all this terrain.

Choreography: David Herrrera and Company dancers

Theatrical Director: Jean Jonhstone

Administration/Outreach: Taylor Carvey

Music: Rob Reich

Costumes: Keriann Egeland

Light Design: Ray Oppenheimer

Photography: Marissa Aragona

Dancers: Helena Birecki, Sophia Formosa, Kaitlin Muse, Molly Fletcher-Lynch 

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $2,800+ to pay for our two weekends, a total of 6 shows at Dance Mission Theater in San Francisco.  If you help us obtain this milestone we will be able to offset the cost of theater rental freeing up the ticket sales to pay our performers which is the ultimate goal.  

*NOTE: most dancers make under minimum wage via stipends but deserve much much more for the time, commitment, energy, and body work they put into a full season of rehearsals, tours, and performances.  We at DHPCo. are working hard to fulfill this obligation but we do still need your assistance.  

Last year we had a very successful fundraising season in part thanks to you and the many who attended the show. WE hope to continue our ongoing relationships with all of you, consider donating once again.

The Impact

With modern dance as our medium DHPCo presents work that tell stories of the human condition.  We make dance works accessible through narrative, story telling, and visceral  choreography.  We are particulary interested in bringing in a"non-traditional" dance  audience including folks from underrespresented (i.e. Latino/Hispanic) and lower income communities who are seldom exposed to modern dance.  

In “the Stranger” DHPCo. exposes topics that are taboo or difficult for many to admit. In particular: shame, regret, and the consequences of having to choose one identity over another.  Herrera explains, “It is important to understand how our finances affect both communities and individuals alike.  We cannot go pretending that financial classes don't exist or even worse, that they don't affect us in long-lasting personal ways.” 

We have a rich history of culturally influenced dance pieces including:

  • A) A Modern World: Latino Perspectives (2009)
  • B) History of Flight: An Immigration Story (2009)
  • C) American Layercake (2011)
  • D) Slumber (2012)

 

ACCOLADES:

2013- Commission UCSC Theater Arts Dept “the Stranger” excerpt
2013- Zellerbach Community Arts Grant “the Stranger (Part 1)
2012- Residency Studio 210
2011- Puffin Foundation Grant “American Layercake”
2011- GW College Professional Dance Invitational
2009 -Residency Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts “Histories of Flight: An Immigration Story”
2007- ODC Pilot Mentorship Program

 

PRESS and FEATURES

The company has been featured in multiple print publications and online: SF Guardian, San Jose Mercury News, Santa Cruz Sentinnel, Santa Cruz Good Times, Wanda Sabir’s Radio Podcast, Mission Loc@l, California Literary Review (Dance Vine).

Other Ways You Can Help

Send our Campaign to Friens who you think Might be Interested.  

LIke US on Facebook and follow our process

Refer us to Press Personnel, Granting bodies, Residency Studios, Universities & Schools, and Communty Outreach Programs who might want to present our body of work

story:
UPDATE 2-13-13: Your donation is being matched by an anonymous donor/bard lover dollar for dollar!  Please donate today and help us make our goal!

What Are We Doing?

Orlando Shakespeare Theater in Partnership with UCF is preparing to do Titus Andronicus for the first time in 24 years. Titus is known as Shakespeare’s bloodiest and most violent work. In order to make this production a savage success, we need money to concoct enough fake blood to fill 15 bodies (so we will not have to actually slaughter our actors every night).

Concept

Here is the concept for the play from the director, Jim Helsinger:

"This is going to be a terrific Titus with a small cast in an intimate thrilling space, close-up and personal. The set is basically white and gets completely splattered in blood by the end of the show. Each death is choreographed to be both artistic and horrifying. They start out realistic and get more and more artistic with each death, until we are literally throwing buckets of blood in the last scene. People are stabbed, shot and sacrificed, hands cut off, a tongue cut out and it includes the most murders of any Shakespeare play. Simple, gory, horrific, sick and twisted, Titus was the most popular of Shakespeare's plays during his lifetime!"

How Much Blood???

 
1 Roman General

+

 
4 Martial Sons

+

  
1 Beautiful Daughter

+


2 Imperial Contenders

+

 
4 Lascivious Goths

+

 
1 Evil (volde)Moor(t)
_________________________

15 deaths
x
2½ gallons per performance
x
38 performances
_________________________

115 gallons of blood = GRAND TOTAL: $5000

 

About the Play

Shocking, savage, and outrageously entertaining – Titus Andronicus is a cataclysmic cycle of revenge between the families of Titus, the great Roman general, and Tamora, the sadistic Queen of the Goths. Each of their barbarous and diabolical acts begets more brutal acts of retaliation. Theatrically vivid and surprisingly moving, Titus Andronicus is what a summer blockbuster would be if it were written by the world's great genius of language and theater.

Performances
March 27th - April 28, 2013

Opening Night Pre-Show Chat
Join us in the Patrons' Room on Friday, March 29 from 7:15 to 7:45 p.m. for a fun and informational Pre-Show Chat with the director and members of the design team.

Opening Night Party
Immediately following the premiere, join us for a party in the lobby at the Lowndes Shakespeare Center. The party is FREE to all ticket holders and includes hors d'oeuvres provided. We'll also have happy hour specials at our cash bar. No RSVP necessary.

About Us

Who We Are
The Orlando Shakespeare Theater is Central Florida’s premier professional theater. The Theater serves adults, children, students and seniors, regardless of race, age or economic status, across the Central Florida region and beyond.

Our Mission
With Shakespeare as our standard and inspiration, the Orlando Shakespeare Theater in Partnership with UCF produces bold professional theater, develops new plays, and provides innovative educational experiences that enrich our community.

Web Site
To learn more about Orlando Shakespeare Theater please visit us at orlandoshakes.org.

Other Ways to Help

Help us make this show a "slice" of heaven! Use the Indiegogo tools to share this campaign with your friends, colleageues, relatives, etc. via Facebook, Twitter, and other social media faves.

story:
***BREAKING NEWS***

In honor of hitting our $1000 goal, we've added a brand new perk! For $75 you can become a member of Charley Kendall's Coffee Klatch*. This new park includes one genuine bottle of Byfar Coffee Syrup, one genuine PMRP mug and our genuine thanks!

*Charley Kendall not included.


Join us this December as 

The Post-Meridian Radio Players proudly present our grandest show of the year: 

The Big Broadcast of 1962: A Byfar Christmas Carol!

Yes folks, this time around Frank Cyrano and the gang are learning the true meaning of the holidays in their own unique way. We'll have all of the classic comedy and music you expect from the Byfar crew and the Chowder House gang.

We’re trying to raise $1000. Why, you ask? Because that’s the balance due on the rental of our theater, the Historical Regent Theatre located in also somewhat-historical Arlington, Massachusetts.  Any extra funds go towards costuming, live foley equipment, publicity and everything else that goes into making the show a grand time for all!

Without this $1000 payment for the theater, the show simply won’t happen. 

That’s where YOU come in! Impress your friends with your natty PMRP t-shirt! Astound relatives with your cast-signed copy of the “Original” Byfar 1962 Press Release! Increase your internet street cred with a mention on our website! And loads of other great perks!

Bottom line is, every penny raised goes into making a better, brighter, Byfar-ier show for you!

The PMRP is a part of a 501(c)(3) organization so any funds raised go right back into producing high quality shows for you!

Please note, perk items like pins and t-shirts will ship after the show closes!

PERFORMANCE DATES

Thursday, December 19th, 2013 @ 8:00pm

Friday, December 20th, 2013 @ 8:00pm

Saturday, December 21st, 2013 @ 2:00pm (matinee)

Saturday, December 21st, 2013 @ 8:00pm


The Regent Theatre
7 Medford St.
Arlington, Massachusetts

To receive updates on A Byfar Christmas Carol or any of our other shows, like us on Facebook or visit our website!

story:
Short Summary

Constance has a dream Her dream is to become a member of the Martha Graham Dance Company. She has already taken steps to getting started. This summer she was asked to begin the Graham Program and start rehearsals with the Graham II, the second company of Martha Graham. Constance has proven time and time again that she will make her goals become realities. She graduated from Southern Methodist University with a degree in Dance. It was not the easiest road to walk. After being denied a spot in the Meadows Dance division twice, she showed everyone that she wasn’t going to give up. Being accepted finally to the program she became a force to be reckoned with. She became a strong worker, a reliable dancer, and even created some of her own works. She went from being a second thought in the dance world, to becoming a potentially great dancer in the real world. As her next goal to reach the top, she is going to start working with Graham II, and prove to them that she has what it takes to make it in their company. She cannot achieve this goal alone, and should you contribute to her goal, you will be part of her journey to the world stage, and she and her support team will be forever grateful. What She Needs Realistically speaking, this endeavor will cost somewhere in the range of $30,000. We are starting with an initial raise of $6000 to help get her through the first year of her work. Instructional lessons, travel, shoes, physical health management it is all needed to achieve this level. Constance's drive, passion, focus, and talent will make her goals a reality. She is limited only by the funds available to help make her dreams come true. The Impact Constance will become something great, and she will do this because she is blessed with such a strong and passionate support system. By becoming part of this system you too with impact the art world. We realize some of you won't be able to contribute but that doesn't mean you can't help! Please put the word out to your circle of friends and family. The more people who share Constance's story the better! Please share, share, share! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Where this funding is going:
    • Dance Classes at the Graham school, a requirement for the company- $2500 
    • Health wellbeing, preventative physical care to make sure major injuries do not halt dancing. -$500
  • Donation Thank yous:
    • $25- Hand written Thank You note from Constance
    • $50- A sticker representing your support in addition to the Thank You note.
    • $100- An autographed photo of Constance in addition to the sticker and Thank You note.
  • If I do not reach my goal the funds raised will go to the same places, in a %80 to %20 split.

The Impact

Your contribution means you are allowing for someone's dream to come true. The only thing in the way of Constance's goal is funds to make it happen.

Constance has a resilient attitude that has pushed her forward in life. She never gives up and always puts forth the maximin ammount of effort. She will be a great dancer, and you can help her get there. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • With tools like facebook, twitter, social media in general, you have the power to let people know about this!

Thank you so much! Love Constance

She became a strong worker, a reliable dancer, and even created some of her own works. She went from being a second thought in the dance world, to becoming a potentially great dancer in the real world. As her next goal to reach the top, she is going to start working with Graham II, and prove to them that she has what it takes to make it in their company. She cannot achieve this goal alone, and should you contribute to her goal, you will be part of her journey to the world stage, and she and her support team will be forever grateful. What She Needs Realistically speaking, this endeavor will cost somewhere in the range of $30,000. We are starting with an initial raise of $6000 to help get her through the first year of her work. Instructional lessons, travel, shoes, physical health management it is all needed to achieve this level. Constance's drive, passion, focus, and talent will make her goals a reality. She is limited only by the funds available to help make her dreams come true. The Impact Constance will become something great, and she will do this because she is blessed with such a strong and passionate support system. By becoming part of this system you too with impact the art world. We realize some of you won't be able to contribute but that doesn't mean you can't help! Please put the word out to your circle of friends and family. The more people who share Constance's story the better! Please share, share, share! 


What We Need & What You Get

Where this funding is going:

Dance Classes at the Graham school, a requirement for the company- $2500 
Health wellbeing, preventative physical care to make sure major injuries do not halt dancing. -$500


Donation Thank yous:

$25- Hand written Thank You note from Constance
$50- A sticker representing your support in addition to the Thank You note.
$100- An autographed photo of Constance in addition to the sticker and Thank You note.


If I do not reach my goal the funds raised will go to the same places, in a %80 to %20 split.



The Impact
Your contribution means you are allowing for someone's dream to come true. The only thing in the way of Constance's goal is funds to make it happen.
Constance has a resilient attitude that has pushed her forward in life. She never gives up and always puts forth the maximin ammount of effort. She will be a great dancer, and you can help her get there. 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
I know some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
With tools like facebook, twitter, social media in general, you have the power to let people know about this!


Thank you so much! Love Constance

story:
Short Summary

Who’s There Theatre’s debut production is a play inspired by interviews with Toronto’s homeless community. An epidemic hits Toronto, causing people to mysteriously disappear, and the city is forced to change in order to survive. A collection of stories about the irony of living in a city of 2.7 million people where everyone is alone.

By: Who's There Theatre
Company: Who's There Theatre
Company origin: Toronto, ON
Director: Tyler Graham
Choreographer: Alyssa Bartlett, Christina Demunda, Anthony Di Feo
Cast: Daniel Bagg, Alyssa Bartlett, Christina Demunda, Ashlyn Kusch

Show length: 60min.
Warnings: Sexual Content, Mature Language, Audience Participation

This performance is not accessible for non-English speakers

venue

St. Vlad's Theatre

show times

July 03 07:00 PM
July 06 08:00 PM
July 07 12:00 PM
July 08 01:15 PM
July 11 11:00 PM
July 12 11:30 PM
July 13 05:15 PM

 

tickets are $10 at the door.

What We Need

Right now, the biggest expense for us is creating the look of the show! That means creating the perfect props, buying the perfect costumes, and peicing together the perfect set that will make this show amazing.

All of your generous contributions will go toward creating a world for our piece, that helps engage the audience in the story that we are telling.

The Impact

Who's There Theatre's original idea was to create a piece that reflected the troubles of the homeless in the city of Toronto. Finding that an issue such as a homelessness is so broad, we as a group decided to focus on the metaphor of invisbility that the we think the homeless suffer every day.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation today, we urge you to come and see the show that we've created! It will be running seven performances throughout the course of Toronto Fringe, and we would love to have any support that we can get!
