story:
Short Summary

7 Potencias presents a rich and vibrant culture from the lesser known part of eastern Cuba, known in Cuba as the Oriente.

7 Potencias is a music and dance troupe based in Cuba!

This will be our first ever U.S. appearance! 7 Potencias will be arriving on November 10, 2013 to the U.S. for a series of workshops and performances in preparation for the 15th anniversary of the company. We want to showcase our work that spans across the years. This series of workshops and performances will be for a month in the San Francisco Bay Area. 

 7 Potencias is unique in that it is able to present authentic folkloric traditions. Many of its members are descendants of immigrants from Haiti, Jamaica, and other Caribbean islands which informs their work. Putting this investigative work on stage and highlighting the stories learned from family members makes it one of the more reliable groups presenting this lesser known Cuban folklore. 

 7 Potencias was founded by close friends who all grew up in the same small city in the Oriente (Eastern) part of Cuba and studied together at performing arts schools and universities in Oriente and Havana. This close-knit group of musicians and dancers had been a part of many other dance troupes and participated in numerous national and international events and festivals. We decided to share our love of Afro-Cuban traditions and especially the lesser-known Oreinte traditions with wider audiences.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds to cover initial costs of the flights, visas, accommodations and costumes for the members of 7 Potencias. We want to expand their work and share it with wider audiences.

Reaching the $12,000 goal will help to cover the initial production costs of 7 Potencias' U.S tour 2013. This will be a great start in funding the entire cost of putting on this U.S. premiere tour of 7 Potencias.

The Impact

In 2003, I began the endeavor to bring 7 Potencias to perform in the U.S. At that time, because of the regulations and the papers needed between countries, we got the U.S. permits, but not the Cuba permits on time. The following 5 years no Cuban groups were coming into the U.S at all. In 2009 I tried again, and was able to get the U.S. permits, but the Cuban permits were delayed.

NOW WE’RE READY! This year we re-applied and we have permits from both countries and that is why we are asking for your help to make this dream project a reality.

This is the dream of the last 10 years that we never gave up on. We need more dance companies like this that do investigative work and research in order to go beyond the popular and share their cultural heritage and roots on stage.

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE DONATE WHAT YOU CAN HERE, AND SHARE THIS LINK WITH YOUR FRIENDS, COWORKERS AND FAMILY. FOLLOW US ON FACEBOOK TO STAY NOTIFIED OF CLASSES, WORKSHOPS AND PERFORMANCES BY 7 POTENCIAS. BRING FRIENDS TO THE EVENTS! IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO DIRECTLY VOLUNTEER WITH CULTUCUBA TO SEE THIS DREAM PROJECT COME TO LIFE, CONTACT MANUEL SUAREZ AT cultucuba@gmail.com.  .

Some people just can’t contribute MONEY but that doesn’t mean they can’t help. WE NEED YOUR WORDS TO SPEAK THIS PROJECT INTO LIFE; SPREAD THE WORD AND COME SEE FOR YOURSELF THE RICH LEGACY OF THE AFRO-CUBAN FOLKLORIC ARTS MASTERFULLY PRESENTED BY 7 POTENCIAS.

story:
STRETCH GOAL!

Wow! We reached our production goal of $1,000 in under 2 weeks. THAT'S INCREDIBLE! We are so floored by the generosity of our community. So we thought, since we have two weeks left at Indiegogo, let's give back to the community. We are now endeavoring to raise another $300 for charity! 

R I B S is teaming up with Girls Inc. NYC - a non-for-profit dedicated to celebrating and supporting young women across the five boroughs — to bring high school girls to the show, free of charge. This is a show for them. Help us make it happen! 

More info about Girls, Inc. NYC here: 

http://www.girlsincnyc.org/

SO THE STORY GOES

Hello! We're the cast and creative team of R I B S, a new poetic-theatre piece that explores women's relationships with beauty and the body.

What does it mean for women to shrink in this world, contort themselves to impossible and pervasive standards? How do we celebrate the resiliency of (all) women? Since 2013, the playwright, Geneviève Beaudoin, has been interviewing women in New York City about beauty. These words have transformed into the poetry project known today as R I B S - a play that continues to be workshopped through performance. 

HERE’S WHERE YOU COME IN

R I B S  will perform at Planet Connections Theatre Festivity this June. We are producing the show without the financial help of an existing theatre company, which is why we need your help to make it happen.

Here's where your support goes:

  • Precious real estate aka REHEARSAL SPACE  in the city

  • Professional photo and video documentation (check out the great team at Sub/Urban Photography)

  • General production costs

  • Printing scripts & festival posters

  • And most importantly, artist stipends

While this is a passion project for so many of us, we believe artists should be paid for their work and we want to extend a gesture to our cast and crew. Your contribution will help us pay our actors, musicians, audio engineer, lighting designer and board op., stage manager, etc.

And once you donate, we won’t leave you in the dark. We’ll be posting photo and video updates each week -- showing you what we’re up to in rehearsals.

WTF IS THAT RIB NOW?

R I B S believes there is power in sharing stories -- with humor and heart and all the messy contradictions of being human. 

These stories are born of particulars and aren’t meant to represent the full spectrum. We welcome the stories still yet to be heard, and those who own them.

Please consider joining us in the conversation. A donation of any kind will go far in supporting R I B S and bringing the kind of discussion it begs one step closer to our communities. Thank you.

ALTERNATIVE SUPPORT

Can't contribute $$? No worries, we get it. Here’s how you can still support our project:

  • Buy tickets! Come see our world of R I B S

  • Share this page! The more people find out about us, the better.

  • Like and share our Facebook page!

  • Do you a rehearsal studio space?  A coupon for heavy duty printing? You get the idea... 

We appreciate it.  
Many thanks,
The RibCage

story:
The Story

On September 23 and 24 I will be premiering "Solo un poco," a solo choreographed by Idan Sharabi for 2015 McKnight Dance Fellow, Alanna Morris-Van Tassel, at the Cowles Center in Minneapolis as apart of the McKnight SOLO concert.  The first phase of the creative process was completed in New York in June 2016 with the support of the McKnight Dancers Fellowship.

An Israeli-based choreographer, your contribution covers the cost of Idan's flight from Tel Aviv to Minneapolis, applicable transfer fees, and his travel expenses for the tech week and premiere. Being able to bring him to the States in September means we can successfully complete this project, marking a significant milestone in my career!

"Solo un poco" embodies the practice of being in the "now," or the present moment.  Through Idan's movement language, I enjoy and play with time, stretching and capturing the moment, finding limilitess potential in dissonnace and intensity.  Working one-on-one is an exceptional opportunity for artistic growth.  It is empowering and challenging and causes us to discover more about our own power and potential.  

The McKnight Dancers Fellowship is a recognition of artistic excellence for mid-career dancers in Minnesota. Three dancers are awarded fellowships each year and are given the opportunity to perform a commissioned solo from a choreographer of their choice.

 

Risks and Challenges

It takes a lot of effort to bring an international choreographer to the States and is very costly.  McKnight Dance Fellows often choose local or national artists for that reason.  On occasion, but rarely, an international choreographer is not able to come for the SOLO tech week/premiere; and it places a lot of responsibility on the dancer to see the work through to opening night. 

"Solo un poco." is a NEW creation and currently a work-in-progress.  Idan's presence in Minneapolis would be best to finalize the work, as it relates to technical, theatrical, and artistic decisions. 

This will be an extraordinary occasion for the Twin Cities dance community to build connections with a well-known, emerging voice of contemporary dance.  Public talks with the choreographer will be held at the Cowles Center on Tuesday 9/20 and as Friday 9/23.  Additionally, there will be a  reception post-performance on Friday 9/23.

story:
The Blue

The Blue is a new work by award-winning poet and director Fiona Templeton, artistic director of The Relationship. 

In The Blue, a man and a woman speak in their own voices, as well as in the imagined thoughts of the other, even ventriloquizing each other until the almost-bare stage seems populated with voices. A tale without caution, caught in several acts.

Who We Are

The name of our company, The Relationship, is a reflection of our philosophy in experimental theater and poetry. We identify the connections between disciplines, people, perspectives, approaches to language, production sites, and the audience.  The company specializes in staging adventurous poetic work, especially innovative work by women.

All of our work uses approaches to staging and seating that challenge conventional relationships to the audience--including runway stages, players embedded in the audience, an audience of one person, immersive experiences, and a variety of site-specific work.

What We Need

Because of cuts to our annual funding—as well as the ongoing threats to the arts under our current political administration—we are seeking to raise $5000 by May 18, 2017 in order to help compensate the hardworking and brilliant members of the cast and crew of The Blue. 

The Impact

Your donation to The Blue will help support the careers and livelihoods of writers, dancers, producers, and directors who continue to push the boundaries of what text and performance can mean in the 21st Century. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't make a contribution at this time? Here's some other ways you can help:

  • Share our Indiegogo campaign on your social media networks
  • Spread the word among friends via email and word-of-mouth and urge them to make a contribution

story:
sans Seattle Premiere 

  • What does it feel like to be without limits? 
  • We're committed. This ensemble has kept in touch, through projects and respect since our 2014 project "This Is Not A Table for Three" (The Pocket, On the Boards). We're ready to make something that goes beyond what each art form involved can accomplish on its own.
  • Support a team of artists pushing themselves beyond their thresholds physically, mentally, and emotionally to address problems in the art world and society at large. All while making something daring and new. And you could be an important part of it!

What We Need & How You're A Part of It

We need about $6,000 to fund a project of this caliber and present it to Seattle, and even more for when we bring it to NYC. So actually, every bit counts:

  • You will see how every penny of the donations are spent. We are in a position where someone liked our work together in the past, so all the fundraising goes to the artists and money they've invested in this endeavor, both through years of training and their current fiscal contributions to this work.
  • Some general figures (AKA where your money is going...to skilled artists):
  • We keep good records, here are some specifics:
  • We are in the unique position in this community that we can offer workshops of our specific skills, sneak peaks (in person and via the internet), behind-the-scenes looks by professionals, and many more advantages that come with working with generous and seasoned artists. 

The Impact

sans is about exploring the problems of gender, using classical springboards and contemporary applications:

  • The world is rapidly changing, for the better in many ways, but backwards in others. We need to use the arts to battle stigmas and break boundaries, so that we can apply those ideas to every-day life. 
  • We have learned how to work together, and we trust each other.
  • We recognize the problems rampant. We're members of our artistic communities. We handle things with care, but are also striving to be fearless.

Risks & Challenges

Nudity. 
We know we've mentioned this show is in the nude. And that's dangerous for a lot of reasons.
We'll leave you to think about it. 

Oh, and classically trained performers reaching into other mediums and defying cultural norms of gender and disciple. Also pretty risky.

  • We've all been waiting for this challenge. And we've been building our skills and repertoires to give it a go.
  • We respect each other, our audiences, and our arts.
  • We're using classical texts, choreography, and music as a means to explore contemporary topics. Artworks like Romeo & Juliet and Medea have survived centuries, we study them in school, but many of the gender issues in these works are still setting the world on fire today.

Our Team (Plus You)

sans is created by Lauren Hlubny (experimental theatre director, NYC/Paris), Christin Call (Coriolis Dance a Seattle contemporary ballet company co-founder), Daniel Christensen (Seattle actor involved in Fringe around town, including LiveGirls, Annex, and 14/48), and Joshua Dent (Nashville cellist and music improvisation instructor). 

The team also includes The Seattle Demo Project (sponsored by Shunpike), the Pocket Theatre (a Seattle arts advocacy venue), Seattle producer/director Wiley Basho Gorn, Seattle filmmakers and photographers Cainen Martens and Bret Doss, Birmingham costumer Cammie Sanders, NYC artist Cathleen Parra, and the Paris&NYC collective Danse Theatre Surreality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! 

  • Share this campaign. As stated a couple times already, we really want to pay our skilled artists for their time! If artists can afford to keep doing what they do, the future looks a lot brighter. Or more retrospective at least.
  • We have performances in Seattle throughout the month of October! Click 'going' on our Facebook event to keep posted on all the excerpt and full length performances happening around town. https://www.facebook.com/events/1575002959472919/
  • We're bi-coastal. We're thrilled to be taking this show to New York City in 2017 if we reach past our Seattle goal, and we'd love to get people all over the country excited about sans and challenging norms in classical art and society at large!

We can't thank you enough.
story_txt:
sans Seattle Premiere 
What does it feel like to be without limits? 
We're committed. This ensemble has kept in touch, through projects and respect since our 2014 project "This Is Not A Table for Three" (The Pocket, On the Boards). We're ready to make something that goes beyond what each art form involved can accomplish on its own.
Support a team of artists pushing themselves beyond their thresholds physically, mentally, and emotionally to address problems in the art world and society at large. All while making something daring and new. And you could be an important part of it!
What We Need & How You're A Part of ItWe need about $6,000 to fund a project of this caliber and present it to Seattle, and even more for when we bring it to NYC. So actually, every bit counts:
You will see how every penny of the donations are spent. We are in a position where someone liked our work together in the past, so all the fundraising goes to the artists and money they've invested in this endeavor, both through years of training and their current fiscal contributions to this work.
Some general figures (AKA where your money is going...to skilled artists):

We keep good records, here are some specifics:

We are in the unique position in this community that we can offer workshops of our specific skills, sneak peaks (in person and via the internet), behind-the-scenes looks by professionals, and many more advantages that come with working with generous and seasoned artists. 
The Impactsans is about exploring the problems of gender, using classical springboards and contemporary applications:
The world is rapidly changing, for the better in many ways, but backwards in others. We need to use the arts to battle stigmas and break boundaries, so that we can apply those ideas to every-day life. 
We have learned how to work together, and we trust each other.
We recognize the problems rampant. We're members of our artistic communities. We handle things with care, but are also striving to be fearless.
Risks & ChallengesNudity. We know we've mentioned this show is in the nude. And that's dangerous for a lot of reasons.We'll leave you to think about it. Oh, and classically trained performers reaching into other mediums and defying cultural norms of gender and disciple. Also pretty risky.
We've all been waiting for this challenge. And we've been building our skills and repertoires to give it a go.
We respect each other, our audiences, and our arts.
We're using classical texts, choreography, and music as a means to explore contemporary topics. Artworks like Romeo & Juliet and Medea have survived centuries, we study them in school, but many of the gender issues in these works are still setting the world on fire today.
Our Team (Plus You)sans is created by Lauren Hlubny (experimental theatre director, NYC/Paris), Christin Call (Coriolis Dance a Seattle contemporary ballet company co-founder), Daniel Christensen (Seattle actor involved in Fringe around town, including LiveGirls, Annex, and 14/48), and Joshua Dent (Nashville cellist and music improvisation instructor). The team also includes The Seattle Demo Project (sponsored by Shunpike), the Pocket Theatre (a Seattle arts advocacy venue), Seattle producer/director Wiley Basho Gorn, Seattle filmmakers and photographers Cainen Martens and Bret Doss, Birmingham costumer Cammie Sanders, NYC artist Cathleen Parra, and the Paris&NYC collective Danse Theatre Surreality.Other Ways You Can HelpSpread the word! 
Share this campaign. As stated a couple times already, we really want to pay our skilled artists for their time! If artists can afford to keep doing what they do, the future looks a lot brighter. Or more retrospective at least.
We have performances in Seattle throughout the month of October! Click 'going' on our Facebook event to keep posted on all the excerpt and full length performances happening around town. https://www.facebook.com/events/1575002959472919/

We're bi-coastal. We're thrilled to be taking this show to New York City in 2017 if we reach past our Seattle goal, and we'd love to get people all over the country excited about sans and challenging norms in classical art and society at large!
We can't thank you enough.

story:
Our Story

Described by some critics as the "most obscene play in the Romanian theatre", Nils' Fucked Up Day by Peca Ştefan is a sarcastic, trashy, punk existentialist take on the fucked up choices we have in this fucked up world. Starting 2011, the play is outrageously performed in English & Ro-English by Romanian actors.

Ziua futută a lui Nils, a play written by Peca Ştefan in 2002, has quite a reputation in the Romanian theatre. It was labeled, by elder critics, as being „outrageous”, „obscene”, „vulgar”. At the same time the play has been widely acknowledged by theatre professionals, who saw it as a rebirth of new Romanian playwriting. The text deals with language, Romanian (and global) hypocrisy, and a form of updated, post-modern existentialism in a hyper ironic way, that’s both challenging and guilty pleasure fun. Nevertheless, the play is an unconventional plea for happiness. For six years it was a taboo to stage this play in Romania, although it won one of the most important new playwriting awards (dramAcum, 2002) and was presented in highly acknowledged festivals such as The New Writing Bienalle in Wiesbaden, Germany (2006). In 2008 the MONDAY Theatre @ Green Hours (probably THE place to go if you want to see the most exciting indie/off theatre productions in Romania) dared to produce it, under the stage direction of the author himself. Ever since, the show has been a sold out hit, in its’ Romanian version. In 2011 Peca, an internationally acclaimed playwright (Juilliard Finalist 2010, one of the 5 Authors in the Berliner Stuckemarkt 2010 (Germany), Winner of Heidelberg’s Stuckemarkt Innovation Award 20007 (Germany)), has rewritten the play so we can share the performance with international audiences (both in Bucharest and abroad). Nils’ Fucked Up Day (the new English title) is now a mix of Romanian and English, powered by one of the best VJ’s in Romania (CINTY) combining multimedia, interactivity and a very inciting way to look at the world and its stereotypes.

The cast is made up of 5 of the best young actors in Bucharest, in the tradition of the MONDAY Theatre. Some of them have been in the films of the new wave in Romanian cinema. (You can watch them here in our teasers for this campaign: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_yY42FIlW-c)

The show was selected in this year's edition of the FringeNYC and now the company needs to go to New York City in August and present this innovative story to New York audiences. The performaces will take place at Dixon Place Theatre, in the Lower East Side. To get six performers from Eastern Europe to New York is a costly, difficult challenge. There are VISA and work permit expenses, accomodation and travel expenses that are much higher than for a local company. Though we had the most difficult part covered (the plane tickets and accomodation for 5 of the performers), through the very generous support of the Romanian Cultural Institute in New York - we are still missing 6000 dollars for the other expenses - such as accomodation for the rest of the team, hiring a local light board operator, and minimum perdiems. As you all know - New York is not the cheapest place in the world and through this campaign we are only aiming to cover the minimum, decent costs of living of 6 performers in the Big Apple for the month of August.

The Impact

“Nils’ Fucked Up Day” by Peca Ştefan isan introduction to Postmodern Trash Punk Existentialism in Ro-English, which we think is a deeply original format. We have 5 scheduled performances in New York City at Dixon Place in August as follows: SUN 14 @ 4:15; MON 15 @ 7; THU 18 @ 7:45; SAT 20 @ 4:15; MON 22 @ 3:45.

We hope to have as many New Yorkers as possible being introduced to the best quality indie theatre in Romania (which is not at all present on the NY theatre scene). As a spinoff to the play we want to make a vlog and a YouTube series about the adventures of these Romanian actors in NYC - all of them will be there for the first time in their life - which is quite a culture clash. It's not Borat - it's real!

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

The money goes to partial accomodation of 3 members of our team (the others will be staying at the RCI NY) local transportation (6 30 day Metro Cards for the performers), hiring a local board operator (which is extremely important for the show), building a wood pannel necessary for the set, paying the venue director (the person that takes care of our set), consumable props (used in the play - we can't get them from Bucharest), the participant's Festival fee (which is 600 dollars per company) and a small amount of pocket money for each actor. All of this is very likely to go over 6000 dollars but we are trying to be as realistic and economic as possible. We are trying to fundraise from other sources, and we do have the support of the Romanian Cultural Institute in NY (they covered our plane tickets and part of the accomodation) but each cent in this campaign will help the show happen in its best format.


We are offering a mention for each 15$ donor on our website as "Friends of Nils". For each 60$ donation you get mentioned on our YouTube series and on our website as "Nils' room mate". For a 100$ donation you get metioned on our website, series and printed programme as "Nils' landlord". For a donation between 200$ - 500$ you get to be "Nils' building owner", get all a landlord gets plus free tickets to the show (from 2 to 5, according to your donation). For donations $600 and above you get on our poster, series, website and 6 free tickets as "Nils' Zone Master"... and free accomodation for when you'll be in Bucharest Romania (for 1000$ and up):) 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't have the possibility of financially helping our trip to NYC, there are others way you can help. Share this campaign - you can share it on Facebook, Twitter, post the You Tube clips - spread the word as much as possible. And if in New York City - tell your friends, boyfriends and girlfriends, work mates and generally everyone you know:) that they're welcome to this very special show from Romania, performed in Ro-English. It's fun, fresh, and something they don't get to see for the rest of the year on the NY theatre scene.

story:
This is a post-production trailer created from footage of our most recent world premiere stage play, The Hamiltons, based on the award-winning, independent film by the Butcher Brothers. It is an ideal example of the type of unique, provocative, and edgy work that The Rage of the Stage Players bring to fans of fringe theatre. 

 

PRODUCTION DATES:

October 19, 20, 25, 26, 27
Special Performance: October 31
November 1, 2, 3
   All performances begin at 8pm.

 

The Rage of the Stage Players are currently attempting to raise $1,800 to produce the world premiere of James Michael Shoberg’s latest stage adaptation, Hooked. It is a grim, violent twist on J. M. Barrie’s novel, Peter and Wendy, set in a future London, overwrought with crime and drugs, where societal decay has left the city a ruined husk of what it once was. When an injured young punk, referring to himself only as "Pan," crosses paths with a girl named Wendy Darling, she and her two brothers, John and Michael, are drawn deep into the heart of the city, where even the junkies, prostitutes, gangs, and piratical thugs have something to fear...a disfigured drug lord named James...better known on the streets as "Hook."

 

Your gift will allow The Rage of the Stage Players to proceed with our plans for our upcoming Fall 2012 season. It will allow Western Pennsylvanians to see new and extremely visceral theatre, and allow actors and production crew to continue to practice and share their work with audiences. All gifts are tax-deductible to the full extent of the law. Every gift is deeply appreciated and makes a huge difference. 

 

Who We Are

 

The Rage of the Stage Players are a not-for-profit fringe theatre group that produces original works, with predominantly dark and mature themes. We are, in fact, the only group in Western Pennsylvania that performs such material not merely as seasonal Halloween fare…but instead, as the core of our company’s productions. The Rage of the Stage Players extend the opportunity to any student (18 years of age and older) or adult in the community, who wishes to apply an artistic skill in a theatrical setting. We strive to satisfy darker tastes in art, and thusly, have developed a fan-base composed of those who seek it.

 

 

When I was traveling from West Chester to work with Rage, I was commuting about 350 miles. There are a lot of reasons that I was willing to do this, but two were most prominent. Firstly, it was the most fun I’ve consistently had to this day. The people I met through Rage quickly became, and still are, some of my closest friends. And secondly, our shows were fantastic. The attention to detail in the scripts, costumes, set designs, props, etc., made it feel like a different world. I was excited for every show to go up, because I was proud of all the things we did. I couldn’t wait for my friends and family to see what we had been creating.

-Sean Michael Gallaher, Actor

 

 

I keep coming to Rage performances because the company never fails to deliver creative, witty, edgy and delightfully deviant theater.  It makes me smile and shake my head at the same time, with its unique twists on familiar stories and hilarious takes on the darkest sides of life.  It's entertaining in the most inappropriate ways, and I really love that.

-David Giesler, Patron

 

 

When I returned to Pittsburgh after ten years, I had been annihilated by “Annie,” beaten by Beckett, shaken from Shakespeare, and rocked from “The Rocky Horror Show.” I wanted something fringe, frightening, and fresh. I chose The Rage of the Stage Players and luckily, they chose me, too.

-Lori Howsare, Actress/Artistic Director of One Mom Productions

 

 

Rage has made every mile I traveled worth it. There is simply no other theatre company that puts such immense detail, not only into the original writing, but into creating the magical world, which appears on that page. Every stroke of makeup, fabric of a costume, and board of scenery is so beautifully crafted, that there is no other comparable theatre experience. You aren’t just acting in a play…you are, for at least a brief period, living in this fantastical world of make-believe.

-Alyssa Herron, Actress

 

 

I started working with Rage because of the intense creativity and passion that they put into every show. I'm a traditionally and classically trained actor and a lot of that training can make us complacent and a little stale as artists. Rage challenges me to think differently and to use my skills in new and unusual ways. It's just a lot of fun!

-Dek Ingraham, Actor/Managing Artistic Director of Phase 3 Productions

 

 

Rage consistently promises visually and emotionally engaging productions. Having known the Founders/Producers for many years, I hold them to that promise.  While other theatre groups may fall short, Rage never fails to draw me in, while immersing me in their twisted, dark, and humorous world.  Having personally been able to participate in one of their shows (even in a small capacity), I can say their level of professionalism and dedication to the craft is fantastic. Not to mention, the experience was a lot of fun as well! A few years ago I moved away from Pittsburgh. However, I still make every attempt to return home and catch one of Rage's new productions. Recently I flew home from Florida to attend their production of "The Hamiltons," and was blown away, as usual. I will continue to support Rage in the future and am proud to tell people about the great work Jim and Carrie do. I am looking forward to the next time I can escape for a few hours, forget about life's troubles and enjoy the show.

-Douglas Talotta, Patron

 

 

This is your chance to become part of the dark magic that is The Rage of the Stage Players. Donate now, and join our carnival of theatrical artistry. Every gift, no matter how large or small, makes an impact on our local fringe theatre troupe.

 

James Michael and Carrie L. Shoberg co-founded The Rage of the Stage Players in 2001. Our independent group is comprised of fringe artists, who travel long distances from within Pennsylvania and the Tri-state area to work with us. Lovers of our unique brand of theatre, these artists volunteer hundreds of hours to making The Rage of the Stage Players a success. They appreciate the opportunity to hone their various talents in a theatrical setting. This is best illustrated in the case of The Rage of the Stage Players’ makeup and special effects designer, Greg Lightner, another of our volunteers, who was recently chosen to compete on the second season of  the SyFy Channel’s makeup/special effects reality show, “Face Off.”

 

 

I really have to thank Jim Shoberg, personally, for believing in me, and coming up with these amazing concepts for Rage. I was really only ever an instrument, a medium to realize his vision. In the end, it was Jim, who was muse to me, and inspired every creation. I can take credit for the makeup and designs, but they would be nothing without him, his creativity, and dare I say, genius? Yes, I dare. I love the synergy that we have together.

-Greg Lightner, Makeup/Special Effects Designer  

 

Throughout the company’s ten-year history, most of the productions have been original works conceived by Co-Executive Producer and Artistic Director, James Michael Shoberg.  We have, however, had the occasion and privilege to debut the writing of other local playwrights, as well. This past fall, James received permission fromThe Butcher Brothers and Lionsgate Films, to adapt their award-winning, independent horror film, The Hamiltons, into a live stage play. The Rage of the Stage Players overwhelmingly well-received production of The Hamiltons was featured in Fangoria.com, Pittsburgh Exhumed, Pittsburgh Magazine, and Rue Morgue Magazine. (See Recent Media Coverage below.)

 

Additionally, The Rage of the Stage Players are an annual participant in The Pittsburgh New Works Festival, the only one-act play festival of its kind, helping other playwrights to improve their plays through the process of a first full production. 

 

We Need Your Help

The Rage of the Stage Players, supported solely from ticket sales and individual donations since our inception in 2001, have never received grant money.  Ticket sales cover only 25% of our costs.  We depend on people just like you to donate the rest of the money to help us bring our vision of theatre to the stage. Our seasons are comprised of two shows, one in the spring and one in the fall. Monies made from each production are used to mount the next, with the success of each, determining the scale of the one to follow. The actors and production crew work on a strictly-voluntary basis, donating both time and talent. Though we’ve proceeded independently without significant outside financial support over the past ten years, The Rage of the Stage Players are now in need of funding to continue creating a brand of theatre that is uniquely our own. That is why we are embarking on our first large fundraising campaign. 

 

Recent Media Coverage

Fangoria.com

http://www.fangoria.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5829:writerdirector-talks-qthe-hamiltonsq-on-stage&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=167

 

Pittsburgh Exhumed

http://pghexhumed.blogspot.com/

 

Pittsburgh Magazine

http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Pittsburgh-Magazine/October-2011/Chiller-Theater/

 

 

Producer Biographies

 

JAMES MICHAEL SHOBERG is Co-Executive Producer, Artistic Director, and Resident Playwright of The Rage of the Stage Players fringe theatre company. He has many years of diverse experience, as illustrated by his work as an award-winning actor; a designer; a director; and a writer, with numerous plays and a collection of monologues to his credit. He is well-recognized for his unique scripts, and two of his favorites, Alice’s Adventures in “Wonderland” (a gritty adaptation set in an urban landscape) and Dorothy in Oz (a darkly comedic adaptation set in a mental hospital) have gone on to be produced both nationally and internationally. James serves annually as a producer for The Pittsburgh New Works Festival. In 2012, he will be the first in the festival’s twenty-two year history, to contribute as a producer, a playwright, and an actor (consecutively), all in one season.

CARRIE L. SHOBERG is Co-Executive Producer and Production Manager of The Rage of the Stage Players, handling the bulk of the company’s administrative duties. She is also a designer of costumes, makeup, and props. She frequently appears in Rage productions, having originated multiple roles in premieres, including, Miss Tuttle in Alice’s Adventures in “Wonderland,” and Glinda/Mrs. Goode in Dorothy in Oz. Both plays have since been produced outside of Pittsburgh. Carrie served as a director for South Park Children’s Theatre for ten years, taught both English and Theatre Arts in the public school system, and was on the board of The Washington County Theatre Festival. She currently apprentices with Lightko Studios, acts in local film projects, and is a producer for The Pittsburgh New Works Festival.



*All tickets sold separately.

-Dek Ingraham, Actor/Managing Artistic Director of Phase 3 Productions
 
 
Rage consistently promises visually and emotionally engaging productions. Having known the Founders/Producers for many years, I hold them to that promise.  While other theatre groups may fall short, Rage never fails to draw me in, while immersing me in their twisted, dark, and humorous world.  Having personally been able to participate in one of their shows (even in a small capacity), I can say their level of professionalism and dedication to the craft is fantastic. Not to mention, the experience was a lot of fun as well! A few years ago I moved away from Pittsburgh. However, I still make every attempt to return home and catch one of Rage's new productions. Recently I flew home from Florida to attend their production of "The Hamiltons," and was blown away, as usual. I will continue to support Rage in the future and am proud to tell people about the great work Jim and Carrie do. I am looking forward to the next time I can escape for a few hours, forget about life's troubles and enjoy the show.
-Douglas Talotta, Patron
 
 
This is your chance to become part of the dark magic that is The Rage of the Stage Players. Donate now, and join our carnival of theatrical artistry. Every gift, no matter how large or small, makes an impact on our local fringe theatre troupe.
 
James Michael and Carrie L. Shoberg co-founded The Rage of the Stage Players in 2001. Our independent group is comprised of fringe artists, who travel long distances from within Pennsylvania and the Tri-state area to work with us. Lovers of our unique brand of theatre, these artists volunteer hundreds of hours to making The Rage of the Stage Players a success. They appreciate the opportunity to hone their various talents in a theatrical setting. This is best illustrated in the case of The Rage of the Stage Players’ makeup and special effects designer, Greg Lightner, another of our volunteers, who was recently chosen to compete on the second season of  the SyFy Channel’s makeup/special effects reality show, “Face Off.”
 

 
I really have to thank Jim Shoberg, personally, for believing in me, and coming up with these amazing concepts for Rage. I was really only ever an instrument, a medium to realize his vision. In the end, it was Jim, who was muse to me, and inspired every creation. I can take credit for the makeup and designs, but they would be nothing without him, his creativity, and dare I say, genius? Yes, I dare. I love the synergy that we have together.
-Greg Lightner, Makeup/Special Effects Designer  
 
Throughout the company’s ten-year history, most of the productions have been original works conceived by Co-Executive Producer and Artistic Director, James Michael Shoberg.  We have, however, had the occasion and privilege to debut the writing of other local playwrights, as well. This past fall, James received permission fromThe Butcher Brothers and Lionsgate Films, to adapt their award-winning, independent horror film, The Hamiltons, into a live stage play. The Rage of the Stage Players overwhelmingly well-received production of The Hamiltons was featured in Fangoria.com, Pittsburgh Exhumed, Pittsburgh Magazine, and Rue Morgue Magazine. (See Recent Media Coverage below.)
 
Additionally, The Rage of the Stage Players are an annual participant in The Pittsburgh New Works Festival, the only one-act play festival of its kind, helping other playwrights to improve their plays through the process of a first full production. 
 
We Need Your Help
The Rage of the Stage Players, supported solely from ticket sales and individual donations since our inception in 2001, have never received grant money.  Ticket sales cover only 25% of our costs.  We depend on people just like you to donate the rest of the money to help us bring our vision of theatre to the stage. Our seasons are comprised of two shows, one in the spring and one in the fall. Monies made from each production are used to mount the next, with the success of each, determining the scale of the one to follow. The actors and production crew work on a strictly-voluntary basis, donating both time and talent. Though we’ve proceeded independently without significant outside financial support over the past ten years, The Rage of the Stage Players are now in need of funding to continue creating a brand of theatre that is uniquely our own. That is why we are embarking on our first large fundraising campaign. 
 
Recent Media Coverage
Fangoria.com
http://www.fangoria.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5829:writerdirector-talks-qthe-hamiltonsq-on-stage&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=167
 
Pittsburgh Exhumed
http://pghexhumed.blogspot.com/
 
Pittsburgh Magazine
http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Pittsburgh-Magazine/October-2011/Chiller-Theater/
 
 
Producer Biographies
 
JAMES MICHAEL SHOBERG is Co-Executive Producer, Artistic Director, and Resident Playwright of The Rage of the Stage Players fringe theatre company. He has many years of diverse experience, as illustrated by his work as an award-winning actor; a designer; a director; and a writer, with numerous plays and a collection of monologues to his credit. He is well-recognized for his unique scripts, and two of his favorites, Alice’s Adventures in “Wonderland” (a gritty adaptation set in an urban landscape) and Dorothy in Oz (a darkly comedic adaptation set in a mental hospital) have gone on to be produced both nationally and internationally. James serves annually as a producer for The Pittsburgh New Works Festival. In 2012, he will be the first in the festival’s twenty-two year history, to contribute as a producer, a playwright, and an actor (consecutively), all in one season.
CARRIE L. SHOBERG is Co-Executive Producer and Production Manager of The Rage of the Stage Players, handling the bulk of the company’s administrative duties. She is also a designer of costumes, makeup, and props. She frequently appears in Rage productions, having originated multiple roles in premieres, including, Miss Tuttle in Alice’s Adventures in “Wonderland,” and Glinda/Mrs. Goode in Dorothy in Oz. Both plays have since been produced outside of Pittsburgh. Carrie served as a director for South Park Children’s Theatre for ten years, taught both English and Theatre Arts in the public school system, and was on the board of The Washington County Theatre Festival. She currently apprentices with Lightko Studios, acts in local film projects, and is a producer for The Pittsburgh New Works Festival.
*All tickets sold separately.

story:
$1 = Roughly 60pence

Short Summary

PurpleCoat Productions are a rising theatre and film group based in Liverpool and have been developing for the past four years. Our work has gained us the thumbs up from the likes of Stephen Fry, Sir Ian McKellen and Richard Wilson. We are now being recognised by some of the top players in theatre.

Firstly, we have been invited to perform as part of the 2012 International Youth Arts Festival. Companies come from across the globe in a huge celebration of theatre across two weeks in Kingston, London. Our production of Romeo and Juliet is booked as one of the headline acts at the 900 seat Rose Theatre. Judi Dench recently performed A Midsummer Nights Dream there. In addition, we have been selected by the Royal Shakespeare Company to perform A Midsummer Nights Dream and, with your support, Titus Andronicus at their venues in Stratford.

This is a massive opportunity for us. We have been working relentlessly towards this for the past four years. Now that we are beginning to be recognised we are hoping for all the support that we can get. These shows have been performed in Liverpool by us to rave reviews and now we want to showcase our talent on a bigger scale. This is where we need your help. To put on these shows requires us to cover costs including rehearsal space, props, set and costume. Although we will invest as much as we can into the productions, any financial support gained would help massively.

'They are clearly onto a winner with the cast of talent on view.'
RemoteGoat.co.uk '

The work you've put in both from a production and performance side is, to be frank, astounding and very unique to boot! We see a hell of a lot of potential in your production company. '                                                                       
Dogwoof – UK Distribution House

'One must remember that PurpleCoat is not a large company with infinite funding at hand; it is a small organisation, run by two overwhelmingly determined and talented students. ”
Writings of a Pensive Observer Blog


What We Need & What You Get:

Funding will be spent on:

 
Rehearsal Space:£1050
Props:£300
Costume:£300
Set:£300
Marketing: £300 

The Impact

Any donation, no matter how small, will make a significant impact on the shows. Please donate! If at all possible please help us get the word out there (through social networking, word of mouth) and make some noise about our campaign!
 
Convert dollars into pounds here! http://www.x-rates.com/calculator.html#
 
$1 = Roughly 60pence

story:
THE TENNESSEE WILLIAMS PROJECT

 

Featuring the talents of nine theatre companies in the largest co-production Toronto has seen in years, the Tennessee Project will hit Toronto in MAY 2012! For seven nights, seven productions of Tennessee Williams' one-acts will rotate through seven different Toronto neighborhoods, bringing Tennessee right to the heart of Toronto in an energized, heartfelt celebration of community, culture, and good ol' Tenn.

 

HOW DOES IT WORK?

On May 1st 2012 at eight p.m., productions of the Tennessee one-acts will open in Cabbagetown, Greektown, Roncesvalles, The Annex, The Beach, Leslieville, and St. Clair West. The productions will rotate to a different neighborhood each evening, giving each community seven different nights of Williams.

 

WHAT'S THE POINT?

The point is to reach directly out to Toronto communities, develop relationships with them, and offer them a personal, friendly, uncomplicated theatre-going experience. We at the Tennessee Project believe Toronto has en enormous appetite for art, and seek to make it accessible, amiable, and celebratory, bringing theatre about our communities directly to them; to decentralize theatre from the downtown core and celebrate Toronto's many faces, colors, and textures through the work of Williams - a man who always defended and treasured people from every walk of life. To bring a spectacular, unforgettable seven nights to the city that we love!!

 

BEYOND THE STAGE:

An evening in the theatre, like any form of entertainment, stands to be enriched through knowledge, familiarity, and interaction. The Tennessee Project is founded on the principle that audience outreach is an exciting and integral part of modern theatre that creates a more intimate and thrilling experience for all involved. Over the next few months, members of the Tennessee team will be getting to know each community. We will be volunteering at â€“ and engaging with - local businesses, holding FREE events, opening up our rehearsals, holding â€˜bar banterâ€™ nights and VIP launch events, staging readings at local libraries, and bumping in to you on the street!

 

The companies involved are:      Birdtown and Swanville Theatre Company,  Red One Theatre Collective,  Red Light Theatre District, Afterglow Theatre company, Another Theatre Company,  Theatre Caravel, Written on Water Theatre,   Quixotic Arts Collective, and Black Tea Theatre. 

GREAT! HOW CAN I HELP?

      Support the project financially. We are aiming to cover our costs through fund-raising initiatives like this one. These costs include rights, rentals fees, wages, set and prop purchases, and costs associated with rehearsal space.

      Tell people about the show. Spread the word on sites like Twitter or Facebook, through your email or blog and through word of mouth.

 

WHAT DO YOU GET?

What a fantastic question. Originally, we thought of sending a card and a box of cookies but after giving it some thought, we decided on the options on your right hand side.


WHERE IS THE MONEY GOING?

You deserve to know where your money will be spent! Every penny we raise will be invested into the Tennessee Williams Project. We will use this money to pay for labour, rent equipment, and rent performance spaces.

story:
IMPRO 2012: Die Gorillas' improv festival in Berlin

The festival "IMPRO" is THE international happening for improvised theater in Berlin, Germany. Since 2001 the Berlin based ensemble "Die Gorillas" is hosting this big annual festival. For the 2012 edition, we have invited 35 artists from 12 countries to perform, teach and learn in Berlin. The festival takes place from march 23rd till april 1st with several (parallel) daily shows. Since its beginnings, IMPRO has aimed to bring amazing performers together to develop new forms of improvisational theatre and to have people from all over the world get (to work) together, inspire each other and develop the art form of improv theatre. First and foremost, IMPRO is a ten days-festival for the audience, that gets to choose from a variety of 30 shows that present improv theater in all its aspects: the funny and the dark, the absurd and the emotional, the old and the new - thats why the slogan for our next festival is: Improv can do anything!


What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to close the gap in our budget. We are facing rising costs in e.g. board and lodging for our artists, while we're still not able to pay ourselves or the artists for performing here. We do not get funding for this festival, it is mainly financed by ticketing, workshops and small allocations by some embassy or small companies. We have been hosting this festival with a lot of enthusiasm, passion and gratefulness in the previous years. With your help, we can keep up the festival in its size and internationality. We would like to do so to keep this festival as an inspiration for both our artists and audience, a highlight of the year.
IMPRO was and is a festival that wants to live the close contact between audience and artist. In supporting the festival beyond seeing a show (hey, come see shows at the festival!), you can help to keep this idea alive and be a part of IMPRO 2012 for example by coming to the BIF days, our frame programm for international improvisers visiting the festival (see our website for details). Come and get in touch with the festival!


Spread the Word!

Please support us in making this call for help a success. Tell your friends and family, coworkers and: enemies about this campaign. Because only those who get to know us, can consider helping us in keeping IMPRO the worldclass international Improv comedy festival it is!

story:
Our Story

Two Days 'til Dawn will be having it's World Premiere at the Gene Frankel Theatre, NYC. Tragic, Beautiful and Dream-like, this play will take you on a psychological roller-coaster.


Open Lab Collective is going to be running a production of Tyler Ham Pong's original play, Two Days 'til Dawn at the Gene Frankel Theatre as part of the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity. Two Days 'til Dawn deals with a writer who is searching for inspiration, but ultimately finds madness as he encounters the ghosts of historic literary figures. This play fringes on the pressures of expectation, idolization and responsibility.


Laura Sisskin-Fernandez is no stranger to straddling the line of farce and tragedy, having assistant directed the sold-out run of The Cherry Orchard at the Terry Schreiber Studio. Tyler Ham Pong's previous play, Moony Mercury, was a science-fiction about philosophy, politics and religion. While Two Days 'til Dawn avoids time travel and zombies, it continues his trend of hyper aware dialogue, and analysis of the human condition. Although the dream-like elements will appeal to fans of experimental theatre, the play is also intended for a larger audience, given it's themes of family, trust and love.


The production will be helping raise awareness of environmental issues through supporting the Lower East Side Ecology Center and will be promoting ways to eliminate energy waste. Performance dates are: 


Wednesday, June 8th @ 9:30pm 

Saturday, June 11th @ 3pm 

Sunday, June 19th @ 6pm 

Monday, June 20th @ 4:30pm 

Wednesday, June 22nd @ 7pm 

Saturday, June 25th @ 5pm


Director's Vision

With Director Laura Sisskin-Fernandez's passion for theater as a means to understand daily life rather than to escape it, she dissects the origins and workings of the given circumstances in Two Days 'til Dawn, dealing with themes of the wasted life, mortality, and the artistic struggle. Various levels of reality are established throughout the play, encouraging an objective experience rather than a personal journey. In a society, and especially in such a city as New York, where achieving success has become the highest of priorities, it is easy to relate to the desire to make an impact on the world, while maintaining a connection to one's personal values. 


What We Need & What You Get

It is our goal to carry out a production worth being picked up Off-Broadway. Money raised goes towards set, props, costumes, and promotion.  The higher the quality of the visuals, the more detailed and artistically expressed the production will be. Also, the more we can afford to spread the word (via flyers, t-shirts, etc) and get reviewed by the press, the better our chances are to share the wonderful and complex voices discovered in this play with more audiences. 



Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help raise money simply by spreading the word! Please share this page with others -- friends, family, anyone you think would appreciate this type of production. The future of Two Days 'til Dawn will not be the same without you!


Tyler Ham Pong (playwright) has collaborated with playwright Saviana Stanescu in developing the play E-Dating, directed by Gia Forakis, and has written, produced and starred in Moony Mercury at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre. He has also starred in countless festival-bound short films, and is currently producing his own short film, Dreamer In Exile: a screenplay that has received much attention in more than half a dozen screenplay writing festivals, and was workshopped in Oklahoma for the 2010 Bare Bones International FIlm Festival. His most recent screenplay Breakup Brody won the 2011 Award of Excellence at the Canada International Film Festival. 


Laura Sisskin-Fernandez (director) started directing at Emerson College where she was awarded a grant through the Penelope Hirsch Student Director Award for her production of The Last Days of Judas Iscariot. She continued honing her skills alongside renowned director Terry Schreiber as his assistant director on the sold-out run of The Cherry Orchard at The Gloria Maddox Theater. Currently, she is working with the acclaimed Italian director, Orietta Crispino at TheaterLab.


Two Days 'til Dawn stars Anthony Ames, Mary Monahan, Geoffrey Pomeroy and Jillian K. Waters. 


Costume Designer/Assistant Director is Crys Huyett. Set designer is Samantha Shoffner. Lighting designers are Tracy Wertheimer and Jane Slade. Sound designer is Benjamin Danielowski. Choreographer is Bronwen Carson. 


Performances will be at the Gene Frankel Theatre, 24 Bond St., New York, NY. Tickets are $18.00. For reservations, visit www.planetconnections.org/twodaystildawn. 

.

Performances will be at the Gene Frankel Theatre, 24 Bond St., New York, NY. Tickets are $18.00. For reservations, visit www.planetconnections.org/twodaystildawn. 
.

story:
Short Summary

I am the girl that ran away from the circus to find her own way to dance, to tell stories and express joy through aerial dance. I am an artist and variety performer specialising in hula hoop and low flying aerial dance. Only lately I have nowhere to fly. After 5 years training I find myself dancing alone from the confines of a rickety hammock frame. I need more space, I need a place to float.

My campaign is to escape the hammock frame and get a portable, freestanding rig to devise my own aerial stories and let others come and learn and play on it in a tranquil and intimate setting. This would change me from dancing alone in a stinky bedsit to collaborating with film makers and sharing skills with others but also a greater freedom of movement to express mysef without whacking metal poles. Mostly it will just bring me joy.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

The money pledged will be spent on a 13ft portable aerial rig that is small enough to fit in a studio but big enough for aerial hammock and aerial hoop/dance trapeze. I also need an aerial hammock and the accessories to hang it from.

In return for pledges my perks include artwork, free aerial dance sessions, hula hoops and even the chance to have my future studio named after you.

If the target isn't raised any money pledged will be saved until I have managed to save the full amount needed to purchase a rig.

The Impact

For years now aerial dance and circus has been the love of my life. I have never proclaimed to be great but even the simplest balances, spinning upside down bring this feeling of peace and elation. My little dances are often like songs to me, full of messages and memories and for the last year I have felt kind of inhibited by lack of space. I would love to bring the childish, giddy, 'at one' sensation of floating in dance to others either through performing on film or letting them try it. I want others to feel no pressure, that they can learn a whole routine or just lie and nap suspended to relax a while. If I can not find a studio to put this in I will put it in fields and parks and rooftops, mountain tops anywhere so there is a place to dance like this.

My track record includes 5 years of circus training (some self taught) and performing. My performance work has included the Paralympic Ceremony 2012, cabarets and outdoor events. I have a degree in Theatre Design and Practise and have taught circus skills to adults and children.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

This project is also looking for suitable spaces to erect the rig and if you can help in that way at all please get in touch.

The other great way you can help me without spending a thing is to share this campaign with all your friends and family using the Indiegogo sharing buttons on this page.

Thank you, big love everyone x
story_txt:
Short Summary
I am the girl that ran away from the circus to find her own way to dance, to tell stories and express joy through aerial dance. I am an artist and variety performer specialising in hula hoop and low flying aerial dance. Only lately I have nowhere to fly. After 5 years training I find myself dancing alone from the confines of a rickety hammock frame. I need more space, I need a place to float.
My campaign is to escape the hammock frame and get a portable, freestanding rig to devise my own aerial stories and let others come and learn and play on it in a tranquil and intimate setting. This would change me from dancing alone in a stinky bedsit to collaborating with film makers and sharing skills with others but also a greater freedom of movement to express mysef without whacking metal poles. Mostly it will just bring me joy.
 

What We Need & What You Get
 
The money pledged will be spent on a 13ft portable aerial rig that is small enough to fit in a studio but big enough for aerial hammock and aerial hoop/dance trapeze. I also need an aerial hammock and the accessories to hang it from.
In return for pledges my perks include artwork, free aerial dance sessions, hula hoops and even the chance to have my future studio named after you.
If the target isn't raised any money pledged will be saved until I have managed to save the full amount needed to purchase a rig.

The Impact
For years now aerial dance and circus has been the love of my life. I have never proclaimed to be great but even the simplest balances, spinning upside down bring this feeling of peace and elation. My little dances are often like songs to me, full of messages and memories and for the last year I have felt kind of inhibited by lack of space. I would love to bring the childish, giddy, 'at one' sensation of floating in dance to others either through performing on film or letting them try it. I want others to feel no pressure, that they can learn a whole routine or just lie and nap suspended to relax a while. If I can not find a studio to put this in I will put it in fields and parks and rooftops, mountain tops anywhere so there is a place to dance like this.
My track record includes 5 years of circus training (some self taught) and performing. My performance work has included the Paralympic Ceremony 2012, cabarets and outdoor events. I have a degree in Theatre Design and Practise and have taught circus skills to adults and children.
 
Other Ways You Can Help


This project is also looking for suitable spaces to erect the rig and if you can help in that way at all please get in touch.
The other great way you can help me without spending a thing is to share this campaign with all your friends and family using the Indiegogo sharing buttons on this page.
Thank you, big love everyone x

story:
ENGLISH VERSION FOLLOWS

15X LA NUIT

15X LA NUIT est le tout dernier solo créé par Paul-André Fortier pour le danseur Simon Courchel. Il s'agit d'un solo de 30 minutes présenté in situ en extérieur, la nuit, tous les jours pendant 15 jours.
Paul-André Fortier veut favoriser un contact différent à la danse et au public en choisissant des lieux de représentation inhabituels, intégrés dans la ville et ses activités nocturnes.

Fortier Danse-Création fait appel à votre soutien pour participer à la création de ce nouveau solo et à sa diffusion dans les plus belles villes du monde !

Votre contribution est très précieuse à nos yeux et permettra à Paul-André Fortier et à Fortier Danse-Création de poursuivre leur mission : faire rayonner la danse contemporaine québécoise à travers le monde et toucher de nouveaux publics en rendant accessibles les oeuvres du chorégraphe.

JUSQU'OÙ IRA 15X LA NUIT ?

À partir du 19 septembre, découvrez quelques-unes de nos villes "coup de coeur" pour 15X LA NUIT et aidez-nous à le mener jusqu'à elles !


_____________________________________________________________________

15X AT NIGHT

15X AT NIGHT is a new solo created by Paul-André Fortier and performed by Simon Courchel. It's a 30-minute site-specific solo, performed outside at night every day or 15 days.
Paul-André Fortier wants to offer a different type of contact with dance, audiences and the city itself choosing some unconventional locations, sites that are integrated into the city and nightime activities.

Fortier Danse-Création is calling on its supporters to contribute to the creation of this new solo and its travels to some of the most beautifulcities in the world !

Your contribution is very important - it will allow Paul-André Fortier and Fortier Danse-Création to pursue their mission of gaining recognition for Quebec contemporary dance around the world, and making the choreographer's work accessible to new audiences.

15X AT NIGHT : HOW FAR WILL IT GO?

Starting on September 19, discover some of our favorite destination cities for 15X AT NIGHT and help take us there!

story:
What is Move This World?

Move This World (MTW) is a global nonprofit that uses creative movement as a vehicle to transform conflict, violence and bullying in communities. MTW focuses specifically on empowering individuals with the necessary skills to identify emotions within themselves, be empathetic in their interactions with others, and act as change agents in their communities. Our hallmark program is an innovative, evidence-based curriculum that engages students Pre-K-12 in movement-based activities that promote empathy, mediation skills, diversity appreciation, anger management, and conflict transformation. In this way, MTW fosters cumulative skill building that grows with the individual and produces measurable impact. Using MTW's holistic approach, we engage students, families, educators, administrators, and communities with targeted programs that promote social change through the art of movement.

In partnership with schools, community-based organizations, and families, MTW is building and connecting more peaceful communities in the United States in Baltimore, Newark, New York City and Washington DC and internationally in Colombia, Germany, and the Philippines. To date, MTW has worked with over 10,000 individuals across 22 cities on four continents. Our vision is to change the way we teach and learn, with movement and empathy at the core.

Who are we?

Our team is made up of past and present interns from different U.S. cities and backgrounds who want to share this amazing cause with you. We have seen the power of the innovative, award winning and evidence-based approach, and we believe in it. Together we work on various projects from social media strategy to project development research. 

Summer 2013 MTDubz Interns:

Dayna Foudy is currently earning a Master's in Global Communications and is eager to support and help spread the effects of this research based strategy.

Mohita Satara is a singer and peace educator with an MA in International Affairs, 3 years of experience in driving arts-based transformation programs, and a passion for the MTW movement! 

Deepika Sharma is a senior at the University of Virginia studying Economics and Psychology and loving her summer here at Move This World! 

Janice Vazquez is pursuing a B.A in Business at Brandeis University, and is enthusiastic to create social change through MTW artistic movements. 

Claudia Zurlini is a junior at NYU Gallatin School of Individualized Study with a concentration in Alternative Health Promotion and Empowerment Through Education and a passion for moving and shaking!

Past MTDubz Interns:

Rayna Bagchi is a senior at the George Washington University studying Dance and International Development, who has been crushin on Move this World and all that they do since she interned for them 2 years ago!

Victoria Bradford is a sophomore at NYU College of Arts and Sciences majoring in Political Science. She is making plans to change the world, one day at a time. 

Jose Tochimani just graduated high school and is ready to enter the next step of his life by going to BMCC to study communications. He interned with MTW in 2012 and would like to shake the world with his passion for dance.  

How can YOU move this world?

A contribution, of any size, to our Indiegogo campaign will help us here at Move This World to continue the work we do. You can also get involved by sharing this campaign with your family and friends, notifying schools and community centers of our programs and learning more at www.movethisworld.org. Follow the links to like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and read our blog! 

We appreciate the love.

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT

Whitman Drama teamed with Theater Unlimited DC is a troupe of college bound and college level performers from the greater Washington, DC area. These young people have come together to explore the struggle of adolescence in Duncan Sheik & Steven Sater’s musical Spring Awakening through the eyes of those closest to its content: themselves. The company is composed of over 30 student perfomers, musicians, technicians, designers and 3 mentoring adults (chaperones).Our production has already been accepted to perform in the 2013 Edinburgh Fringe Festival at:

Augustine's - The Sanctuary
located in Augustine United Church
41 George IVth Bridge

 

We need your help getting there by supporting our campaign to raise funds for production expenses.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost to transport the students and the show to Scotland and participate in the festival will be approximately $130,000.

Each student is paying for his/her own travel food and lodging expenses, and as a group, the students are committed to a wide variety of fundraising activities in an effort to secure the necessary financial support. 

Donations will go to renting the theater space, attainting the legal rights of the show, costumes, set design, shipping of insturments, lighting and sound equipment. 

Additionally you can see our "perks" listed to the side in consideration for your generous support.

Whitman Drama is an award-winning high school drama department directed by theater professional Christopher Gerken. Whitman Drama is structured very much like a conservatory program. The department's primary focus is on the process of artistic development rather than the end-product. Students are responsible for ALL aspects of theater production. They participate in multiple theater components — everything from on-stage performance to design to technical and production management. The organization has an annual Student Producer, annual Student Stage Manager, annual Student Technical Director, and assistants to these positions who change per production. It strives to promote intelligence, commitment, diversity and an understanding of the human condition by applying techniques based in realism. Whitman Drama especially emphasizes student involvement and ownership. The program is based in Bethesda, Maryland. Whitman Drama has successfully performed at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival twice before with productions of Songs For A New World (2008) and The Laramie Project (2011).

ABOUT THEATER UNLIMITED DC

Theater Unlimited DC is a 501(c)(3) theatrical production company specializing in the teaching and performance of the musical theater genre to the Washington DC metropolitan area.  Theater Unlimited DC offers a series of summer camps, workshops, and stage productions to children 18 years old and under.  These activities are designed to foster and build the creative process and arts education for a diverse community.  All programs offered are constructed to include participants from every social, economic and cultural background within the community in order to create a diverse learning experience. 

 

ABOUT SPRING AWAKENING 

When German playwright, Frank Wedekind completed his play Fruhlingserwachen(SPRING AWAKENING) in 1891, he ignited a firestorm of controversy and censorship. Over 100 years later, this seminal story about teens struggling with their sexuality continues to be performed all over the world! 

Winner of 8 TONY Awards, including BEST MUSICAL, SPRING AWAKENING celebrates the unforgettable journey from youth to adulthood with a power, poignancy, and passion that you will never forget. Adapted from Frank Wedekind’s 1891 expressionist play about the trials, tears, and exhilaration of the teen years, it has been hailed as the “Best Musical of the Year” by the New York Times, New York Post, Star Ledger, Journal News, New York Observer, and USA Today. 

 

ABOUT THE FRINGE FESTIVAL

The Edinburgh Theatre Festival is the largest and most prestigious performing arts festival in the world. Each August Edinburgh, Scotland becomes a magical place as performing artists from all over the world come to Scotland to take part in the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.  The whole city becomes a stage as visitors view performances from every possible venue, from playgrounds, to conference rooms, to city parks, to churches. The Fringe Festival includes over 18,000 different performances of music, theatre, and dance during its three week run. Whitman’s  performance will be showcased in the first week of the festival in August in 2013.

 

THE IMPACT

SPRING AWAKENING is a tragedy and the themes and issues that the main characters deal with in SPRING AWAKENING produce tragic consequences still today. However, through artful exploration we have the power to be catalysts for change. By bravely and honestly discussing the issues in SPRING AWAKENING, audience members can personally prevent the tragedies that befall the characters in Spring Awakening. The famous playwright, Bertolt Brecht, once said of theater that, “The point is not to leave the spectator purged by a catharsis but to leave him a changed man (or woman), to sow within him the seeds of changes which must be completed outside the theater”. We embrace these seeds of change.

  • According to studies conducted by the the Center for Disease Control, when parents talk to their children about sexuality, the children are more likely to delay intercourse, have fewer partners, and use contraception.
  • For youth between the ages of 10-24, suicide is the third leading cause of death and results in more than 4,400 deaths each year in the US.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We cannot do this without the support of our friends, family, and Spring Awakening fans all around the world. Together we will breathe new life into Frank Wedekind's greatest work.

We appreciate any and all support you are able to give us. If you are not able to donate to our project in the way of monetary funds, please do what you can by sharing this Indiegogo campaign with everyone you know. Post it on your Facebook page, send out a tweet, a carrier pigeon, alert the local press, stand on a soap box, send out your best smoke signals, and let the world know all about us.

WHO IS GOING

The Girls
Wendla – Julia Medine
Martha – Katherine Paterson
Thea – Erin Craig 
Anna – Nicole Ramirez
Ilse – Aliza Daniels
Brigitte - Jessie Mann
Female Ensemble – Nikki Ladd, Natalie LaRoe, Elena Schwam

The Boys
Melchior – Ryan Savage
Moritz / Ulbrecht – Jake Zeisel
Hanschen / Reinhold – Lucas Weals
Ernst / Rupert – Teddy Sullivan
Otto / Dieter – Noah Franklin

The Adult Women – Sara Wright
Frau Bergman, Wendla’s mother
Frau Gabor, Melchior’s mother
Frau Bessell, Martha’s mother
Fraulein Knuppeldick
Fraulein Grossenbustenhalter

The Adult Men – Christopher Gerken
Herr Gabor, Melchior’s father
Herr Stiefel, Moritz’s father
Herr Rilow, Hanschen’s father
Herr Neumann, Ilse’s father
Herr Sonnenstich

Pit Orchestra
Conrad Mascarenhas, Keyboard
Lindsay Worthington, Second Keyboard
Carson Lystad, Guitar
Jordan Wolff, Drums

Directors
Director: Christopher Gerken
Producer: Sara Wright
Music Director & Adult Conductor: Vince Lorusso
Vocal Director: Haruka Nakagawa

Student Conductor & Music Coordinator: Olivia Weals


Technical Crew
Stage Manager: Daniel Levine
Technical Directors: Nikolas Allen & Hailey LaRoe
Lighting Designers: Nikolas Allen & Stephen Indrisano
Sound Designers: Alex Allen & Lindsay Worthington
Costumes Designers: Daniela Gomes & Victoria Happ
Properties Designers: Brandon Babbit & Evan Lund
Publicity Managers: Tessa Berry & Harry Cash
Assistant Stage Managers: Brandon Babbit & Victoria Happ
Additional Stage Crew: Keegan Sullivan & Niels Verhoeven

story:
What We're Doing

Pipeline Theatre Company closes its 4th season this March with Adam Szymkowicz's Clown Bar, a clown noir, directed by Andrew Neisler.

When Happy’s junkie brother Timmy is found dead, Happy returns to his old clown life to ask a few questions. But can he go home again without getting sucked into the seedy clown underbelly of vice and violence?

This will be a fully emmersive envirnmental production and we need your help to enhance our designs and take our very special show the extra mile.

The Impact

Pipeline prides itself on our collectivity and the empowerment of our peers by offering the opportunity for full-scale, fully funded, fully organized and realized Off-Off Broadway productions. Our topsy turvy Clown Bar world will be equal parts whimsical and threatening, and we need your help to truly bring both these elememts to life.

What We Need

In line with our mission of delivering imaginative adventures, this show will transport our audience into a whole new un-explored world, but we need $2,000 more to enhance our designs and create a seemlessly emmersive experience. We envision giant clown shoes, original head to toe clown costumes, elaborate make-up, an interactive environment, and hundreds upon hundreds of clown noses.

Need another incentive? This year we recieved our 501(c)3 nonprofit status and now all of your donations are tax-deductible (minus the value of your chosen perk)!

Any amount, big or small is greatly appreciated and incredibly helpful! 

Who We Are

PIPELINE THEATRE COMPANY is a downtown Manhattan-based non-profit theater company, comprised of 23 emerging actors, directors, and writers. Pipeline makes theater of the imagination. We thrive on adventure and believe no story is worth telling without a little risk. Above all, we aim to leave you with stories that stick somewhere in your heart, your brain, or your guts.  Productions include: Timberlake Wertenbaker's The Love of the Nightingale, Tim Chawaga's Sleepless City (World Premiere), Psycho Beach Party, Alex Mills' Shakespeare the Dead (World Premiere, 2010 Dream Up Fest at Theater for the New City), Bekah Brunstetter's Fat Kids on Fire (directed by Tony nominee Peter Frechette), The Caucasian Chalk Circle (Winner! 2011 NYIT Awards for Original Music, Cormac Bluestone - Composer, and Nominated for 2011 NYIT Award for Lighting Design), Colby Day's Felix & The Diligence (World Premiere), Timberlake Wertenbaker's The Ash Girl, and most recently Colby Day's Giant Killer Slugs (World Premiere, 2012 Dream Up Fest at Theater for the New City).

Our Brave New Works, whisper & SHOUT, and Hung Up series, produced in tandem with our mainstages, develop and support adventurous original material and deepen connections with our ever expanding network of artists.

 

Thank you for helping to make this wonderful show a reality!

- The Clown Bar Team
story_txt:
What We're Doing
Pipeline Theatre Company closes its 4th season this March with Adam Szymkowicz's Clown Bar, a clown noir, directed by Andrew Neisler.
When Happy’s junkie brother Timmy is found dead, Happy returns to his old clown life to ask a few questions. But can he go home again without getting sucked into the seedy clown underbelly of vice and violence?
This will be a fully emmersive envirnmental production and we need your help to enhance our designs and take our very special show the extra mile.
The Impact
Pipeline prides itself on our collectivity and the empowerment of our peers by offering the opportunity for full-scale, fully funded, fully organized and realized Off-Off Broadway productions. Our topsy turvy Clown Bar world will be equal parts whimsical and threatening, and we need your help to truly bring both these elememts to life.
What We Need
In line with our mission of delivering imaginative adventures, this show will transport our audience into a whole new un-explored world, but we need $2,000 more to enhance our designs and create a seemlessly emmersive experience. We envision giant clown shoes, original head to toe clown costumes, elaborate make-up, an interactive environment, and hundreds upon hundreds of clown noses.
Need another incentive? This year we recieved our 501(c)3 nonprofit status and now all of your donations are tax-deductible (minus the value of your chosen perk)!
Any amount, big or small is greatly appreciated and incredibly helpful!
