story:
Help bring a beautiful piece of free theatre to U of M!!

The Secret Garden is Maia Gersten's senior thesis project that we are putting on through the RC Players. The musical is based off of the classic novel of the same name. We chose this show because it is not only an acclaimed and beautiful piece (Tony Award: Best Book of a Musical 1991), but it is also a piece that tackles challenging issues such as death, hope, self worth, and coming of age. Our hope is that through the expression of this piece we will start a conversation among our production team as well as audience members as to how to face and self reflect in times of trouble. The project, which includes 17 cast members and 8 members of the production/design team, is headed by director, Maia Gersten, who is using the musical as a creative outlet and an exploration of the impact of the arts on both artists and audience members.

We are working with a very small budget and are in need of outside assistance to fund our set, costume, and props efforts. Our team is incredibly passionate and driven but we cannot make it happen without your help! With your help, we can make our dream a reality and put on an amazing show. Thank you so much for your generosity!! We can't wait to see you at our show on April 23rd & 24th in the Keene Theater in East Quad.

story:
Santasia - A Holiday Comedy

Santasia is a hit holiday musical comedy that has been entertaining Los Angeles for 15 years. Santasia’s comedy is being compared to Vaudeville and to the likes of the Kid’s in the Hall, SNL and the Carol Burnett Show. This critically acclaimed, award winning, multi-media holiday special has it all!

"hilarious ... a side splitter" ... LA TIMES
Critics Pick ... "comedic perfection ... laugh out loud funny" ... BACKSTAGE
Pick of the Week ... "ingenious ... priceless"... LA Weekly

What's happening?

Santasia has the opportunity to perform a limited run at the St. Luke's Theatre in New York City. This off-broadway house has been home to many hit shows and they have extended a personal invitation to have Santasia perform this holiday season!
This is an opportunity for us to take Santasia, a show that so many people love and adore, and share it with a whole NEW (YORK) audience.


We need your help!

We need your help to bring our Los Angeles show to the poor theatre-deprived people of New York. 


Risks & Challenges

We are also performing in Los Angeles at the same time.  Meaning our cast and crew will have to fly back and forth. We need to double our set pieces, props, costumes, etc!  And of course, Theatre cost.

This unexpected opportunity to take our amazing show to NYC has not been budgeted for. In order to go to New York we must raise funds separate from our Los Angeles theatre cost.  And we ain't got it.

So we need your help.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the "Santasia World Tour" Journey with everyone on Social Media.
  • Plane Tickets - We need to get to NYC and back to LA. Airline Companion Voucher, Frequent Flyer Miles, Private Jet
  • Housing - We need a place to stay while in NYC. Hotel points, Airbnb, blowup mattress, Penthouse suite
  • Pick us up at LAX... or we can fly into Burbank.
  • Any experience you might have in soliciting corporate sponsors.
  • Help us fill the theatre at the St. Luke's Theatre in Times Square, NYC.
  • Join our FACEBOOK page
  • Share this website
  • Visit Santasia.com

story:
Here at The Cinema, we count ourselves among the many unique establishments that Rochester has to offer. Currently we are trying to survive as the venue that you’ve known and loved for the past 30 years. We’re pretty much a movie lover’s dream, in that we show over 100 different films annually of every different genre. We’re a friendly place within the city limits that offers quality concessions and all at very modest prices.

Two years ago, with 35mm film on the way out, we had to upgrade to a digital projector in order to survive. This is a pricey undertaking for a small establishment like us. Thanks to help from many generous donations from the community we have been able to tackle much of this expense. However we are still saddled with a loan payment that has put us in the red every month since we have taken it on. We are asking your help to pay off this loan and get our monthly operation expenses back to normal.

We are still facing over $10,000 of the loan plus interest. We intend to run more campaigns in the near future to help alleviate this expense. Please keep donating to The Cinema. Your help means everything.

story:
We hope this finds you well! We are raising money to debut OUTLIERS Theatre Co. with an intimate production of Jean Genet's THE MAIDS:

Two sisters, Claire and Solange, struggle to believe their existence as maids is anything but sub-human. Each night they enact a secret revenge fantasy while their mistress is away, but the game leaves them unsatisfied. When their attempt to destroy Madame's love affair goes awry, their hope for transcendence grows increasingly slim. A desperate hunger for dignity drives their sadistic ritual to new depths.

 

 

From Director Ben Gunderson:

“Growing up gay in North Dakota was growing up in a forest of secrecy. Shame was my second language, compliance and obfuscation my actions. My full self was expressed only in the freedom of private fantasy – and I believed that this fantasy was ‘wrong’.

THE MAIDS hooked me when I first encountered it in college at UNCSA. Genet’s language, his puzzles and his blasphemies, struck at my midwestern heart. His characters worship deviance, revel in smut and rage, and are beautified by their darkness. Their resistance amplifies their dignity.

Genet gave me permission to integrate my darkness and believe that it is a necessary component of my path toward dignity.

THE MAIDS feels immediately relevant in our climate of class warfare and complex gender dynamics, but these issues are only stars in the constellation. The beauty of theatre is the myriad associations born in the spectators, and I wish for our production to ignite unexpected relevances within you.”

Tatianna Noelle is joining us as Stage Manager. Designers will be announced soon.

 

 

Producing theatre in NYC is expensive! In spite of our being an upstart, we are committed to paying our artists and performing in venues with visibility. 

Your donation will 1) pay artist stipends, 2) give us a place to rehearse and perform, 3) help us realize our modest physical production, and 4) aid us in attracting a broad audience with captivating marketing materials.

 

YES! OUTLIERS Theatre Co. is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nation-wide non-profit arts service organization. All donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. OUTLIERS Theatre Co. can accept in-kind donations as well as donations matched by your employer.

 

 

Help us fulfill our mission of Immediacy, Community and Refusal by supporting our debut production of THE MAIDS! This project will employ 7 artists, a stage manager, a technician, and give opportunities to several volunteers and helpers.

If you have any questions please do not hesitate to contact us on our website or at info@outlierstheatreco.org.

WWW.OUTLIERSTHEATRECO.ORG

 

–––

OTHER WAYS TO DONATE:

     SHARE this campaign on Facebook and Twitter

     EMAIL this campaign to your friends and family

     VOLUNTEER to work with OUTLIERS Theatre Co.

 Email info@outlierstheatreco.org with questions, suggestions, etc.

story:
Short Summary

Wild Woman Theatre aims to empower Indigenous women through story and providing artistic opportunities to emerging artists.

Originally developed through Native Earth’s Annimikiig program, SPAWN has since had two workshop readings as part of the Weesageechak Festival in November 2014 and 2016. This spring the play will be presented at a festival in Vancouver, BC at the Vancity Culture Lab. Unfortunately, we did not receive government funding but we are still accountable to the festival. Therefore, we are reaching out to the community for your help.

SPAWN is a new Canadian play that weaves traditional Coast Salish stories with dance and multi-media to tell the story of death and new life. It is the struggle to reconnect to family, culture, community, and land. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our $5,500 budget covers the cost of our set materials, costumes, small artist honorariums, stage manager travel, and printing and marketing costs. Our unique salmon inspired perks get you exclusive access to the show including a selection of our soundtrack by classical guitarist Jake Kalina, SPAWN ticket vouchers for the date of your choice, and reserved VIP seating. Note: For out of town backers we are sorting out a partnership with a local community organization where the incentive tickets can be donated to Indigenous women and youth.

Egg - $5-49 

Benefits:

  • A personalized thank you email from the production team with digital signed poster

Alevin - $50-99

Benefits:

  • A personalized thank you email from the production team with digital signed poster
  • Acknowledgment in SPAWN show program

Fry - $100-249

Benefits:

  • A personalized thank you email from the production team with digital signed poster
  • Acknowledgment in SPAWN show program
  • A digital selection of music from the show by classical guitarist Jake Kalina

Smolt - $250-499

Benefits:

  • A personalized thank you email from the production team with digital signed poster
  • Acknowledgement in SPAWN show program
  • A digital selection of music from the show by classical guitarist Jake Kalina
  • 2 vouchers to SPAWN for the date of your choice May 24 - June 4 2017
  • Reserved VIP seating

Spawners - $500+

Benefits:

  • A personalized thank you email from the production team with digital signed poster
  • Acknowledgement in SPAWN show program
  • A digital selection of music from the show by classical guitarist Jake Kalina
  • 4 vouchers to SPAWN for the date of your choice May 24 - June 4 2017
  • Reserved VIP seating

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can purchase tickets for SPAWN. Details available shortly.
  • Spread the word to your family and friends.
  • Follow us on Social Media for behind the scenes access: facebook.com/WildWomanTheatre/

Meet Our Team

Wild Woman Theatre is lead by three Indigenous women, Cheyenne Scott, Nyla Carpentier, and Ashley Bomberry. The production of SPAWN will employ 11 emerging artists providing material for their portfolios and experience for their resumes in addition to a small honorarium in acknowledgement of their skills and hard work.

Cheyenne Scott: Playwright and Co-Director 

(Coast Salish First Nation) Her work is an exploration and celebration of her indigenous heritage through impactful personal expression and storytelling. Cheyenne strives to create complex positive contemporary indigenous characters. Her work is often inspired from the land; actively moving and writing from its sources. She co-wrote her first piece Zero Visibility as part of the AMY Project and had a full production at SummerWorks 2013. Winner Best New Media Award at the 2014 imagineNATIVE Film and Media Arts Festival for her Indigenous Routes interactive poem UHKE. She developed a collaborative spoken word piece Singing River as part of the 2015 PanAm Games Path. 

Nyla Carpentier: Director and Choreographer

(Tahltan/Kaska/French/Scottish) is a multifaceted performing artist currently residing in Vancouver, BC. Since the age of three, Nyla has been powwow dancing, now with 30 years of experience she also teaches the various powwow styles. In 2011, in partnership with Raven Spirit Dance Company, Nyla started the popular Powwow Bootcamp class in Vancouver, BC. In 2014 she created a powwow based dance piece, Equating Echoes with musician David Newberry for Brief Encounters 21. Nyla is also an actor; she’s toured in the TYA show, Raven meets the Monkey King with Axis Theatre and wrote her first play 21st Century Trickster. Recently she was in The Flats/Les Flats by Ginny Collins, a co-production with Prairie Theatre Exchange and Theatre Cercle Moliere in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Ashley Bomberry: Stage Manager

(Mohawk) Multi-disciplinary artist from Six Nations, Ontario. Ashley is an emerging writer, director, and producer working in film, television and web series. Her most recent film work as Executive Assistant on the film Maudie had a successful World Premiere at Telluride Festival 2016 and Canadian Premiere at TIFF 2016. She also works as a stage manager  on various projects, with her latest project titled Paddle Song by Tom Hill and Dinah Christie, performed by Cheri Maracle. Paddle Song has toured to Riddu Riddu in Norway and to the High Performance Rodeo in Calgary, Alberta. Ashley studied Film Studies at Ryerson University and focuses her work on social & cultural documentaries and docudramas. Ashley is currently working as Festival Coordinator for Native Earth Performing Arts and is based in Toronto.

Alana McLeod: Costume Designer

A textile designer and maker of Cree and Scottish decent, residing in Toronto, Ontario. Alana grew up in Northern Ontario and began working with images and fabrics at an early age. From painting onto fabrics to printing photographs, Alana has worked with images and textures consistently. She studied at Sheridan College and became a graduate of Applied Photography (2005) and Textile Design (2010) in Oakville, Canada. Combining her loves of photography and textiles, Alana naturally uses imagery from her home and heritage and also from the Northern Ontario landscape to create textile based art. 

Justin Buyukozer: Set Designer

Justin has a Bachelor's with Specialized Honours in Devised Theatre from York University (Toronto). As a Set and Costume Designer: Festival IV (VCP), Urinetown: the Musical (StageWorks), and Sleepwalk (Chris Di Staulo). Justin has worked on Clock Tower Productions of The Harrowing as an Assistant Director, Co-Producer, Make-up Artist, Set and Costume Designer. Most recently, he provided the set and costume for the web series My Roommates an Escort (MRAE Productions, Katie Uhlmann).

Jake Kalina: Sound Design

A composer and music teacher working at Heritage Music School in Cloverdale.  Originally from Kamloops BC, Jake moved to Langley in 2009 to attend Kwantlen Polytechnic University, earning a Diploma in Music.  Inspired by the forests, waters and mountains of British Columbia, his compositions take on sense of the surroundings. https://soundcloud.com/light-through-leaves

The Venue

The Vancity Culture Lab, or C-Lab, was added to The Cultch during 2008 renovations. This 72-seat black box studio is a cinderblock construction with the latest in acoustical properties and has been referred to as the best “blackout” room in the city.

A textile designer and maker of Cree and Scottish decent, residing in Toronto, Ontario. Alana grew up in Northern Ontario and began working with images and fabrics at an early age. From painting onto fabrics to printing photographs, Alana has worked with images and textures consistently. She studied at Sheridan College and became a graduate of Applied Photography (2005) and Textile Design (2010) in Oakville, Canada. Combining her loves of photography and textiles, Alana naturally uses imagery from her home and heritage and also from the Northern Ontario landscape to create textile based art. 
Justin Buyukozer: Set Designer

Justin has a Bachelor's with Specialized Honours in Devised Theatre from York University (Toronto). As a Set and Costume Designer: Festival IV (VCP), Urinetown: the Musical (StageWorks), and Sleepwalk (Chris Di Staulo). Justin has worked on Clock Tower Productions of The Harrowing as an Assistant Director, Co-Producer, Make-up Artist, Set and Costume Designer. Most recently, he provided the set and costume for the web series My Roommates an Escort (MRAE Productions, Katie Uhlmann).
Jake Kalina: Sound Design

A composer and music teacher working at Heritage Music School in Cloverdale.  Originally from Kamloops BC, Jake moved to Langley in 2009 to attend Kwantlen Polytechnic University, earning a Diploma in Music.  Inspired by the forests, waters and mountains of British Columbia, his compositions take on sense of the surroundings. https://soundcloud.com/light-through-leaves
The Venue
The Vancity Culture Lab, or C-Lab, was added to The Cultch during 2008 renovations. This 72-seat black box studio is a cinderblock construction with the latest in acoustical properties and has been referred to as the best “blackout” room in the city.

story:
FreakFest is a weekly alternative comedy show.

It's a place where performers can show off their weirdest, most outrageous material. No stand up, no improv, all insanity. We've had: a guy eat a cardboard box, a mime instruct two people in one big shirt to peel an orange, and presentations on everything from queer theory to cannibalism.  

What We Need & What You Get

We believe in paying our performers. We also need to pay rent to our theater each week. We are asking for your support so we can continue to afford both of these expenses. Any and all donations we receive will go directly to our rent and our performers, and any extra will go to doing bigger and better shows in the future (advertising, touring acts, props, etc.).  

There are a bunch of prizes you can claim when donating through Indiegogo. We have posters, t-shirts, and some wacky chores we're willing to do for you: like being your butler for a day or walking your pet. We will also be auctioning off more silly stuff at our fundraiser show!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come out to our fundraiser show to show your support for your fellow freaks! August 31st! 10 PM! Under The Gun Theater in Chicago, IL!

Any donation of $15 or more will grant you admission to this special show, but tickets will also be available at the door!

story:
Who & What Is Struck?

STRUCK is a hybrid play/documentary/rock concert drawn from an eclectic group of source materials: Shakespeare’s The Tempest,  Oliver Sacks’ Musicophilia, and co-writer/composer Rebecca Hart’s personal account of a lightning strike in her early composing days.  Struck tells the story of nomadic cult-rock performer Beth Prosser, whose abilities were spawned by a lightning strike that could have killed her at the age of 18. Gifted with music but burdened with a worsening neurological condition as a result, she roams the country in a non-stop tour called the Transient Luminous Event.  When a mysterious storm strands her in her hometown on the ten-year anniversary of the strike, she must confront her family, her past, and herself. Rock music, epilepsy, neuroscience, weather patterns, and a guy in a lion suit.


Robert Saietta and Rebecca Hart are highly accomplished downtown stalwarts who are collaborating on STRUCK. Mr. Saietta is the Producing Associate Director of International WOW, performing and creating over 20 plays in NYC and abroad. Writing Credits include: Yudkowski Returns!, Robert Saietta is a Liar, Mrs. Sweetney, Ordinary Days, Crime Scene Cleaners and others. Ms. Hart is an actor/musician who divides her time between fronting a rock band (www.rebeccahart.net) and acting. Most recently she created the role of ‘Lois_L’ in Anne Washburn’s A Devil at Noon at this year’s O’Neill Conference and at the 2011 Humana Festival (ATL).


Why Do We Need Your Help?

We have been given the opportunity to kick off this year's Ice Factory Festival, presented annually by Soho Think Tank.  While STT graciously provides the space (this year at the glorious 3LD space downtown) and resources (lighting equipment, tech time, marketing), we still have a lot of overhead to cover, from paying our actors, musicians, director, and designers, to covering the cost of rental space for rehearsals, printing costs for scripts, and the dozens of other little costs that add up to a big chunk of money.


Although we have a few sources of income for this project, we are relying heavily on our friends and fans to donate through indiegogo.com/Struck! for support.  Your dollars will go a long way in helping us meet our budget goals.


What We Need & What You Get

So we have some funding trickling in from here & there, friends & family kind of stuff, with some generous donations underwriting parts of the show's budget... but we also have last minute costs (quite a few, actually), and the more we can raise in the next couple weeks, the more splendiforous we can make this show!  Since it's based around the musical stylings of a new-agey rock guru, we thought it would be fun to come up with perks that would allow you to do some 21st Century entertaining, like having Rebecca come to your party and do some Tarot card readings ($100), or have her band play a private concert ($1000).  So not only are you supporting a great cause, you are getting a great par-tay as well! 


Please Spread The Word

If you caught Struck! in its earlier incarnation at HERE last year and liked it, here is your chance to not only see it again in its new and improved version, but to spread the word about it.  Share the info with your friends on facebook, twitter, and all those other social media thingies.  Email folks. Pick up the phone.  Come chill in the Ice Factory @ 3LD!

story:
In this Romeo and Juliet re-imagining, Tybalt and Mercutio now fill the roles of the starcrossed lovers born to be enemies. Constructed around Shakespeare's original dialogue and expanded upon into a love story of intrigue, scheming, and hope, two beloved characters get new life, as they each grow into individuals hoping to find a companion in a world where their sexuality has no voice or champion. Exploring the battle of defining one's heart, and the ultimate tragedy of the many loves erased from history, Starcrossed is, to its core, the story of what happens when love is stifled. 

 

DEVELOPMENT

A newer but fast-moving work, Starcrossed had its first reading in September 2017. Starcorssed will make it's World Premiere at FringeNYC this October. With only three performers, and no substantial set to tell the tale, Starcrossed focuses on the words that build us up, tear us down, and mend our hearts in times of need.

story:
Note: This website is for donations for YATA's production of Dog Sees God....to buy tickets please visit       http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/179219



Our Story

Young Actors Taking Action or YATA for short is an organization who produces shows to benefit worthy charities.  Founded in 2007, our original mission was to perform in various places (such as orphanages and senior centers) that house residents who may not normally have the opportunity to see live theatre, and put on small variety shows comprised of all young actors for their entertainment.  We were very successful in that endeavor, but as time went on we began to think about how we could expand the organization so that we could reach a wider audience and benefit even more people.  The obvious solution was to produce published plays (not just variety shows) and open them up to the general public.  Our hope is that these plays would attract a larger audience and I would be able to give the proceeds from the show to a worthy charity.


The Impact

This year we are planning on producing is a production of Bert V. Royal's Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead and giving the proceeds of the show to The Rachel's Challenge Organization.  The show is a fun, yet deeply touching spin-off on Charlie Brown and the rest of the Peanuts Gang.  In the play, the gang are in their teen years  facing problems and choices that all teens face.  It deals with issues of drugs, sexuality, suicide, and bullying....the latter being the reason I want to donate the shows profits to Rachel's Challenge.  Rachel's Challenge is an organization founded in memory of Rachel Scott, a young women who was the first to be killed in the tragic Columbine shooting of 1999.  Before she passed she kept dairies in which she wrote, "I have this theory that if one person can go out of their way to show compassion then it will start a chain reaction of the same."  That is what Rachel's Challenge is all about.  According to their web site (here is the link: http://www.rachelschallenge.org/) their mission statement is this, "we exist to inspire, equip and empower every person to create a permanent positive culture change in their school, business and community by starting a chain reaction of kindness and compassion." 


What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $2,500 dollars for this up coming production.  This money will cover everything from theatre rental ($2,100), materials for a set (approx. $250), costumes (approx. $100), and other miscellaneous expenses such as printing playbills, and advertisement for the show.  Any money that has been donated and not used will go directly to Rachel's Challenge.


What you will get for your donation:

-For one dollar to $29 you will be listed as a "Friend" in the playbill.

-For $30-$49 you will receive one complementary ticket and a listing as a "Friend" in the playbill.

-For $50-$99 you will receive two complementary tickets and a listing as a "Supporter" in the playbill.

-For $100-$249 you will receive two complementary tickets and a listing as a "Sponsor" in the playbill.

-For $250-$499 you will receive two complementary tickets and a listing as a "Patron" in the playbill.

-For $500-$799 you will receive two complementary tickets and a listing as a "Benefactor" in the playbill.

For $750 and up you will receive four complementary tickets and a listing as an "Angel" in the playbill.


Other Ways You Can Help

Encourage your friends and family to donate and come see Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead on June 16th, 17th, 18th, or 19th d Roy Arias Studios and Theatres located at 300 West 43rd Street Floor 5, Manhattan!



Thank you for your support! 


If you have any questions or comments please do not hesitate to email Taylor at youngactorstakingaction@yahoo.com.

story:
Our Story

People come to Hollywood to make it big. Actors, writers, directors, producers, etc. are all on the hunt to see their names on the big (or small screen). But before TV, and even before movies, there was this great thing called theatre. Having grown up footsteps away from Broadway, theatre has had a great impact on all of our lives. Wouldn't it be fun to strip down the Hollywood dreams for one night and go back to basics? If you answered yes, then...


We're pleased to present:


SANITY IS FOR SUCKERS:

One Act Plays for the Out of Touch


Come see a night of one-act plays on the above theme to help benefit 826LA, a nonprofit writing and tutoring center here in LA.


This performance will be for one night only on:


Sunday, November 6th @ 7PM 

@ Artworks Theatre & Studio 6569 Santa Monica Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90038


PURCHASE tickets here: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/206701


Love,


Alissa Bachner, Melanie Weinstein and Paul Karp


The Impact

If you can't attend in person, you can still contribute to our night. We feel very fortunate that we were able to realize our love of the arts and writing, and we're hoping to help less fortunate children come to that same realization. To learn more about the organization we're donating to, please visit: 


http://826la.org/


Other Ways You Can Help

Send this link to your friends and family! (Please!)

story:
Audiences are the lifeblood of theatre

Why do theatre-makers spend months in rehearsal sometimes putting themselves through emotional and physical torment, and yet do that so willingly? Simply in order to create a production that they hope an audience will connect with and relate to in some way - whether that is to laugh out loud or quietly stifle sobs. Theatre is a shared experience and one that can have a huge impact.

What We Need

What we need is simple - an audience! In order to make this endeavour worthwhile in every sense of the word we osimply need people to see our production. 

Buy a ticket. Come see a stage show that we guarantee will move you. Spend an hour or two completely absorbed in a story that has inspired so many artists before us and has enthralled readers and audiences ever since Henry James created it in 1898. 'The Turn of the Screw' has inspired numerous adaptations including plays, movies, songs and even an opera!

What you get

Our goal is to pre-sell a proportion of tickets for Cabal Theatre Company's staging of 'The Turn of the Screw' at the Cork Arts Theatre from Monday 21st October to Saturday 2nd November, 2013.

This production promises to be one of those unforgettable nights of theatre that leave a lasting impression on those who get to see it. And we are offering certain incentives if you purchase your ticket here ahead of time...

  • Gala Opening Night Tickets with pre-show reception.
  • Souvenir Programme for all ticket purchasers.
  • Special online-only discount tickets for certain nights.

Please check out the full details in the listing.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you won't be able to come along to the show you can still make a difference simply by:

  • Making a once-off contribution.
  • Share this Indiegogo page.
  • Spread the word amongst your friends about the show and this page.

You can help Cabal Theatre Company continue to present work that is challenging and entertaining. You can help in many ways. Please take a moment to browse your options.

About the production

Cabal Theatre Company presents

THE TURN OF THE SCREW

Adapted by Jeffrey Hatcher from the story by Henry James

Based on the provocative tale of suspense, horror and repressed sexuality, this adaptation gives the famous story yet another turn of its own!

A young governess journeys to a lonely English manor house to care for two recently orphaned children. But she is not their first governess. Her predecessor, Miss Jessel, drowned herself when she became pregnant by the sadistic valet, Peter Quint, who was himself found dead soon after under mysterious circumstances. Now the new governess has begun to see the spectres of Quint and Jessel haunting the children, and she must find a way to stop the fiends before it is too late. But one frightening question tortures the would-be heroine: Are the ghosts real, or are they the product of her own fevered imagination?

Starring Chloe O'Reilly (seen recently in the Wolfe Stage School's 'A Midsummer Night's Dream') and Emmet O'Riabhaigh (whose credits include a role in HBO's 'Game of Thrones'). Directed by James Horgan (recent credits as director include 'The Collector', 'Anna Weiss', 'Shakers', 'Moll').

"In his thoughtful adaptation of Henry James' spooky tale, Jeffrey Hatcher does away with the supernatural flummery, exchanging the story's balanced ambiguities about the nature of reality for a portrait of psychological vampirism..."  - The Boston Globe

"It is hard to think of an interpretation of Henry James' famously eerie novella 'The Turn of the Screw' that is more in keeping with James' own intent... Jeffrey Hatcher could have been taking his cues directly from James' preface to the story: 'Only make the reader's general vision of evil intense enough, and his own experience, imagination, sympathy and horror will supply him quite sufficiently with all the particulars.' The key word is imagination. In this beautifully executed adaptation... the audience is forced, through subtly ambiguous shadings, to vividly project what is cleverly left unseen and unspoken. A dazzling act of the imagination. Mr. Hatcher has pushed James' clever turn to its furthest degree.""  - The New York Times

"In his thoughtful adaptation of Henry James' spooky tale, Jeffrey Hatcher does away with the supernatural flummery, exchanging the story's balanced ambiguities about the nature of reality for a portrait of psychological vampirism..."  - The Boston Globe
"It is hard to think of an interpretation of Henry James' famously eerie novella 'The Turn of the Screw' that is more in keeping with James' own intent... Jeffrey Hatcher could have been taking his cues directly from James' preface to the story: 'Only make the reader's general vision of evil intense enough, and his own experience, imagination, sympathy and horror will supply him quite sufficiently with all the particulars.' The key word is imagination. In this beautifully executed adaptation... the audience is forced, through subtly ambiguous shadings, to vividly project what is cleverly left unseen and unspoken. A dazzling act of the imagination. Mr. Hatcher has pushed James' clever turn to its furthest degree.""  - The New York Times

story:
UPDATE FROM THE MEENA'S DREAM TEAM: Our initial goal of $16,000 was set to cover the costs of creating a music album, high-quality film, and seed money for our first production on tour. However, this is covering just the beginning of our efforts. Should we exceed our goal (!), we wanted to let you know what we would do with additional funds:

+$1,000: fund to offset ticket prices so that when touring, we can ensure that we have a diverse audience across class, race, culture, and experience 

+$2,000: airfare to bring Anjna, Rajna and Sam to a tour site, not just Anu with a CD.

+$5,000: covers our kick-off tour production - a short weekend run of Meena's Dream in a city near you!

[Video clip taken from a 2013 workshop of Meena's Dream at University of Maryland.]

Hi! We’re MEENA’S DREAM TEAM - Anu, Anjna, Rajna, Sam, and Ronee, and more – and we want you to join our campaign to give our play a future life after the January 2014 World Premiere at Forum Theatre.

Our Story Begins with Anu Yadav, actress and playwright.

"I started writing Meena's Dream, a play about a young dreamer who fights the evil ‘Worry Machine’, to help me not blame myself for when times got hard – when I was displaced and in need of housing, without health insurance, when money was tight. In our society, more of us are living without our basic needs. I was 12 when my father died, as my mom successfully juggled caring for my brother and I, going to night school, and working various jobs so we could have enough.  Social security helped us not fall through the cracks. I worried, “What if something happened to my mother?” I got scared. Growing up Hindu in Iowa, at night I dreamed that Lord Krishna sat on my bookshelf watching me sleep. My dreams would lead me to be a playwright and actress. But the worries of my youth no longer held me captive. 

We live in an abundant society, yet somehow we get the message that living with scarcity is an individual problem due to our personal failings. We are alone. This is the heart of the Worry Machine. People remain homeless while homes remain empty. Patients go without medicine as medicine is thrown away. This is the struggle of young Meena.  I'm hoping this play can help support public dialogue about these contradictions, invite people to remember their own childhood dreams, and keep envisioning the possibilities for a world where everyone has enough.

This January Forum Theatre will produce the World Premiere of Meena's Dream. I’m working with three incredible musicians, Anjna Swaminathan, Rajna Swaminathan and Sam McCormally, who have created a live original score for the play." 

Then Entered the Band: Anjna, Rajna and Sam

"When Anu invited us to work on the music for Meena's Dream, the three of us were coming from very different musical backgrounds. As we began working together on composing the score, we formed a mutual aesthetic and rapport that fluidly combined all of our influences into a unique sound. Over the past two years, we have continued to learn from one another, and discovered that the music we've created has the scope to impact people beyond the context of the play. We call our band The Worry Machine. What is particularly noteworthy is the cross-cultural nature of this music: the South Indian classical tradition is being used in a novel way in conjunction with other textures derived from jazz and indie folk to evoke the complex yet universal emotions of the play. Just like the play, the music straddles multiple worlds and identities, and conveys a message of its own.

Enter our Directors: Caleen, Paige, and Patrick

Meena was lucky to have not one, but over three directors contribute to it's development and life. Caleen Sinnette Jennings directed the reading of Meena's Dream at Arena Stage, Paige Hernandez directed the workshop production at University of Maryland, and Patrick Crowley is currently directing the world premiere at Forum Theatre. All made a distinctive and invaluable contribution.

Going National: Ronee, our Touring Producer

"I started working with Anu because I was inspired by her passion for people and for change. I was surprised by how deeply Meena’s Dream affected me. The play courageously looks healthcare and poverty in the eye, and makes us grapple with what to make of it. With humor, imagination, and great artistry, this body of art works a little magic - bringing each audience member to a vulnerable place where they can imagine something better. I’m passionate about bringing Meena’s Dream to a larger audience."

Our Goal: We want to make a video, a music album and begin touring the play. Will you help us?

Making a theater production is tough. Trying to also produce a music album and a high-quality video that captures the spirit of the live performance at the same time is even harder. We want this to live on past the walls of the theatre, and hopefully inspire more dialogue about the kind of world we should all keep hoping and fighting for. 

Join us. Fight the Worry Machine. Contribute today.

WHAT WE NEED:

Meena's Dream Music Album = $4,000

Sometimes finances and scheduling don't allow all key artists to be present on tour. Meena's Dream will need a high-quality recording of the musical score created by Anjna, Rajna, and Sam so that audiences can experience the full work as envisioned, even if our musicians can't be present with Anu. If we reach our $4,000 goal we can record a full album- a soundtrack with extended versions of the pieces from the score, but also including some pieces that didn't find their way into the show.

Meena's Dream Video = $10,000

For theatre presenters and producers far from Washington, DC to consider booking Meena's Dream, they need a video of the performance so they can evaluate the work. The $10,000 goal would allow the Meena's Dream team to go even further and create a high-quality film for potential audiences who can't get to the play. This video is critical for the artists to represent and advance their work locally, nationally, and internationally and generate interest in a future life for Meena's Dream.

Meena's Dream Tour Start-Up Funds = $2,000

Getting on the road often means self-producing at first. The $2,000 will provide seed funds for the first traveling production of Meena's Dream, which will require funds for travel, housing, and publicity.

All donations directly go to the actual costs of the video, album, and tour, and are TAX-DEDUCTIBLE. Rhythm Fantasies, Inc. is the fiscal sponsor of our campaign, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that strives to promote South Indian classical music and dance in a space that encourages education and enrichment through innovation and cross-cultural collaboration. The artistic directors of Rhythm Fantasies- Anjna, Rajna, and P.K. Swaminathan- have been engaged in this mission as presenters, performers, and educators, working to keep these traditions relevant to the contemporary Indian diaspora and to demonstrate how we can continue to find meaning and expression in ancient art forms. 

PERKS AND CONTRIBUTIONS:

Check out the great perks (at right) that come with supporting the arts! You can also contribute to the success of Meena's Dream by sharing this Indiegogo campaign, or by getting in touch with us. Leave us a note at meenasdreamteam@gmail.com. We want to hear how Meena's Dream intersects with your work, hopes, and dreams. If you live in the Washington, DC area, please join us at Forum Theatre's production of Meena's Dream January 8-18th, 2014 in Silver Spring, MD. http://forum-theatre.com/meenas-dream

Thank you, and see you at the theatre!

story:
Our Story

My name is Petronia Paley and I am an actor/playwright/director. I wrote On the Way To Timbuktu because I had to. I needed to create a unique American-African woman unlike any I'd seen, been offered, or played. I needed to release a part of my creative spirit that I had not owned or recognized as a valid and necessary voice. On The Way To Timbuktu is a multi-media one woman performance play that uses live music, projections and Shakespear's sonnets to explore the world of a college professor in a psychic breakdown. In additon to that story,  I had to tell the story of yet another mysterious and unknown woman of color who fascinated, gripped and would not turn me loose. My play deals, with gender issues, sexuality, racism, and love's vagaries. It is the story of three involved in a love triangle without compromises.

 

The Impact

My first indiegogo campaign was a steep learning curve adventure. On my way to fundraising, I learned a great deal and had some success (my heart felt thanks to  all of you who heard my plea and generously donated). But the journey to production continues. Let me tell you what was a very positive outcome of my first campaign--I've booked a theatre and have sheduled 9 performances for February 2012! I also have a fundraising event planned for December.  I hope to see you there. That February deadline looms large and I have a long way to go. I urgently need you and your support now!

What We Need & What You Get

Those of you who create theatre know and understand the the costs of production n New York. In orer to create the magic, your gift wil help provide for the following:
  •  Director
  •  Musician
  •  Designers
  •  Rehearsal space
  •  Supplies

Other Ways You Can Help

Please know that no amount is too small, from small seeds, giant oaks grow. If you are unable to give financially, whether you  shout or whisper, you can  spread the word to friends, bosses, co-workers and family. Forward the email. Volunteers are always needed. Thank you so very much. My mother thanks you.

story:
Project Overview

This spring marks the 5th year anniversary of NYC (and formerly Boston) based contemporary/modern company Grant Jacoby & Dancers. Over the past five years, we have been beyond fortunate to have the opportunities to present work throughout New England, New York City, and beyond, including, but not limited to: La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, Movement Research, Green Space, The Dance Complex (Boston Globe Critic's Pick 2014 & 2015), Green Street Studios (Boston Globe Critic's Pick 2016), AS220 (Dorry Award 2016), RAW Boston (2014 Performer of the Year), and The International Festival of Arts & Ideas.

This April, in line with our five year mark, Grant Jacoby & Dancers will present a brand new work, entitled "American Pearl," at Triskelion Arts in Brooklyn, NY as a part of their Split Bill Series. This opportunity is a huge step forward in our audience visibility and networking presence here in NYC. However, we need your help to make it all happen!

What Is This All For?

In order to keep us up and running through this project, as well as the remainder of our 2019-2020 season, we are hoping to raise $5,000 to cover our various rehearsal and production costs. We have a lot of exciting things on the books, including, but not limited to, the premiere of “American Pearl" in April , an encore of the work as a part of The Dance Complex’s Festival of Us, You, We, & Them in June, and an upcoming under-wraps (for now) project, set to premiere in NYC in early 2020.

The entirety of the funds raised, regardless of if we reach our goal, will go towards the following:

  • Compensating the artists involved with "American Pearl" (3 dancers, a composer, and an administrative assistant) for their hard, dedicated dancing work.
  • Reimbursement for studio rental space; we have been fortunate to receive a subsidized grant from Triskelion Arts, supported by the New York State Council on the Arts and the Mertz Gilmore Foundation, however there is still much more than needs to be covered!
  • Promotional materials that include: photo and video documentation of the performance, flyers/postcards, etc.
  • Securing funds for our next project, set to premiere in early 2020

Your Impact

Making dance professionally, and independently, is hard work! All of the artists involved have donated countless hours & energy to make this project come to life; it only seems right that they are all compensated for their diligent efforts. However, funding for the arts is extremely difficult to come by, and many choreographers, like myself, have to reach out to supporters like you to make it all happen!

It has been a dream come true to run this dance company for the past five years, and it has all been possible because of generous donors who have helped ensure our success. No matter what, we plan on being around for another five years, and beyond, but anything you can do to help us out in the interim is beyond appreciated!!

For your generosity, we are offering the following in terms of compensated perks:

  • Bronze Patron ($10) - Shout out on social media!

  • Silver Patron ($25) - Shout out on social media and a personalized thank you letter!

  • Gold Patron ($50) - Shout out on social media, personalized thank you letter, and footage of the April 2019 performance!

  • Platinum Patron ($100) - Shout out on social media, personalized thank you letter, footage of the April 2019 performance, and 2 tickets to our 2020 performance!

  • Diamond Patron ($500) - Shout out on social media, personalized thank you letter, footage of the April 2019 performance, 2 tickets to our 2020 performance, and a special choreographed thank you dance!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are fully aware that some people just can't contribute--and that's ok! However, that doesn't mean there aren't other ways you can help help:

  • Come to one of our performances!! "American Pearl" is set to be presented twice in 2019: first at Triskelion Arts in Brooklyn on Friday April 12 and Sunday April 14 at 7:30 PM, as well as at The Dance Complex over the weekend of June 21 (exact date and time TBD). Please check out the links below for more info!
    • Triskelion Arts Split Bill: https://www.triskelionarts.org/split-bill-apr-2019
    • The Dance Complex Festival of Us, You, We, & Them: http://www.dancecomplex.org/festival-of-us-you-...
  • Share this campaign and/or ticket links! We always love reaching new audiences, artists, and patrons, so any way you are able and willing to share our info via e-mail, social media, or word of mouth is greatly appreciated!

I cannot thank you enough in advance for your support. Here's to lots of dancing and dance making in 2019 and 2020!

 

xo Grant

story:
LEMONS

What does it mean to be inside or outside of one’s own body?

 

This is the question that led Rebecca to her new play lemons, largely constructed from pieces of direct transcript of Laura (Rebecca's mom) discussing what feeling grounded in the body means to her. There is no separating Laura's--or Rebecca's--understanding of this topic from Laura's 30+ years living with lupus (she was diagnosed at age 20, the same age Rebecca was when she wrote the play). Between her mother’s words are short vignettes from Rebecca’s own life, exploring how these topics inform their relationship with each other and the bodies they call home. Rebecca may perform alone but the play is a conversation between these two women. lemons reveals an honest, complex story of life with chronic illness--one that never resorts to heroic or tragic cliches, one that leaves room for humor, bitterness, and joy.

 

Where?

lemons has been accepted into two upcoming festivals in 2019. The first production will be through NYC Summerfest and performed at the Hudson Guild Theatre on W26th St on August 29, August 31, and September 1. The play will next be produced by United Solo at the historic Theatre Row on 42nd St on October 30 with the possibility of more performances later that fall.

To spread the word to those dealing with this chronic illness personally and the people in their lives, we have teamed up with the Lupus Research Alliance.

To learn more about lupus, please follow this link. To learn more about the LRA, follow this link or reach out to Rebecca, who can put you in contact with their team.

Tickets for Summerfest

Tickets for United Solo

 

Who?

Rebecca assembled a creative team of Josh Walker and Claire Marieb, two collaborators she met during her time at the National Theatre Institute. Josh and Claire are collaborating together as the director and producer for the piece. Josh Walker is a Philly-based director, playwright, and producer, Josh’s most recent work includes The Pass Me Over Party, which will be seen upcoming at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Claire Marieb is a New York-based performer, director, and producer. Up next Claire will be directing a main-stage production of Caryl Churchill's Top Girls at Sarah Lawrence College.

 

Our Ask

Mounting these productions requires a substantial investment of time, love, and money from all three of us. So, today we are asking you to support this project in any way you can: coming out to see our work, spreading the word, and donating. We want you to help us meet our goal of $4,500 to make these productions possible.

 

Raising $4,500 would cover…

  • The base fees for both festivals
  • Production costs (including rehearsal space, design and documentation)
  • Transportation
  • Marketing (Promotion of the piece on social media, flyers and posters)
 

Without these contributions Rebecca and her mother's story will not be able to be told. Anything helps, whether it be $2 dollars or $200 or a share of our story and this post.

 

These festivals have led to the success of many shows and having the opportunity to have this piece seen by the public would open doors for Rebecca, lemons and our entire production.

 

We need your help to share this story.
story_txt:
LEMONS
What does it mean to be inside or outside of one’s own body? This is the question that led Rebecca to her new play lemons, largely constructed from pieces of direct transcript of Laura (Rebecca's mom) discussing what feeling grounded in the body means to her. There is no separating Laura's--or Rebecca's--understanding of this topic from Laura's 30+ years living with lupus (she was diagnosed at age 20, the same age Rebecca was when she wrote the play). Between her mother’s words are short vignettes from Rebecca’s own life, exploring how these topics inform their relationship with each other and the bodies they call home. Rebecca may perform alone but the play is a conversation between these two women. lemons reveals an honest, complex story of life with chronic illness--one that never resorts to heroic or tragic cliches, one that leaves room for humor, bitterness, and joy. Where?
lemons has been accepted into two upcoming festivals in 2019. The first production will be through NYC Summerfest and performed at the Hudson Guild Theatre on W26th St on August 29, August 31, and September 1. The play will next be produced by United Solo at the historic Theatre Row on 42nd St on October 30 with the possibility of more performances later that fall.
To spread the word to those dealing with this chronic illness personally and the people in their lives, we have teamed up with the Lupus Research Alliance.
To learn more about lupus, please follow this link. To learn more about the LRA, follow this link or reach out to Rebecca, who can put you in contact with their team.
Tickets for Summerfest
Tickets for United Solo
 
Who?
Rebecca assembled a creative team of Josh Walker and Claire Marieb, two collaborators she met during her time at the National Theatre Institute. Josh and Claire are collaborating together as the director and producer for the piece. Josh Walker is a Philly-based director, playwright, and producer, Josh’s most recent work includes The Pass Me Over Party, which will be seen upcoming at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Claire Marieb is a New York-based performer, director, and producer. Up next Claire will be directing a main-stage production of Caryl Churchill's Top Girls at Sarah Lawrence College. Our Ask
Mounting these productions requires a substantial investment of time, love, and money from all three of us. So, today we are asking you to support this project in any way you can: coming out to see our work, spreading the word, and donating. We want you to help us meet our goal of $4,500 to make these productions possible. Raising $4,500 would cover…

The base fees for both festivals
Production costs (including rehearsal space, design and documentation)
Transportation
Marketing (Promotion of the piece on social media, flyers and posters)
 Without these contributions Rebecca and her mother's story will not be able to be told. Anything helps, whether it be $2 dollars or $200 or a share of our story and this post. These festivals have led to the success of many shows and having the opportunity to have this piece seen by the public would open doors for Rebecca, lemons and our entire production. We need your help to share this story.

story:
The Internet: LIVE is a live comedy game show where players bring web content to life with a series of hilarious, impossible challenges inspired by memes, viral videos, and internet culture of yore. The Internet: LIVE is the newest co-production from The Arcanists, Inc., creators of the cult, interactive variety show The Tarot Reading (“one of the city’s more unique theatrical offerings”--DCist). It is co-produced and hosted by ScienceAF’s Rachel Pendergrass, creator of the science variety show Solve for X and host of the monthly powerpoint drinking game Nerd Nite DC. It plays for one weekend only, Jan 31 and Feb 1, 2020 in the upstairs bar of The GOAT, across the street from Clarendon Metro. It’s digital comedy一no scrolling required.

Backing The Internet: LIVE now gets you a bunch of cool crap, including a presale ticket to either show. There are only two nights, so getting one now means you can brag about it later when the show sells out. It also supports local entertainment, unavailable on netflix and disney+, which makes you, like, an influencer...we guess?

Did we mention the cool crap? Check out our cool crap.

This program is supported in part by Arlington County through Arlington Cultural Affairs, a division of Arlington Economic Development, and the Arlington Commission for the Arts.

story:
Short Summary

We have developed this show through in-kind contributions from Fringe and The Lir, but we need your help to bring it to audiences. Your contribution will help us to pay for venue costs, costume and props hire, and the tech required to realise this ambitious project to best capacity.

We also think it's really important to pay people. As this immersive work requires a limited audience, profit share will be small. Your contribution will ensure that our wonderful team is compensated for their time.

We are excited and passionate about this show, the cause and conversation around climate change, and new and challenging ways to tell stories. We would be so grateful if you would consider lending us your support to tell this one.

 

Thank you

 

Sam & Lauren

story:
Leslie Parker Dance Projects strives to utilize dance art as a means to challenge our collective assumptions, to lift up and broaden awareness. We will start production for  a  thesis performance work starting in January 2017 to premiere at Hollins University in summer 2017. 

Your contribution will go towards-

  • Rehearsal space
  • Artist fees
  • documentation

"Moving Dialogue for Non-Violence"  is a platform to use dance art as a  catalyst for social change by leading movement workshops to facilitate dialogue.

Your contributions will go toward solidifying "Moving Dialogue for Non-Violence" in residence at Broadway Women's House Shelter  as regular programming for Spring 2017.   The larger goal is for MDNV to travel across the country reaching people of color, to collaborate with art therapists and provide opportunities for public performances within a communal setting. 

Leslie Parker Dance Project values the power of the collective as well as  independent artists/thinkers who advocate ingenuity, integrity and interdependency. LPDP is  striving to increase an individual donor base to sustain within a competitive market and to be of service.

story:
WHO WE ARE, WHAT WE'RE DOING 

  • A Gathering of the Tribe has been a home for hungry artists since 1991. Steve Cannon has been a mentor to Phoebe Mar for six years, helping her navigate her career and artistic life. Katelyn Pearce and Phoebe Mar met 7 years ago during a production of THE LIBATION BEARERS at another NY institution, American Theatre of Actors. Since then they have not stopped collaborating in film and tv... and now they want to go back to their roots on the stage. http://www.tribes.org/
  • There is no substitute for live theater... even when we use it to talk about TV. Live theater creates a relationship between audience and actor that is magical and ephemeral. They are in the moment together, effecting one and other. The audience is essential to this moment, which can be created in no other medium. 
  • From the seeds of a simple idea, "let's put on a play," Phoebe and Katelyn have already brought an artistic community together that will keep growing and creating work for artists... especially because everyone who is a part of the this project is being compensated for their time and talent, which so often doesn't happen. 
  • C.S. Hanson is a powerful female voice in the theater world. She has already given us opportunity and we want to shine more light on her unique voice. 
  • Lastly, we chose to produce our work at Theater for the New City, a paragon of independent theater, that only produces original work and reinforces the grassroots message.
  • https://www.facebook.com/TVINMYBONES/

We Need Funding For: 

  • Theater rental
  • Payment for actors, director, playwright, stage manager, set designer, sound designer, costume designer, and light designer
  • Sets, props, costumes
  • Marketing: art work, printed materials, mail outs (we needs butts in the seats) 
  • Rehearsal space
  • Insurance for the space and the actors
  • Food for the cast on long rehearsal days

Risks & Challenges

Our deposit for the Theater Rental is in. And the contract is signed. So we will be at the theater August 10-13th no matter what. Help us not get evicted for our art. We are brave, but we don't want to be homeless. Please help. Think of Marty and Ripley, Katelyn's beloved cats. 

Our experience in performing and producing has prepared us to tackle this challenge. You want proof? Check out both seasons of our multi-award winning web series So SOHA on YouTube: http://www.sosohatheseries.com/

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word of our campaign to your wealthy friends and theater lovers! 
  • Come come come to the show!

story:
Fur Elites opens in Winter 2015 !

 ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪


Previews on January 29th + February 5th,

Opening Night on February 12th !

 

 ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪

 

 

Fur Elites is a new musical set in (and written/produced) in Chicago, Illinois. Synopsis:
 

Denny, a small, quiet boy in a big, mad city is working as an assistant at Ecnayonna Furs, a retail fur shop in a high end shopping district. The characters that orbit Ecnayonna Furs are of the oddest sort; former models, wildly wealthy global elites, international fur dealers and even the occasional illustrious vagabond. Based on actual events, Fur Elites is an absurd, parlor musical about finding the light in a world trying to eclipse you.

 

 

 ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪ ✪

 

Have you ever wanted to express yourself but felt limited to do so?

Well thanks to CrowdFunding and the Creative Community Spirit of Theatre limitations are a THING OF THE PAST !

When writing this play, we did NOT ever think it would get green-lit and staged! Now that it is, we need $2.27mm in order to detail the set with authentic fur jackets, Real Charles Shaw Wine & a whole lot of other wildly luxurious items that are certain to bring this (opening) production of Fur Elites to a new tier of  WOW!

All the music from the video is Original Music produced in Chicago, IL by Declan Murphy (the writer of the play, and a member of the cast!) we hope you enjoy, and further, hope you come out to see Fur Elites opening February 12th at the Annoyance Theatre & Bar !

story:
Hello, My Lovelies!

Cameron here.

Well, this is it.

I applied to my first international burlesque festival- and I was accepted. I applied with three of my best acts, and I have been accepted for every act I applied with. I'm still a little in shock at this news. London has been at the top of my places to go since I was a kid- my parents brought me up on Shakespeare and live theatre, and it has always been a dream of mine to go there.

If you told me a few years ago that I would have the opportunity to perform on stage in London f*cking England, I would have straight-up laughed in your face. (There's a personal story there, but I don't want to get off-topic.) This is beyond my wildest dreams, and I am overwhelmed.

Obviously, the purpose of this fundraiser is to help cover my expenses to London. I am putting whatever I can towards it personally as well, but as far as I understand, it is possible that I'll end up raising more than my goal. For the purpose of transparency, I would like to tell you that I already have plans for what I will do in the event that this happens. One of the things that would be a huge asset to me at this point in my career is a wireless microphone- many of the acts I do would benefit greatly from me being able to use both of my hands, including two of the acts that I applied with. (Back here at home, you'll be seeing more live-singing/stripping numbers from me! *winks*)

However- if I exceed my goal by over, let's say, $1200- I would like to purchase another plane ticket. I want to bring my mom with me. She has been one of my biggest supporters from the very beginning, and it would mean more to me than I can possibly express to have her there and share the experience of my first international performances with her. She is also older, and does not have the finances to afford a trip like that at this point in her life. (Details aside, finances have been tight for my folks in recent years.) However, if I do raise the funds for this I will videotape her reaction to me telling her that I'm taking her with me- trust me, it will be incredible.

But- I realize that I am lucky to have the support network I do in the first place, and do not want to take advantage of this. So if you are only comfortable donating your money directly to my travel expenses, please tell me and that will be the only thing your money will go towards- not a mic or my mum coming with me. Transparency is my goal, and I would never want to jeopardize that.

Almost done here, I swear. I want to throw it out there that I am fully aware that there are plenty of amazing causes out there- so if this isn't something you feel inclined to donate to but have the resources to donate to something, anything, everything- please do so. If you choose to donate to another cause you deem more worthy, I'll still be thrilled because there's someone out there benefiting from this.

Lastly: I thank you for your time, love, support, and everything else you all do for me. Each and every one of you continue to lift me up and inspire me like nothing I have ever experienced before, and you make me want to be a better performer, and person, each and every day.

I end with a promise- I will do you proud to the absolute best of my ability.

All of my love,

Master Cameron Eric Leon

P.S. Perks are still in the works- thank you for your patience!

story:
THANK YOU FOR HELPING ARTISTS AT PLAY REACH AND SURPASS OUR GOAL! We can't wait to see you at the LATC this fall for In Love and Warcraft. TICKETS ON SALE HERE: http://bit.ly/AAPWarcraft 

WHO WE ARE | Artists at Play is a theatre-producing collective of Asian American creative professionals in Los Angeles. We will present the West Coast premiere of Madhuri Shekar's In Love and Warcraft, directed by Alejandra Cisneros.

(from l. to r.) Producing Artistic Leaders Stefanie Wong Lau, Marie-Reine Velez, Julia Cho, and Producing Member Nicholas Pilapil

Since our debut in 2011, we have garnered box office success and critical acclaim with the L.A. premieres of Ching Chong Chinaman, Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them (Ovation Recommended, GLAAD Media Award Nominee), Cowboy Versus Samurai,  and last year's 99 Histories. We proudly continue our tradition of curating quality works missing from the local landscape with our first West Coast premiere.
WHAT WE'RE DOING | In our fifth year of producing, we present In Love and Warcraft, a fresh look at the collision between online gaming and In Real Life (IRL) relationships. We have all been fans of Madhuri Shekar’s work, a delightful intersection of humor, love and subculture, and this play is no exception. Evie-- gamer girl, college senior and confirmed virgin-- has it all figured out. Not only does she command a top-ranked guild in Warcraft with her online boyfriend, she also makes a little cash on the side writing love letters for people who've screwed up their relationships. Love is like Warcraft, after all. It's all about strategies, game plans, and not taking stupid risks... or is it? 


In Love and Warcraft will have a 4-week run at the historic Los Angeles Theater Center (LATC) in September-October 2015. Our fundraising goal is $8,000, which will cover venue rental and rehearsal fees at this beautiful space in the artistic hub of Downtown L.A.  We also aim to provide proper stipends for artistic and technical personnel as we elevate production values, befitting this new space and the more fantastic elements of this particular show.

WHAT YOUR SUPPORT MEANS | Artists at Play envisions a Los Angeles community where Asian Americans are recognized as both theatre-makers and theatre-goers. Our productions represent a new generation of voices in American theatre that transcend the label of "Asian American" or "minority." Your support for In Love and Warcraft and Artists at Play will help promote more diversity and inclusion of Asian American artists and stories in the local theatre landscape. With our latest show, we continue to further contribute to the Los Angeles theatre community as we strive to create entertaining and challenging work that is accessible to anyone and everyone.

Watch our video to check out 5 reasons to support this show, and then share with 5 of your friends. Please note that through the fiscal sponsorship provided by Fractured Atlas, donations are tax-deductible. As Artists at Play continues to grow and develop, thank you for your support!

story:
THE STORY

Clarice Lispector was a Brazilian writer lauded as the most important Jewish author since Franz Kafka. Her work is innovative, beautiful, deeply stirring, and often unsettling. Her final novella, The Hour of the Star, was completed just weeks before her death in 1977.


Benjamin Moser is a writer, editor, critic, and translator who was born in Houston in 1976 and lives in the Netherlands. His first book, Why This World: A Biography of Clarice Lispector, was published by Oxford University Press (USA), Haus Publishing (UK), Cosac Naify (Brazil), and Civilização (Portugal). Editions are forthcoming in France and Germany. He is the Series Editor of the new retranslations of Clarice Lispector to be published in the United States by New Directions and in the United Kingdom by Penguin Modern Classics. And is the translator for the 2012 edition of The Hour of the Star, published by New Directions.


In The Hour of the Star, Rodrigo S.M. has given up sex and soccer to write the story of Macabéa, a poor typist living in Rio de Janeiro who survives on nothing but hot dogs and dreams of one day becoming Marilyn Monroe. Traveling through Rodrigo’s wretched soul as he uncovers Macabéa’s thin and tragic story, we find that in the midst of darkness even the smallest moments of beauty make life worth living.


This isn't a traditional theatre project. It is a cross-disciplinary collaboration, lifting Clarice's words from the page and giving them life as a live event. Clarice's original text, illuminated through the brilliant English-language translation by Benjamin Moser, has been transformed into a theatrical event by our creative team.


OUR JOURNEY

From Dara: This process started over 8 months ago with a recommendation to read Clarice. From the moment I started reading The Hour of the Star, I was hooked. I jumped down into the rabbit hole, bringing friends, family, and collaborators to join me on this weird and wonderful journey attempting to capture this restless and enigmatic literary figure and all of the lessons and questions pulsing through her text.


We have an incredible team creating this piece including: Blake Palmer (set), Mike McGee (lights), Holly Rihn (costumes), Nolan Lem (sound), Justin Drobinski (video and projections), Kate Dial (stage management), Jolene Noelle (dramaturgy), and Meghan Long (producer).


And a super talented cast: Ean Sheehy*, Ana C. Ribeiro, Broderick Clavery, Claudia Acosta, Zuleyma Guevara*, and Theodore Bouloukos. (*Appearing courtesy of Actor’s Equity Association)


Now, we are a few days away from starting rehearsals, just weeks before getting the show up on its feet, and we need your help.


WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT

In The Hour of the Star, Clarice writes, “let those who read me get punched in the stomach to see if it’s good. Life is a punch in the stomach.” You should support this project if you desire work that punches you in the stomach, that makes you re-consider the world around you and think deeply on what it means to be human. We have been so incredibly inspired by this project and we can’t wait to share this experience with you.


By donating to this project, you become a part of our company.


Your contribution will support everyone working on this show through artist stipends and help us purchase materials for set, costumes, lights, video and sound.


FEBRUARY 2015

Mark you calendars! This show is coming to The Connelly Theatre February 18-21, 2015. The Hour of the Star is Dara Malina’s Columbia University School of the Arts directorial thesis production and part of the 2014-2015 Columbia Stages Season. Check out more info here (http://columbiastages.org/season/2015/dmalina.html).


THANK YOU!
story_txt: THE STORYClarice Lispector was a Brazilian writer lauded as the most important Jewish author since Franz Kafka. Her work is innovative, beautiful, deeply stirring, and often unsettling. Her final novella, The Hour of the Star, was completed just weeks before her death in 1977.Benjamin Moser is a writer, editor, critic, and translator who was born in Houston in 1976 and lives in the Netherlands. His first book, Why This World: A Biography of Clarice Lispector, was published by Oxford University Press (USA), Haus Publishing (UK), Cosac Naify (Brazil), and Civilização (Portugal). Editions are forthcoming in France and Germany. He is the Series Editor of the new retranslations of Clarice Lispector to be published in the United States by New Directions and in the United Kingdom by Penguin Modern Classics. And is the translator for the 2012 edition of The Hour of the Star, published by New Directions.In The Hour of the Star, Rodrigo S.M. has given up sex and soccer to write the story of Macabéa, a poor typist living in Rio de Janeiro who survives on nothing but hot dogs and dreams of one day becoming Marilyn Monroe. Traveling through Rodrigo’s wretched soul as he uncovers Macabéa’s thin and tragic story, we find that in the midst of darkness even the smallest moments of beauty make life worth living.This isn't a traditional theatre project. It is a cross-disciplinary collaboration, lifting Clarice's words from the page and giving them life as a live event. Clarice's original text, illuminated through the brilliant English-language translation by Benjamin Moser, has been transformed into a theatrical event by our creative team.OUR JOURNEYFrom Dara: This process started over 8 months ago with a recommendation to read Clarice. From the moment I started reading The Hour of the Star, I was hooked. And a super talented cast: Ean Sheehy*, Ana C. Ribeiro, Broderick Clavery, Claudia Acosta, Zuleyma Guevara*, and Theodore Bouloukos. (*Appearing courtesy of Actor’s Equity Association)Now, we are a few days away from starting rehearsals, just weeks before getting the show up on its feet, and we need your help. Life is a punch in the stomach.” You should support this project if you desire work that punches you in the stomach, that makes you re-consider the world around you and think deeply on what it means to be human. We have been so incredibly inspired by this project and we can’t wait to share this experience with you.By donating to this project, you become a part of our company.Your contribution will support everyone working on this show through artist stipends and help us purchase materials for set, costumes, lights, video and sound.FEBRUARY 2015Mark you calendars! This show is coming to The Connelly Theatre February 18-21, 2015. The Hour of the Star is Dara Malina’s Columbia University School of the Arts directorial thesis production and part of the 2014-2015 Columbia Stages Season. Check out more info here (http://columbiastages.org/season/2015/dmalina.html). THANK YOU!

story:
The Info

Beth Liebowitz & Artists is a company of dancers, musicians, actors and visual designers led by choreographer Beth Liebowitz. We collaboratively create work based on human connection and both our physical and psychological environments. In August 2014, Triskelion Arts invited BL&A to be part of their Split Bill Series, on January 8th & 10th, 2015. For the past 3 months we have been creating Gateway Dance, a triptych of movement inspired by different cultures of addiction including uppers, downers, and technology. Here is the show info: http://www.triskelionarts.org/split-bill-january-3


You & Us

- We need your help to offset the costs of creating this piece. Funds we generate from this campaign will go to paying the 6 dancers and 3 musicians first and foremost, who have collectively put in around 70 hours of rehearsal time during this process, with more to come! 

-Our goal is to raise $2000. $1300 will be paid to the dancers, $200 will be paid to the musicians, and $500 will go towards the cost of renting rehearsal space, costumes, and props.

-Anything and everything helps. Please consider donating in the name of art, or the holidays, or whatever may motivate you. There are a few perks you can receive in return as well!

 The Impact

By donating to the premier of Gateway Dance at Triskelion Arts, you are supporting the arts in a direct way. Gateway Dance will be a 30 minute piece that showcases the talent and voices of young artists trying to do what they love in NYC. We hope to offer you a visual feast of dance, music and costumes that make you feel, think and smile.
