story:
My Story

I have been dancing since I was 6 years old.  I currently dance 5-6 hours each day training in classical ballet, modern, jazz and contemporary. 

 My mom is divorced and the sole provider for our family.  She is working to support me and my sister while she is attending college to complete her degree and working on a non-profit to help women leaving domestic abuse.  She has always kept me dancing no matter what! 

I have auditioned for Ailey since I was 10 years old.  I was accepted each time but unable to attend financially.  Last year, thanks to a 50% tuition scholarship and a successful fundraiser, I was able to attend Alvin Ailey’s Summer Intensive-Professional Division.  I worked hard while I was there and I loved every moment.  The instructors were amazing.  It was a very successful learning experience which helped me earn a full tuition scholarship at this year’s summer intensive audition.   

At my age and level it is critical for me to be able to attend this intensive in New York to receive the training specific to Ailey that isn't available in my area so I will be prepared to audition for acceptance to the Certificate Program of the Ailey School next year.  My short-term goal is to get to New York this year to attend Ailey’s summer intensive to have training and performance opportunities with them and for them to be able to assess my ability, work ethic and focus.  Then I will return home to complete my senior year of high school since I won’t meet the age requirement to stay in the housing.  When I am 18, I will audition for the Professional program and hopefully begin a long, successful career with Ailey. 

 Any generosity that helps me overcome our family's financial struggles so I may achieve my fundraising goal to continue pursuing my dream of dancing with Ailey will be greatly appreciated.

My Fundraising Goal = $5,000

The tuition for the 6-week Alvin Ailey program is $2,755.  Fortunately, I received a tuition scholarship to cover all of that except for fees of $430.  However, I still need to raise a substantial amount of money to be able to attend the Summer Intensive.  Almost $3000 is required for the Ailey housing at Fordham University.  Ailey estimates additional costs of meals and other living expenses of $1800+ and I will need travel expenses to and from NYC.  I am planning local fundraisers to try to offset the additional costs for dance clothing, etc. 

The Difference Your Contribution Will Make in My Life

When I went to Alvin Ailey last year, I felt like I belonged there.  I knew I had found my path.  I grew so much as a dancer during my six weeks at Ailey last summer and I know I will gain even more this summer. During the 2014 Ailey Summer Intensive an audition was held for scholarship and admission to the year-round school.  I was accepted with a full scholarship except fees but unable to stay in the housing since I had just turned 16. I believe I will have a successful experience at this year's summer intensive also and you will not waste your money by helping me get there. 

My Dream

I hope to be a company member with Alvin Ailey in the future. I plan to gain everything possible from this year’s summer intensive at Ailey, and then audition for the year-round school once I turn 18 and achieve my high school diploma.  From the school, I will be trying to get accepted into Ailey II and hopefully one day the company.  I realize there are no guarantees on any of this but this is dream and has become my life’s goal.  Your contribution would mean the world to me.  It may mean the difference between whether I am able to continue to pursue my dream of becoming an Ailey dancer.   You will be helping a dedicated dancer who doesn’t have the necessary financial support to participate in the training she needs to become a professional dancer.  

Challenges

It will be challenging to raise this amount of money in 60 days but I am hopeful there will be enough people in the world who would like to enjoy an Ailey performance one day and have the additional joy of knowing they helped one of the dancers make it to that stage. 

  • My life has had challenges financially but I never quit.  I always give my art everything I have in me. 
  • Indiegogo wants to know what I will do with the money if I don’t achieve my goal.  I don’t believe that will happen, but if I don’t raise all the money needed, I believe I will still make it to Ailey.  Even if I have to go for a shorter time, I need to be there. The money will be used for Ailey training no matter what. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you in advance for your contribution!  I know sometimes you want to help but you can’t contribute financially.  That doesn’t mean you can’t help though!

Please share this on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc. and ask your friends to help spread the link to their friends.  Please help me get the word out about what I am trying to achieve.  I don't have much time to make this happen!  Thank you so much!

story:
Welcome!

Hello Dance Enthusiasts, 

Deborah Karp Dance Projects is thrilled to share with you our newest work, Standing On One Leg, to be premiered at the Joe Goode Annex in San Francisco, September 12-14,  alongside the brilliant Aura Fischbeck Dance. Since 2005, Deborah Karp Dance Projects been creating and performing original dance in Washington D.C., New York, and now the San Francisco Bay Area. This is our biggest choreographic endeavor yet and a huge step forward in our growth as a dance company. We've spent nearly a year in the studio developing this work and now we're ready to share it with the world! 

The Work:

Standing On One Leg investigates the relationship between the internal, private self and its public, external opposite. Movement-based research, exploration, and questions guide this work. What is the outward, performative expression of a shifting, inward landscape? How does the meaning of a simple movement change when executed with an internal focus instead of an external, audience-minded focus? 

We feel incredibly fortunate to work with a rockstar team of artists for this, our newest project, Standing On One Leg. The dancers performing this work are Janet Das, Mo Miner, and Deborah Karp, with lighting design by Delayne Medoff, costume design by Emma Jaster, an original score by musician Robert Lopez, and 72 feet of Astroturf. 

Why 72 feet of Astroturf?! We are attracted to this bright green, platicky grass both aesthetically and metaphorically; for the vibrant color it brings to the black dance floor and expansive white walls of the Joe Goode Annex, and for the significance of something natural replaced by something terribly artificial.

Your Impact:

Producing an evening of dance utilizes human resources: time, ideas, and dedication  to create a sustainable livelihood for working artists. And, the fundraising it takes is no different. In our current economic climate of increasingly limited arts funding, grassroots, crowd-sourced fundraising has become a vital part of what allows the dance community to flourish. The dancers and artistic staff of Standing On One Leg have given tirelessly of their resources and now we're reaching out to you! 

Your support of Deborah Karp Dance Projects you will have an immediate impact by going directly to artist fees and the costs associated with presenting dance, such as rehearsal space rental, theater rental, publicity, and documentation. 

The show is less than 2 months away and we're reaching out to you! 

Please consider supporting artistic livelihood by helping us meet our fundraising goal!

It could look like:

$10 from 300 people or
$25 from 120 people or
$50 from 60 people or 
$75 from 40 people or 
$100 from 30 people or
your choice!


If you're not able to contribute at this time, please consider sharing this campaign with a friend and coming to the show! 

With sincere appreciation and deep gratitude, Deborah Karp Dance Projects
For more information please visit deborahkarpdanceprojects.com

story:
Eugenia Woods, Playwright and Producer for Taproot Productions is proud to be collaborating with ZUZI! Dance Company and Director Marc Pinate on this workshop production of THE MIGRATION PROJECT, a theatrical docudrama about human migration and our efforts to create a safe and enduring home.


We live in a time of rapid and dramatic demographic change, with the rate of migration higher than at any other time in human history. People are migrating at unprecedented rates due to war, global warming and its impact on the environment, globalization and its impact on local and regional economies, and oppression associated with race, religion, sexual and gender orientation.

For the past 2 years, Woods has been gathering stories from refugee, immigrant, indigenous and homeless communities, weaving together the challenges of the journey, the lives left behind, and the dreams of a new life into a dynamic, interdisciplinary performance. We have traveled to the sacred Hopi mesas to talk with traditionalist elders and a younger generation struggling to balance the lure of city life with the spiritual call of the kivas. We have played theatre games and conducted story making activities with refugee children and witnessed their mothers' stories in the intimacy of a closed story circle. We have visited the homes of undocumented immigrants whose multi-generational families straddle a dangerous and militarized border. We've engaged the general public in interactive art installations and created performance poetry on the fly at the Tucson Museum of Art. Now it is time to bring the voices of our diverse program participants to the stage.


The project, funded in part by Tucson Pima Arts Council, is scheduled for a workshop production on November 14, 15, 21 and 22 at ZUZI! Theatre in Tucson, Arizona. We are committed to sharing this important work free of charge to 135 people (mostly project participants) on November 14, and need to raise extra money to pay artists, purchase wardrobe and props, increase technical value of the production by renting video projectors and buying time for audio and video editing. A word here about paying artists: grant money helps artists develop and produce work, but generally speaking, most artists cannot make a living with the stipends they are paid. We are losing great talent every day due to financial stress, and that will unquestionably impact the quality of art you consume, and the quality of life in your community.

It is our hope that, through this work, audiences will recognize the common issues we face when we are compelled to leave our home of origin to pursue a new life in a foreign land. It is our hope to foster empathy and a welcoming attitude in our changing communities. Even the smallest donation helps to break resistance and move these voices further into the mainstream of our national conscience. We cannot afford to ignore or resist the changes that are happening in our world, and the growing diversity of our communities.

Even if you cannot afford to contribute anything financially, please do consider spreading the good word about THE MIGRATION PROJECT.  Many thanks to you all for your attention and for lending your energy to this work.


THE MIGRATION PROJECT opens November 14, 2014 for one free performance for project participants, collaborating artists, and the theatre and dance community.

Performances continue November 15, 21 and 22, 7:30 p.m. at ZUZI! Theater, 738 N 5th Ave in Tucson.

Tickets are $18, $15 for students, seniors and military.

For more information or to reserve tickets call 520 975 4021 or email the migration project at themigrationprojecttucson@gmail.com.
